content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
Title: Among the SleepGenre:  Action, Adventure, IndieDeveloper:  Krillbite StudioPublisher: Krillbite StudioRelease Date: 29th May 2014TL;DR, VerdictReally interesting premise for a horror game. Takes camera away from you a lot so motion sickness can be an issue. Worth the play if you want something a little different from typical horrors.*Note as a motion sickness gamer I will keep trying to play this game because I do like it.* P.S : this game made sure I looked suspicious  to my teddy ProsGood voice actingGood atmosphere and soundsBright, contrasting environments for your main character, the sort of colours you expect to see in a small child's roomConsIf you have video game motion sickness, don't play this Gameplay This game focuses on a toddler's view of the world, and how their active imagination distorts things and makes things more unsettling. You start off looking into the bottom of a glass, except the effect is confusing - just like how a toddler must feel when interacting with so many new objects and unfamiliar environments. The music in the background and the mother's crooning voice makes the game unnerving for something that everyone does to their children. The screen sometimes shakes and despite the normal settings of the game, ordinary things are made more nightmarish by your baby's first person viewpoint and way of looking at the world. Almost everything can have a sinister undertone to it. When you have full control of the baby you prefer to crawl around for speed rather than walk, and you interact with the objects and environment around you. And the teddy bear.The voice acting is quite good, the speakers to your baby all use that special voice  reserved for small children or cute animals.  You're not sure if your teddy bear is evil or not. He makes you hide in a dark closet, and you have to hug the teddy to “light” up the area, and make it less scary. Except it doesn't work out like that. The voice acting and noises help to make a perfectly normal environment scarier than it should be, as if your character is isolated and alone in their world. And mother is a potential enemy. And teddy is either your last resort or your worst friend. I like the fact this game really plays on the feeling of a kid's active imagination. Monsters in the dark, sounds you don't recognise, everything being exaggerated out of proportion.I struggled to keep playing this game though I liked it. It's not a good game for those who suffer from video game motion sickness.Liked this review and want to read more of my reviews? Click here to join my steam group and Click here to follow my curator page!

												One of the most unique game concepts to come along in recent years. Sure, it borrows heavily off games like Amnesia, but making the protagonist a toddler is definitely new territory. It's not particularly challenging except when it comes to avoiding enemies in certain areas. Also, the vantage point of crawling can make things confusing in dark areas and sometimes seems unclear about what direction to go in. Luckily, most of the levels are not too big. Plus, th ereveal in the end hits you right in the feels.Definitely recommend, although it's not a game that lends itself to repeated plays.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Among the Sleep has great atmosphere, story, and suspense, as well as some interesting subtext about viewing the world through the eyes of a two year old. As story games go it is more of a short story than a novel, with five main levels - which I finished in around two hours - and not a lot of replay value once you've seen the ending. One of those games that I think you'll enjoy more the less you know going into it, but a lot of the best parts are given away in the trailer. Those minor caveats aside, I still enjoyed and recommend it.Also, while it says "full controller support," it seems Xbox One controllers are currently not supported. After switching to a 360 controller it worked fine.

												Absolutely the best indie/horror/adventure game I have played. Next to Amnesia, I should say. Not only terrifying, but you solve puzzles as a young child would. Since you are not so tall, (For being a child.) you have to move things around to climb, walk, and get past. You have the abilities as of a small child, which hold you back at doing things like you would in most horror games.Which makes this game all the more realistic.Though I did encounter a few problems, which I shall list:- When the "infinte" drawer goes through the first hole, it hits the box and then gets stuck inside the wall. Making it so it can't move. (Which has been fixed now. Thankfully! ^.^ )- When I tried to go back to another chapter, the game would crash and I would have to keep trying until It did it without problems.- The game sometimes froze in the menu. In-game, however, I had no issues whatsoever.- At one point, during the part with the second Merry go round, I picked up the bird staue, and it doesnt move. I had to restart from the last checkpoint, which was quite a ways back.Other than the listed bugs I found, the game is absolutely perfect. Because of the bugs, I give it a 9/10.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
Among The SleepThis review was last edited when I had completed the gameShort ReviewA decent horror adventure game that built up a good atmosphere and was at times genuinely frightening. It's "unique" slant was that you play through the eyes of a toddler making the perspective and movement very different to usual.Long ReviewYou play as a toddler that has to wander through your dreams, rendered in 3D, looking for four memories that will allow you a way out. You are accompanied of your travels by your teddy who offers advice and can cast light if hugged. You traverse the adventure in a fairly linear fashion, with a few of puzzles to solve, but nothing too difficult, and some monsters to avoid but death is a minor inconvenience in this game as you are restart at the last save and there are frequent background saves made throughout the adventure.The initial section is played whilst you are awake and allows you to get the gist of the controls and understand the mechanics of the gameplay.The are another four levels to make your way through, each taking around 30 minutes to an hour to complete. Each level has its own theme and all of them are hauntingly rendered. It is worth noting the ending is very good too.I can't see any replay value in the game unless you want the achievementsProsGenuinely frightening at timesVery atmosphericThe perspective of seeing things from a child's eyes, much closer to ground level that you would normally experienced worked for meConsBecame a bit grindy at times when I kept going over the same ground again and again to spot a clue I'd missed.The scariness dwindled once the same scene was repeated several timesMarks Out Of 55) Must have - stop whatever you're playing now and play this4) Worth the asking price and considering as your next purchase3) Maybe purchase if you're stuck for choosing your next game or mildly discounted2) Only purchase if it is heavily discounted1) Not worth getting even if given away freeWhere I got the game fromI bought this game from  Humble Bundle [www.humblebundle.com]Platform Played OnIntel Pentium G3258 Anniversary Edition, 8Gb RAM, Palit GTX 750, Windows 10, EasyAcc Mouse & Steelseries MERC keyboard. Played at windowed 1440x900 resolutionMy best guess for a PEGI ratingUsing  PEGI Ratings [www.pegi.info] I'd suggest at least a 12 and probably a 16. There were several scenes where I was genuinely frightened. My wife couldn't play this game, it was too unsettling

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
This review contains a couple of mere spoilers. Among the Sleep has a very impressive affect on the player. It shows the great idea that only a genius could think of - using the perspective of a baby. Throughout this baby perspective, we can clearly notice that the baby has worries over many things like their mother's scream. At the beginning of the game, the character's mother goes to answer the door that had just had the doorbell ring. The mother then screams which queues the music and visual effects to give a dramatic effect. This happens to show that the baby feels stressed and panicked as though the mother is giving a distress call - an in-danger tone. I find this is a very creative idea and the creator really understands how emotion is built up in a game. After seeing the monster, I have a slight lust of disappointment, for as soon as a monster is shown in a game, that ruins the horror element of a build up. No studios are able to create a monster that is more horrifying that what we, as consumers, create in our head from mysterious build-ups, such as lighting effects and creaky floorboards. As soon as a monster is shown in a game, it automatically drops some tension and makes the player less scared of the monster. This game has lost the horrific momentum by showing the monster, and the monster doesn't look very scary, but I guess there are limits as to how scary you can make a monster look. And to be quite straight... what is a monster? A monster is a horrific creature or person that is created IN OUT HEADS by dramatic effects and noises. Making a monster be shown in a game really doesn't make it a monster anymore. The teddy bear's voice acting and sounds are very good. The sound effects successfully create tension and the teddy bear successfully sounds like a Paedophile - I mean a nice friend.  In addition, the animations of movement in the game are very smooth, however are a little slow and... the opposite of slick. Whatever that word is. As far as I can judge on the game mechanics, they are quite simple and not all that amazing. Animations for the things the character uses are very simple and could be improved through more time in development. I do believe this game has a really good story line, really good twists and successfully shows the in-depth perspective of a baby in every-day situations. Among the Sleep shows a definite prime example of what a baby would think about as they go to sleep on a dark, windy night. It shows how the baby is petrified and shows how simple things are over-exaggerated in the baby's mind, such as a wardrobe. Overall, I think this game really is worth the play and if you don't play this game, you'd be missing out on a lot of interesting perspective.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												[NO SPOILERS]For the love of god, do not spend $20 on this game.Visuals (8/10)Sound (6/10)Gameplay (4/10)Storyline (5/10)Replay value (none)This one belongs in the horror genre as much as Goat Simulator. You get a few shock scares, but all in all it's a puzzle game with a dark setting. The terror vibe wears out about 30 mins in and never comes back. I'll admit that the idea of the main character being a 2-year old with their teddy interested me enough to buy the game and although I enjoyed some parts, I regret buying Among the Sleep.One play-through is only between 2-3 hours; waaay too short for the price. The graphics lag a bit in certain areas but it's not too bad. The redeeming factor of this game are the visuals. Very well-done, except for the mom's face. Sounds are kind of repetitive, but nothing to get real mad about.What I did get mad about was the fact that I paid $20 for a 3 hour game that doesn't get you on the edge of your seat. I was disappointed with this title, and wouldn't recommend it to anyone. How sad :(------[SPOILERS BEYOND THIS POINT]-----The play time is about 2-3 hours depending on how much you run/walk. Initially it's more intuitive to walk than run because you don't know what the game is all about. After about 30 minutes you realize there's no real backlash to being caught by the monster and you run through everything. This is where the game lost me.First of all, it reveal what the monster looks like waaaay too early. In fact, they shouldn't have ever done that considering the short play time. after it's revealed you lose all sense of this game being the least bit frightening. Aside from a few instances where you actually have to hide from the monster to avoid the harsh penalty [sarcasm] of starting almost exactly where you were caught with no progress rewind, there's no real 'horror-value'. There is only 1 event where you have to consider not just plowing through the map. Bottles on top of blocks that summon the monster if they fall? Brilliant, I love it! Showing every bit of what happens during that scene in your teaser trailer? Moronic.The end scene has a bit of redeming factors in that we're taken for a loop to find out our once loving mother is actually an abusive alcoholic stuggling with the idea of continuing on as a single parent. Lovely. That, combined with the recent dismemberment of best friend Teddy, we've basically witnessed the making of a potential psychopath. Maybe the sequel will have us mass murdering 1st graders! The possibilities are endless.Buy this game if you have money to burn.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Honestly, Among the Sleep is captivating on many levels. I personally love horror games and while this game definitely had its moments of jump scare, it was nothing like other games in the genre (Amnesia or Outlast just to name a few), but considering the powerful story they tell perhaps its good they aren't like the others. The subtle way the writers work in real adult issues in the eyes of a 2 year old is impressive, as well as scary. The story reaches a depth that I sometimes don't see in a game with 60 hours worth of campaign, and deserves a lot of credit for it. The game takes you through a fantastic story that leaves you exposed and vulnerable. Definitely a great Indie story in a mild horror game.PROLOGUE:The prologue is a short add on to clear up part of the story that a lot of people might not have picked up on in the original game alone. Neither of your parents are perfect.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												As much as I wanted to like this, I found myself wishing for the end of the game and given that it's a short game anyway, that's not so good.  Whilst there are some well done / clever moments and the designer did a great job of making the change of perspective into something that was a little overwhelming and scary, the experience was more of a walking (crawling?) simulator with a rather overblown story.  For a horror, it was more creepy than scary and the 'monsters' were very much more of an irritant that something to fear.  This was partly due to the poor AI presenting very little challenge, but also grinding visual and audio effects that made me want to go brew a cuppa whilst I waited for them to pass.Similarly, puzzles were unchallenging - pretty much 'pull this to free this' and 'move this then jump on it', wrapped up in fetch quests.  Not that other horror games don't do unchallenging, but Among the Sleep isn't distracting you with the anticipation of terrifying things happening.  There are plenty of pretty bits, some very nice alice moments and the aforementioned change of perspective, but it's just not enough.  Not at fifteen quid a go.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												First off, I want to say that I kind of feel bad giving this game a thumbs down for its review. I wish there was a more dynamic grading scale than yes/no.That being said, my biggest complaint is that this game essentially puts all of its eggs in one basket. The one point in which this game really excels is its visual effects. This game does an amazing job of not only providing a creepy horror environment, but it also really gives you a feeling of how an imaginative child may picture the world around him. Especially a child with a morbid imagination. It may not be as perturbing as Silent Hill's blood, rust and isolating fog, but the abyss surrounding the playground and the overgrown nature of the library really helps give the player a feeling of uncertainty and vulnerability. In other games the abyss would be viewed as "I guess they put an invisible wall there, 'cause the objective's over that way." but this game is in a unique position to utilize the idea of object permanence; even if the comparison wasn't intentional.Unfortunately, while I could feasibly recommend playing the game simply for the visual experience, the gameplay and storyline are not on the same level of expertise. The gameplay is not really challenging at all. There's no real danger of being seen or anything just as long as you crawl under something. Even if it's a doorway or a table almost as tall as the monster pursuing the player. I had plenty of times where I was standing in a cupboard, inches away from a pursuing monster who, simply, stood in the doorway until he just...disappeared. As immersive as the environment was, it almost got less interesting once the monsters started showing up...As far as the plot is concerned, the whole game pretty much all builds up to the opening of the sealed portal at the end of the game. There's no real plot advancement outside of progressing from one level to the next until right before the door is opened and the (plot twist?) ending is revealed. It...felt like it was SUPPOSED to be a plot twist, but with the child's drawings littering each level it's not too hard to figure out exactly what's happening. [I'll omit mention of the less obvious hints mentioned in later levels for potential spoiler reasons...although idk if it's worth not spoiling given how telegraphed the ending was.]Overall, my main reason for down voting this game comes down to the price. If it wasn't $20, I would still recommend a purchase for the sake of getting to immerse yourself in the environment (if you're the type of person who can appreciate that stuff). $5 is definitely a reasonable price for this game, but given the lackluster story and...(I apologise in advance) gameplay that will count you AMONG THE SLEEP (ha HAAAAA! Zing!) I'd have to admit that most people would probably find purchasing this game for $20 to be rather disappointing.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												There is nothing scarier than being a toddler who's looking for their mum, while crawling through creepy environments that have something wicked lurking in every shadow.It is not often that I find a horror game worthy to be standing tall beside great titles such as Amnesia and Slender, but Among the Sleep is definitely one of those horror games. While the game clearly reveals its Indie roots by having a playtime value of about two hours, depending on how much of a scaredy cat you are, it's dripping with a great concoction of creepy visuals, haunting sounds and eerie music. It has done what many so called horror titles of this day and age fail to do; frighten me. Among the Sleep shines in making you feel like the fragile little child you control, and it's just enough to make your skin crawl as you struggle to open doors and find elaborate ways to climb on top of a drawer.Check it out when you've got the time and cash! This game is definitely worth your time if you're a fan of horror that has the potential to make you soil your pants.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												“A child shouldn’t have to go through this.”Wise words from a teddy bear. They’re also spot-on for the situation Among the Sleep’s two year-old protagonist finds himself in, as he’s forced to endure a number of horrors that are both imagined and very real in one of the most original — and refreshing — horror games I’ve played in some time.Among the Sleep is a must-play for any fan of the genre, so long as you can overlook its handful of technical annoyances — almost all of which can be easily remedied with a patch — and immerse yourself in this game’s beautifully realized world.Head on over to Bloody Disgusting for the full review: http://bdisgusting.com/1mSIdpE

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												When I was very young and prone to getting seperated from my parents in department stores I would later have nightmares about hiding in the center of the circular clothing racks, peeking out from under heavy wool coats and suits while monsters sought my tender flesh in the darkness.This is just one of the intense emotional experiences of this game which is painted from every spectrum of emotional palette you can imagine: from the rainbow joy of discovery and exploration as you search for your mother to the black depths of terror and loneliness.This game is not only a masterpiece of survival horror but a poignant piece of storytelling at the same time.  It terrifies on a completely psychological level with a perfect counterpoint of harmonious safety and aesthetically amazing exploration as you get closer to your mother and the end of the tale.This is one of the most intense five hours I've ever spent on a game title and everyone should experience this game no matter what genre of games you are into.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												This is what indie gaming is all about IMHO - Experimenting, and art! Yes it is tragically short, yes it is simplistic and fairly linear.  However this means the intensity of the experience is never diluted.  You can relax and know that you will beat this game within 3-4 hours tops.  You will relax and just let the experience wash over you. I treat this game as an interactive movie of sorts, and find it's bite size scope perfect.  The price makes it all the more attractive. This game HAS to be experienced to be appreciated.  No this isn't a bloody, gore fest like Outlast.  No it's not a zombie hunting game.  It is still horrifying in the extreme... When you reach the end you will understand.  This game reminds me a great deal of the Pencil and Paper RPG "Little Fears" where players take on the role of children in their early teens or younger (all the way to toddlers like this), in a survival horror environment of just this side of reality supernatural happenings.  I give this game 5 stars, I would totally crap my Diapers again.  Oh, and if you try this game... give the bear an extra hard squeeze for me... By the end of the game I wished I still had me teddy...

												Great game. But way too short.Graphics are fine. Could be a little better. But it's still nice to look at.Sound is alright. Some cute sounds here and there. And the atmosphere sounds are done fairly decently.Story is an interesting take on horrors. It's very simple though. Nothing fancy. So chances are if you're used to horrors, you won't really get much of a scare out of this. The only thing I had was a few jump scares. But there was very little suspense for me.There is not really any replayability either on this. The game had far more potential to really be a powerful game with a deep story, proper scares and indepth gameplay. But sadly this did not happen.But if the game is on sale, buy it if you're looking for a simple short and sweet take on a horror. If I were to rate this out of 10, I'd give it a 5/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												Wow, this game was pretty amazing. One of the main reasons I got it was because of the fact that you played as a toddler, which was something I've never seen before in a game. And the other, well, because I'm an indie/horror enthusiast, so this looked really promising.The atmoshpere and level design are extremely creepy and dark, almost Tim Burton-esque. Every level was heavily detailed and as such helped me feel very immersed. What I like about it is that it is subtle, like Amnesia - nothing is really too forceful with trying to shove terror down your throat, instead it just eases it down nice and slowly, making sure you suffer every last bit. I really underestimated the game's horror factor, because it has moments where it's right up there with Outlast in making me bleed out sweat.The gameplay is pretty good; it captures the movements of a toddler very well. Walking upright, you waddle around like you're drunk, and you can also crawl on the floor, which is actually a lot faster. You can run while you are upright, but you risk the chance of tumbling down to the ground, so I never really did that. One thing I really found annoying was the teddy bear as your light source, because he obstructed a lot of my view towards the ground, which made it very difficult at times to be able to see objects, or where I was heading. Not to mention, he does not provide a very good radius of light, although perhaps maybe that is a problem with how I set my gamma, not sure.Well anyway, yeah, epic game, but the only problem is, it was too short! :C But oh well. I still do strongly recommend you get this if you want horror similar to Amnesia and with a bit of a psychological feel to it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11
												I found this to be an OK game. Concept of being a toddler was new and interesting. The rest was mostly old news. The scare factor comes mostly from 2 things for most of the game: loud random bg noise, giving the impression you are not alone; and scripted jumpscares. While I thoroughly enjoyed the 1st factor, the 2nd one became boring really fast, to the point where I wouldn’t feel threatened at all. The addition of enemies (which felt mostly scripted too) solved that issue in a way, at least for me.First off: SAVING MECHANICS LIE TO YOU. You see all those dandy “saving” notifications in the bottom right corner? Yes, they are saving checkpoints. For when you *die*. If you close the game mid chapter and reload, you’re forced to repeat the whole chapter. It isn’t fun, especially on longer chapters where you might want to take a break, and where the checkpoint system makes it look like you’ll be dropped where you left off.Graphics were ok. Some strange clipping if you actually pay attention but nothing too major. You can use the demo to check them for yourself, I barely noticed a difference.NPCs push you out of the way (which is awkward when the main NPC is so small). Detection for the “climb up” command is really awkward in the last chapter where you have to walk into slightly higher places, not tall enough to be climbable, but I was unable to simply walk towards the 5cm higher place and get on it. That whole chapter had weird collision to think of it. I couldn’t get under furniture that I could get under in previous chapters.Sound was nice and scary. A bit overdone, sometimes?There wasn’t much to the story but then again you’re a toddler, your life isn’t expected to be super complicated anyway. It made sense in the end, wasn’t terrible or anything, but also isn’t going to stick with me.Overall it was interesting. Not one of my favourite games, probably won’t go back to it after getting the achievements. Would still recommend checking out.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												Among the Sleep is both beautiful and tragic at the same time. The story unfolds in such a way that it leaves room for your imagination to run wild as you explore creatively designed areas, solve fun interactive puzzles, and hide from the monsters under your bed.I was very impressed with the controls and the detail put into the game, from the cute pajamas right down to the stitching in the rug that you crawl across. Tons of items are intractable and it is surprisingly easy to lose yourself in simple things like stacking blocks or piling toys into chests.The monsters in the game are unique and tie very well in to the story – no spoilers, you need to play to the end! There are several moments in the game where the monsters can come after you, but if you are patient and hide well then they can be avoided to some extent. My overall score for the game: 10/10. I really enjoyed this game, I even came back and played it again for the achievements and the prologue. The story is incredibly touching and will leave you with some pretty heavy emotions by the time you reach the end. Among the Sleep is a gem, don’t miss out on this one!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Okay, okay. For all those kids out there that think it's one or two hours of gameplay, get real. Why do you even play games, if you are in such a rush to finish them? Think of this as a great film... I got four to five hours out of it. Yes, 20 is a bit much... but if I am lucky, the Dlc will be free. (Right.) Anyway, to those of you that think this is going to change the way you play. NOOOOOOO! The story is genius, to me at least. You won't understand how brilliant it is if you are just a kid. This is aimed at adults and if you have children or grew up in a bad home, it will make sense. To everybody else, you'll be wondering why you never get to kill anybody. Grow up, then come back to this. This game really is brilliant and should be played by anybody who has children. It is not perfect, not even close, but it does tell a very important story that is sad, scary and beautiful. I know not a lot of people are willing to admit when a game spooks them or makes them feel uneasy, yet I will tell you this, I was spooked out by a part in this more than any other game I have ever played. Now, this is best played with headphones on in the dark. A lot of reviews spoiled some of the most intense moments, so dont read too much into the story. The graphics are nothing special, but they do the job and the enviroments are nice to look at. I also found the creature to be well designed. The puzzles are far too easy and end up being things that just slow you down more than test your wits. Still, the story and atmosphere are amazing. The real let down is the price since this game is very short and doesn't bring anything new to the table. If you catch it on offer, it is a must own.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Among the Sleep was a very interesting and unique horror game. The gameplay style is similar to Amnesia. However, this is not a violent/gore-infused game since it clearly involves a toddler (and ripping a toddler apart would be kind of weird). It is a very short game, one that took me about 3 hours to complete (and I take my time sweet with these types of games). However, this game is definitely worth your time. Even though there is no gore and violence, Among the Sleep definitely captures the essence and perspective of what it is like to be a defenseless toddler and have a wild imagination. The storyline is something that many people can directly relate to and it is a sad reality that many individuals go through/have gone through (I chose not to say anything further in order not to spoil anything). This game's spookiness will surprise you! P.S.: Although I thoroughly recommend this game, I suggest you wait until it goes on sale. I feel that $20 may be too steep for the amount of game time that one gets.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												The most obvious complaint you'll get is that the game is too short. You could speed run in an hour or so, or take some time to enjoy the ambience.  Monument Valley (mobile game) is the same kind of beast; short but very enjoyable.To be honest the 3-d models come across a bit unpolished (specifically the mother), but once you are 1/3 of the way through you don't notice anymore because you are too distracted by the SUPURB audio.  Seriously this game's audio is on par if not better than Outlast in keeping you nervous about what's about to happen (wear headphones). Puzzle elements aren't too difficult and I feel like it was designed in the same spirit of Super Meat Boy in how it introduces a mechanic and then expands on it, slowly guiding you as needed until you understand all the options at your disposal.There are some jump scares sure, good ones in fact, and it's not excessive and the times where you are hiding from [REDACTED] are suspenseful.  The ending was good simply for the fact that they didn't take the easy way out with the story. You may think you have it figured out as you go along looking at drawings thrown about but it's not quite what it seems.I was a kickstarter backer, and I don't regret it, seeing how you can spend $20 on a few pizzas this is very much worth the price, and there has been DLC announced which I believe will be free.I'd give it a 7/10

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												I would like to start off by saying that I rarely play horror games.  Among the Sleep caught my attention by its promise of an emersive I rarely play horror games as I am a little bit of a wimp when it comes to being scared.  However, Among the Sleep caught my attention with its promise of an immersive world and a new perspective.  Both of which it delivered very well.  I started the game expecting to be scared out of my mind, but this game was very mild on the horror spectrum.  There was a small hand full of times that my heart raced and I jumped a little.  Very reminiscent of my childhood days when I remember being afraid to walk around the house in the dark because my imagination had already created all of the worst possible things that could be waiting to grab me.The biggest complaint I read in reviews was that the game was too short.  And really it was, however I also don’t think it should have been much longer.  The puzzles were relatively simple.  I got lost a couple of times in areas that seemed a little circular and the right direction was hard to decipher.  Otherwise the game moved at a steady pace.I’m glad I played this game and would recommend it to anyone looking for something to occupy a few hours of their time.  Seeing the world from the height of a 2 year old gave a fresh perspective and I believe the development and design of the game was very well done.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												a treat for any horror fan with a great original storyline you play as a 2 year old that you believe has a pretty normal life but when you go to sleep you wake up to your crib turned over and you start getting scared as you hear your mom's voice that sounds concerning and you cannot find her anywhere you look around and start hearing muffled screams throughout the hallways in your home, you then find your teddy that you just recently met in the washing machine telling you something is wrong we must find your mother things start turning into a world of the childs mind twisted by confusion while you start finding clues to where your mother is throughout this adventure. This game is extremly well done dealing with the element of psycological horror and survival as you go around avoiding monters and realizing various events about the childs life you did not even realize. This game took the darkest turns and made me believe i was that child trying to escape all these horrors that are trying to hurt me it was truly well made and well done with the sound effects, jump scares and monsters. i do recommend this game for any horror video game ethusiest and anyone that enjoys a good storyline that makes you question a lot of what is going on but in a great way, worth the time and worth the play. Well done krillbite studios. :)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												It’s hard to know how big an effect a parent’s actions can have on children, until certain mannerisms start to materialise in that child’s behaviour. In Among the Sleep, you’ll be confronted by such scenes that might bring a tear to the eye of parents who play through. I’m not a parent myself, but at the end I couldn’t help staring at the screen in bewilderment of what I had just played through. Read more in our Among the Sleep review below.Having just finished watching the film “Room”, I was reminded just how much an adult’s behaviour can impact the lives of their children. Among the Sleep touches on quite a lot of issues that parents face, but more importantly, it takes you on a two-year old toddlers journey through a world of imagination that depicts just how different a child’s perception of their surroundings is.There is so much about Among the Sleep’s story that I’d love to talk about, but unfortunately that would involve spoiling the majority of the game. I’m going to do my best to touch upon certain aspects without potentially ruining the experience of those who are yet to play it.Happy BirthdayThe beginning of Among the Sleep starts with the toddling protagonist downing a glass of drink. Because of the way you are first seeing the world through the rounded walls of a drinking glass, my first impression was that I might be witnessing a birth scene. But as I moved my mouse around, more and more of the world became visible. Eventually I was left looking at the beaming face of the toddler’s mother. It was the two-year old’s birthday and the mother was preparing a cake.As you wait for the cake to be presented to you, you’re given the opportunity to look around the kitchen, and even play with an abacus. Finally mother comes back with the cake and cuts a slice for mister toddler to eat. Unfortunately, before we got to sink our teeth into this tasty looking cake, we were interrupted by a knock at the door of the toddler’s house.Here’s where the strangeness begins. Distortion lines start to appear around everything and the sound becomes muted. A growing feeling of unease pierces the atmosphere. Just as you’re starting to think you’ve fallen into a scene from Paranormal Activity, the distortion dissipates when you hear the mother shout “NO!”, and slam the door.Back she comes with a present in her hands and a face conveniently disguised with a big smile. But before you’re allowed to open it, she picks you up and takes you and the present upstairs. You get placed in a playpen and the present is set down upon a chest of drawers. When the mother leaves the room, you gain control of the toddler.The usual ‘WASD’ keys control your movement while the mouse is used to look around. Also, ‘left-click’ allows you to interact with objects. Obviously toddlers aren’t known for their jumping prowess, so instead of jump, the ‘space-bar’ allows you climb onto platforms such as chairs and open drawers. Holding ‘shift’ lets you sprint for a short period of time, but instead of being presented with a stamina gauge, you’ll simply fall over when you can no longer keep up the pace. The ‘control’ key drops you to the floor and allows you to crawl through narrow nooks and crannies.Eventually you come across Teddy. A loveable soft toy who accompanies you on your adventure. In the toddler’s mind, Teddy can talk, and informs you that by pressing ‘F’ to cuddle him, you’ll feel safer. What he really means is that he’ll light up and allow you to see in really dark places. To be honest, I was constantly pressing ‘F’ because it gets quite creepy in the dark… Not only is Teddy a provider of light, but he also acts as a guide to the toddler.Playing AroundThe gameplay in Among the Sleep mainly consists of solving puzzles. Each puzzle rewards you with a memory that’s required for progressing to the next area of the game. The puzzles are relatively simple and won’t require a lot of thinking to solve, but the journey involved in solving each puzzle takes you through some incredibly imaginative environments; from dark, creepy playgrounds, to mazes of bookshelves haunted by a tall, crazy-haired, lurching monster.Speaking of monsters, you’re not going to find as many of them out in the dark as you believed you would as a child. However, in later areas of the game, the tall monsters will appear more frequently. If they catch you, you’ll be in trouble and have to start again from a previous checkpoint. Thankfully the checkpoints come around often, and you won’t be replaying certain parts of puzzles over and over.Among the Sleep incorporates a great physics engine that allows you to open drawers, cupboards, fridges and interact with pretty much anything you can see. Some puzzles and achievements require you to pick up certain items and throw them. This gives things an extra injection of realism and also lengthens the overall gameplay experience.An extra little incentive when playing Among the Sleep are the many toddler-like drawings scattered around each area. The drawings depict some scenes we can only imagine are events the toddler has lived through.All throughout Among the Sleep, you’ll be followed by a feeling of unease. Teddy will whisper to you that things look dangerous and you should be careful. Creepy sounds and crescendos in the music add a feeling of panic to your journey, and when you first encounter the creepy, tall, crazy-haired monster, you’ll be looking over your shoulder every time you hear something out of the ordinary.Aesthetic CharmFrom the moment you are taken upstairs and witness the introduction credits apparate before your eyes in the form of glowing lights, you can tell that you’re in for a visual treat. The graphics have a cartoony feel to them, resembling something you might see in a Pixar film. Everything in the real world is drawn with such bright, vivid colours. Each colour stands out the way you’d imagine a toddler to see them. In contrast, the imaginary world is dark, full of shadows and incorporates creepy distorted shapes to the overall design of things.Playing as a toddler, you would expect their movement to be quite wobbly and Krillbite Studios certainly deliver in terms of wobbliness. It definitely injects an extra bit of realism to the character you are playing. Otherwise it might just feel like you’re playing as any FPS character in an overgrown world.The soundtrack is eery and coats everything with an unnerving sheen. Sounds and effects raise goosebumps on your skin, especially when the monsters commence their pursuit of your tiny form.Final ThoughtsAmong the Sleep is truly a masterpiece and tells a story we’re all too familiar with. This could be confronting to some, but the way it plays out through the eyes and imagination of a toddler, portrays it in a different light. Those of you who aren’t parents might stop and reflect on the adventure you’ve just played through. Parents might shed a tear or go and give an extra hug to their children.The entire game is so smooth to play, and although it only lasts for around three hours, you’ll feel like those three hours just flew by. Krillbite Studios have added Steam achievements to the game, so there’s a bit of replayability in terms of collecting everything and unlocking each achievement.If you’re looking for a game that relies more on telling a rich story rather than throwing you deep into an action-packed shootout, Among the Sleep will not disappoint. It’s story will leave you speechless but you won’t be able to help yourself from wanting more.Read the full review[gamereviewsau.com]

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												It's a nice short and atmospheric game. Not worth 30 quid but if you're a horror fan, you can't go wrong with it when it's on sale. The environments are creepy and the sound design is top-notch (although I can't figure out why the baby himself/herself sound like a monster themselves sometimes). There's isn't much in the way of puzzle solving or anything besides moving objects and pushing stuff around. Graphics look gorgeous. The lighting is superb.Be wary, though. There are clipping bugs galore; so don't be surprised if you get stuck on the environment occasionally and can't move. I had to restart a couple of levels because I got stuck in the ground and wound up where the game apparently didn't want me to be. Gameplay mechanics are pretty easy and I'm sure your non-gamer significant other can enjoy it as much as you do. Can't say it had much in the way of surprises or the story was that special but it did keep me interested throughout the 3-or-so hour experience. Sometimes I felt the developers had the atmosphere and story down but couldn't really come up with any new ideas for gameplay. As I said earlier, if you find this on sale and you're into horror and toddling simulation, you'll get your bang out of Among the Sleep.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												This will say I've played over two hours. It was less than that for me. There was a part I got stuck on for a little while and an AFK that lasted at least 20 minutes. Among the Sleep is as short as people are saying it is. I hate having to make a huge chunk of my review about money and length, but it feels necessary. It's hard to say if this game is or is not worth $20. That price for roughly an hour and a half, more or less, seems somewhat unfair. The fantastic imagery, atmosphere, and story (though, I caught on way, way earlier than I was supposed to and I think most players will, too), and the amount of love you can tell was put into this is actually worth $20. I find myself telling friends to wait for a sale, though. I'm not sure I'm pleased with paying the full price, even if the work put into this is probably deserving of it. I do recommend this game. It's creative, unique, and very cool. It does have its flaws, and unlike many gamers on here, I don't often excuse a lot just because the developer is indie. I do think the positives heavily outweigh the negatives, however. I wish there were more ways to interact with items. There was quite a bit of graphics tearing and floors disappearing. There was no real challenge and I would have had more fun if the puzzles were designed to make me have to think even a little. I can't really say if the length is a negative, it's as long as they felt the story should be. I'm indifferent towards the length itself, keeping price out of it. I like that they littered the levels with drawings by the child and other little things that hinted at what was going on in reality, but there was way too much that gave it all away immediately. It makes sense but essentially ended up leaving me without any suspense. That's okay with me, though. It came together wonderfully at the end.This is one of those games where it's all about the journey. I like that sort of thing. If you don't, I wouldn't recommend it to you.It has creepy elements and while you can call it horror, it isn't a frightening game. Unless you scare easily, don't expect to have a nightmarish experience. I love how they illustrated the perspective and imagination of a child, it was brilliant and unlike anything else I've ever played. It was definitely a terrifying and emotional experience for our two year old.Among the Sleep is worth playing, what you're comfortable paying for it will have to be up to you.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
												Among the Sleep is a First Person horror/puzzle game in where we play as a toddler trying to find his mother in a dark and twisted world. We start off in our birthday party, eat some cake with our mom and are given a terrifying teddy bear as a gift. The bear teaches us the basics of the game such as picking stuff up and climbing but you may be half expecting it to murder you at any given moment. Surprisingly that creepy as sin stuffed bear turns out to be your best friend throughout this ordeal and doubles as a flashlight whenever you hug it. The voice actor that plays the teddy bear has a very calm and soothing voice which ironically enough adds to the creepiness of it.Everything is all well and normal until you go to sleep and have your crib flipped over by an invisible entity. From there on out the world turns pretty twisted and has no sense of coherency sort of like a dream as the ways the areas connect to each other make no sense. Not much will make sense actually as the story is quite cryptic and you will have to piece it together yourself. As strange as the world is the level design is linear and well thought out so you should never find yourself lost. Most of the story is also told through the environment so there is a reason to pay attention to your surroundings other than the possibility of death. A large portion of your time will be solving very simple puzzles to be able to progress to the next area but there are a few stealth sections where you must hide and avoid monsters. These are definitely the low points of the game as it can be hard to indicate when the monster is near until you catch a glimpse but by then you will be killed. They just hold you up in the air and show a game over screen so don't expect violent baby executions buying this. Another problem with having to avoid the monsters is that your fat baby legs are nowhere near agile enough to move to cover quickly. As mentioned before these sections are few and far between so it doesn't really have much of an impact to the experience.When you are standing you will be able to run shortly before falling down and reverting back to your crawling stance. Crawling allows you to fit into tiny locations and is much faster than walking but you are unable to hug the teddy bear for light and since you can also run when standing there is little reason to crawl. You can also climb on objects to reach places. An example being pulling up a chair and climbing it to reach a door knob. You can also pick up objects and throw them but throwing doesn't really become a factor until much later on. The baby is surprisingly strong considering how hard he throws objects and is able to move chairs without a problem.I'd imagine you are not considering purchasing this game for the cool physics or the puzzles but for the horror. Among the Sleep pulls it off pretty well and being a toddler really helps as everything in the world seems big and scary. This isn't really the kind of game that will throw jump-scares at you around every corner. Jump-scares are rare for the most part and the game instead relies heavily on subtle psychological horror such as dimly lit rooms, objects falling and distant noises. One thing that I found separated it from most horror games is the lack of blood, gore or violence. It is definitely a breath of fresh air and shows you can make an unnerving experience without resorting to gross out tactics.The audio in Among the Sleep really amplifies the horror. It does a very good job at making you paranoid through use of sudden thumps, braking glass and just tense ambient music. Without such good sound effects and ambiance the game would have been much less effective at horror. Environments are unique and have the advantage of really making you feel like a small defenseless toddler in a over-sized world. Graphics are pretty good as well and I found it impressive how environments went from breathtaking to horrifying in some areas. Levels don't actually interconnect in any real way other than you sliding down a rusty pipe into a new location but it does end up adding to the surreal nature of it all.Overall this is a pretty good horror title. It does lack in gameplay and the puzzles are so easy that they will not offer any challenge and may feel like they are there just to give you something to do. Though considering the game is only two hours you will likely finish the game before boredom or repetition sets in. The horror does stay unpredictable throughout and they do a really good job at sparingly using the monsters to hunt you. Among the Sleep doesn't feel like a glorified game of hide and seek like other modern horror titles, instead it feels like a very personal experience through the warped mind of a toddler. It really does feel like a walking simulator with puzzles thrown in to slow you down but if you are fine with that there is a truly memorable and unique experience here that will remain in your mind long after you beat it.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												Recommended for the story-oriented sort of player who likes to focus on the environments and storytelling, rather than the more goal-oriented sort of player who's more into solving puzzles to get rewards.  A lot of the heart of the game, and a lot of its biggest scares, come in taking your time and letting yourself get immersed in the game, particularly the sounds, rather than paying attention to the mechanics.  Not for everyone I suppose, but it definitely grabbed me.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Among the Sleep is one of those games that really makes me wish Steam had a better rating system than "yes" or "no."It's good and there's a lot to like about the short time you'll spend in this world, but there's also an aftertaste of "it could have been better" that lingers as the credits roll. The game design and atmosphere are what really make this a recommended game. I really liked that the controls actually bring life to the idea that you're playing as an infant. Run too long and you fall into a crawl.... the bobbled, bow legged walk. These are all great details that helped immerse me into the world. I actually had an unnerving sense of nostalgia when crawling between coats and dresses in the endless expanses of closets. Remember how big closets used to seem when hiding in them?I guess my biggest dissapointment was that due to the short amount of time and focus on the game itself, that I really wish I was able to care more about the characters. Maybe that plays into being an infant and not picking up on these things, but it felt like an afterthought. Obviously, Teddy is the only character you really have the chance to connect with and he always felt so artificial that it gave me that "uncanny valley" uneasiness rather than the feeling of comfort he was supposed to provide the player. Regardless, this was a well crafted experience and I can't find a reason to tell anyone not to play it. The price tag is pretty steep at the moment. In the end, I always equate it to "was the experience worth the price of admission" which is completely subjected to my own opinion. In this case, not for me. It's a game I enjoyed, but I won't likely bring it up in conversations or think about it too much after my playthrough. I am excited to see what the developers do in the future.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												I just finished the game, let my emotional reaction fade away, and now I gotta say I love it. There are a few glitches still, and my game crashed making me replay the last chapter, but I didn't mind so much other than having to get through a few scary moments again. Keep in mind I do not normally play horror games, I'm extremely skittish and jump scares always tend to get me. I thought the game was a good level of overall eerieness without being so scary I couldn't play. It's not going to scare horror veterans, but the story is more important in my eyes. The ending had me scared for the adorable little protagonist in more ways than one.As far as length it's a short game. Took me about 4 hours including redoing that last chapter. Any more though would've been padding, as the game told it's story quite well in the time taken. There's not a ton of replay value as the emotional reaction is never the same as the first time, but I know a few people I'll be suggesting this too. I did not see the ending coming. I had a similar idea to what happened, but was a bit off. The sound design was pretty good throughout, although if I play again I'll probably adjust the levels so some of the noises are a bit obnoxious after too long. I'm looking forward to seeing more from this company, and have no regrets with getting this game.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												I'll let others review the scary aspect of this game. I wanna focus on the toddler simulation aspect.Holy cow. I wish there was a way to just have a toddler simulator based on these mechanics. After I played through the actual storyline I went back and started over again and just played around in the playroom and was blown away by the attention to physics. Drag a stool across the wooden floor, it slides okay. Push it across carpet and you're in for a struggle. You can't lift a pillow above your head but you can toss an inflatable ball a few feet.You can pick things up, put them down, open and close things, climb and even fall. There's no health bar so spills don't really matter. You wobble when you walk and make appropriate sounds as you move around. And it's interesting to see the world from the perspective of one so small (again). In all I would love to see more done with just the simulator side of things. It would be a riot to run around the house and interact with the environment without having to worry about the 'bad guys' getting you. After a long hard week of adulting, sometimes I don't want my gaming to give me puzzles or enemies to deal with. I just want to unwind. but I'm not into the farming or app-type games. This is just my style! I'd love to see more walking simulators like this.That said, the spooky aspect to this game and the storyline are both awesome. Sometimes though I couldn't help wondering if -I- was the monster. Something about all the crawling through vents and bookcases and scurrying under beds...

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												An absolutely oustanding game. Keep in mind that the game is actually very short. You can beat it in 3 to 4 hours in one sitting if you're aiming to, so you'll want to weigh that against whatever the game's current price.First let me say a few frank things about this game. These aren't complaints or criticisms. Just saying these things to adjust your expectations in case you are expecting the wrong thing from the screenshots/trailer/description. Firstly, the game is not really what you would call a horror game. It definitely has a distinctive "strange and eerie" quality to it that makes for an incredible atmosphere, but you're not going to be screaming or falling out of your chair or biting your nails. Secondly, the game does not present very many threats. There are VERY few situations where you are in any real danger. The result of these two things is that Among The Sleep adds up to be a fairly casual experience. So let me be frank about that. HOWEVER. Although "casual" is often used in a pejorative sense, it is not at all a bad thing here.This game is most recommended to players who, above all else, prize things like exploration, atmosphere, a sense of wonder, and outstanding visual style / art direction.Playing the game is more like an adventure game. It's slow-paced exploration with periodic object puzzles. The core gameplay principles are very comparable to games like Penumbra or Amnesia: you can freely manipulate doors, drawers, and most light objects. You can crawl inside closets to hide, and since you are a small child in this game, you can even hide inside of very small cupboards, under beds, and other small places. Unlike Penumbra/Amnesia, you rarely encounter dangerous creatures. When you DO encounter them, it's basically the same idea: run to the nearest hiding place and wait until it goes away. If you are looking for some kind of deep stealth gameplay, you won't find it here.That being said, despite my love of HP Lovecraft, I always found the Penumbra/Amnesia settings to be sort of bland. Among The Sleep however is a visual feast to behold. I found myself not wanting to stop playing the game just so I could LOOK AT IT some more. It's not that the game has better graphics than The Witcher 3 or something. It's more about what the game does with spacing, composition, lighting, contrast, and various other little artistic nuances. Among The Sleep is like a delicious cake for your eyeballs.The game also goes to an interesting place with the story, making it something more than just a fantasy. While I mostly consider this a plus, it is also one of those "reveals" that you see coming a hundred miles away. Perceptive players will see where this story is going before they even leave the first area. No doubt the devs intended foreshadowing, but the foreshadowing comes on a bit strong. ;-)Note that there is a free DLC level you can acquire after completing the base game. You can get it by going to chapter select and looking for the "unlock prologue" option. The DLC level is decent in gameplay terms, but it lacks the eerie and magical feeling of the base game on account of having you explore just a regular house instead of strange and eerie landscapes. The fantastic art of the base game is the most notable thing missing from the DLC, but it's a decent enough level otherwise.Using my own scale below, I'm putting the game at a 5. I honestly really want to give it a 6, but I'm dialing it back to 5 on account of it being a little on the short side. 7) A classic, essential, and/or must-buy game that is worth full price.6) A good game that is worth the full price.5) A pretty good game that is definitely worth checking out—especially if discounted.4) A pretty good game, but I would recommend buying it discounted.3) Worth checking out, but I would recommend buying it heavily discounted.2) Only worth checking out if you are dangerously curious.1) Avoid at all costs.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												The demo was amazing, however the gameplay of the finished version barely expands on what the demo showed. What gameplay there was (about 1 1/2 hours) was really fun, and had a few interesting mechanics, however there were several bugs that ruined the gameplay a bit. The character developement of Teddy was a little sloppy in the way that he's introduced, but over the course of the game, he becomes a lovable character.Things I liked:The plot progression was really well done, and it had an interesting twist at the end.The limitations of movement accurately represented what it would be like as a small child.The bear-flashlight (Awwh!).The non-violent terrifying monster and hide sequences.The plot twist at the end.Things I didn't like:The extremely short gameplay.The multiple bugs that ruined gameplay a bit.The high cost for such little gameplay.The somewhat repetitive ambience.Overall, the game is a really fun experience, but not worth $20. The different sections each have their own unique ambiences and creepy layouts, and usually make you not want to leave any hidey-hole that you find. The gameplay is really short, and leaves you feeling like you bought an incomplete game. Teddy is a lovable character and a useful flashlight, and the movement is realistic, but the combination of bugs and short gameplay ruined the experience a little bit. If this game is ever $8 or lower, then it would definitely be worth the purchase!

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												Short, sweet, chilling, sometimes mortifying and thought provoking once you figure out whats really going on. A genius look at making a scary game that isnt conforming to the standard jump scare shock horror, yes the game can be completed in a few hours easily but the story itself is a pleasant reminder that the real monsters are all too human. I really hope these guys create another and much longer game using the same unique approach to storytelling.Play the demo if you want to see how this plays, if you dont enjoy the demo you wont enjoy the game, buy the game when its on sale or not, either way the game definately got onto my must own list for its originality, perhaps not the most replayable of games however. As a side note...spelling words with the letter blocks seems to be popular with everyone :)And dont forget to hug your teddybear.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												Game horor yang cukup bagus, dimana kita bermain sebagai anak kecil 2-3 tahun menjelajahi mimpi ditemanin boneka teddy.Gameplay sangat baik bisa berinteraksi dengan benda2 sekitar, dan ada crosshair ditengah, graphicnya mendukung dengan effect2 kejutan dipadu dengan sound effect yang sangat baik membuat bulu kuduk berdiri sepanjang permainan dibuatnya. Dan cukup ringan dimainkan di laptop middle end.Perasaan seram sekali hanya diawal 15-20 menit pertama, kemudian sudah mulai terbiasa hanya saja sound effectnya membuat kaget sepanjang permainan. Dan 2 map ada hantu yang merupakan sisi buruk dari orang tua (menurut saya) menghantui mimpi dan kita hanya bisa berlari maksimal sebagai balita dan bersembunyi dibawah lemari atau meja so creepy.Sayangnya untuk puzzle-nya hanya memindahkan kursi, menggeser laci, dan melempar benda. Dan kalau gagal sembunyi atau lari dari hantu, maka hantu tidak muncul lagi setelah kita continue games.Tips bermain : mainkan dimalam hari jam 10 malam keatas, sendirian, dengan kondisi cahaya redup dan menggunakan headphone, barulah game ini sangat terasa baik.Cukup baik untuk menambah koleksi library steam dengan harga yang tepat jika dapat dibundle atau pas diskonPenilaian saya : 58/100Gameplay 75Graphic 75Sound 100AI 25Tingkat kesulitan 25Alur Cerita 50

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												It's a very simplistic puzzle game with a few jumpscares and some chasing sequences. I found myself jumping into the water out of boredom just to hear the sound of crunching bones (from what I assume was some water monster eating me), BEGGING for something to kill me to relieve the tedium of collecting items, using them to open a door, and continuing, while the ambience and lighting tried to convince me I was in some kind of danger, then 80% of the time it was just smoke and mirrors and I was completely aware of it.I was SUPER amused by all the little details of being a baby. The cooing, the bear, and the pause screen is adorable - he holds his hands up and covers his eyes, like a kid would do when trying to hide from scary monsters - but all charm aside, I would NOT have bought this game knowing how short it is (for 20 dollars, no less) if I hadn't been suckered into thinking this was a bona fide horror game. It's a glorified puzzle game with some creepy theming, but Amnesia was both much more challenging and much more terrifying. This game borrows a lot from well-established series and just feels kind of cheap, and you can beat it in about an hour or two.To be frank, there were some very creepy moments. When I was being chased by the darkness monsters, I felt like they were clearly gaining on me faster than I could crawl, so there was a nice helpless element to it like I expected to get snatched up RIGHT as I was about to make it to a a safe place. There are also ambiguous crayon drawings, which is usually a cliche in a horror game - children drawing crude depictions of murder or creepy ladies with long, black hair - but in this context it was pretty chilling on occasion. At one point I saw what looked like a tall dark figure holding up a stick-figure infant above its' open jaws, about to devour it. It's rare for anyone to address the murder of children/babies in games, so that's a unique theme that gives it that extra "Ugh, ♥♥♥♥ that" feeling.Very ambient, very creepy, very short, very dull, even once the enemies show up. Wait for a sale, until then the LetsPlays will be just as scary. Out of 100%, it's probably a 68% or so. Nothing fresh or revolutionary beyond being about a baby, and the puzzles get really stale.

Posted: June 24, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game but after about 45 minutes it became clear that it was hobbled by the age of its protagonist. For the same reason that you never see horrible things happening to kids on television (the image is withheld, harm is implied by lead up or aftermath) you realize that nothing will ever really harm your character in this game. I don't have a problem with this conceit since I have no desire to see these kinds of things but the result here is that there is nothing at stake in the game. The puzzles are weak, the atmosphere defanged, the engine aged and visually outdated.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												Among the Sleep is a game that is supposed to show world from a baby's perspective. Story starts by you finishing your glass of drink and your mother coming to feed you cake since it's your birthday. Soon you get brought upstairs where after a bit of fun, you get to be put to sleep. This is where the game starts from.. The game is a horror game with stealth sections in it and it utilizes fps perspective, so you can crawl+run and climb. You also also interact with the world by using your mouse,ála Amnesia. After the intro, the game kinda forgets what it's concept was (world from a baby's perspective). Because the game turns into some kinda Amnesia meets Silent Hill and thus, to me it feels like a missed opportunity. Because you start visiting weird dark worlds, hearing voices and seeing monsters, it really doesn't have anything anymore to do with world of babies. Once the game really starts, it feels like I'm playing some mod for Amnesia because the environments are suddenly set on entirely different era. Positives  Athmosphere Soundworld Visual effects quality Controls feel fairly solid Negatives  Missed opportunity on the concept Forced stealth sections Linear gameworlds Very short game lenghtGame is really short because it's only 2hrs long and due to this, it's not something that can be recommended for the base price of 14,99€. I paid 9,99€ for this and feel kinda ripped off..

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												A fantastic First person  journey of horror that starts at your childhood. After eating some cake and getting your teddy bear present, you are on your way to a journey you'll never forget, A magical journey of Horror and wonder.The games made me hold my breath at some points  and I usually don't get scared, the game did a great job on this becuase of the sound and environment which really brings immersion me to the game. The Graphics are pretty good and the game was should be played on the occulus rift to bring in more immersion. With a bit of puzzles here and there for you to solve and make your way to reach the next memories, you'll appreciate this game for the art and life lesson behind this game if you enjoy these types of games. HOWEVERThe game was really short, like 1 hour to beat or 1 and a half hour.  The puzzles were way too easy and predictable nothing too innovative or witty except the one with the sheep platform. Along with the steep price for its value that might make some players wait for a price drop, if you do purchase this game enjoy the art make sure you play it in the dark with headsets on!+First Person Horror+Phenominal Immersion+Great sounds+Good graphics+Good story+Its a real piece of art-Easy puzzles-The length  (1 hour to 1 and a half hour)- The price of the game for its time - No replaybility except to experience the trippy ride again.

Posted: June 3, 2014
												An A+ frightening and unforgetable experience! Full of creative physics puzzles this game kept me engaged from start to finish. Playing from the persepctive of a baby certainly added to the fear factor. It adds a unique twist to the gameplay experience not seen anywhere else which makes the threats in game credible (especially the sounds and being stalked). Seeing things from a low-angle POV was a thrill. The artwork is hauntingly surealist and does well to create a spooky atmosphere that'll keep you on edge. The characters are memorable and you really connect with them because the story works to create emotional bonds with them in ways you've probably not seen before in-game. The story is well-crafted and stays with you well after you've finished, a thoughtful experience. As a big horror fan I can honestly say this game is in my Top 10 Scariest games of all time because it takes the familiar and turns it into a fun-filled nightmare. I can see myself coming back to this for Halloween for some more good scares. Great work and thanks for the amazing experience! :)

Posted: June 2, 2014
												Despite (literally) crawling through this game, stopping to admire the art direction, slowing down to analyze the rather ingenious creative decisions by the Krillbite team, and simply standing frozen in terror on one end of a hallway, I blazed through this whole game in less than 4 hours, and it seems that the length is something that people have been rather disappointed about.Well, I'm going to share my opinion with you, and go on record to say that the length of this game... is... PERFECT. Krillbite doesn't beat around the bush, trying to draw out the gameplay with collectibles, and almost unattainable achievements, or the like. Instead, It focuses on its story, and sticks to it, allowing the player to truly immerse themselves in the unique scenario. There are sometimes lulls in the feeling of insecurity that you'll get while playing, but even in the calmer moments (with perhaps the exception of the VERY start of the game) there is never a moment failing to build tension.As a horror game alone, this title is very good, but it seemed like much more than that. The main draw of "Among the Sleep" is, of course, your character; that of a two year old child. Fear for a two year old and fear for an adult are two completely separate things, so when I say this game is more than just a game, I view it as an incredibly realistic look in to the child psyche. As I played through, I would have very vivid moments recollecting childhood fears. Things that are now commonplace were once terrifying! In a way, "Among the Sleep" brought back very VERY distant memories for me that I hadn't touched in ages. In one particular example, I had to put down my controller for a minute and just stare at the screen. Somehow, the creators had managed to build the scene before me as an almost perfect mimic of a recurring nightmare I would have as a small child. I'm not ashamed to say I stared at it for minutes before being able to proceed! In fact, the only thing I feel after beating this game is impressed.This game is surely going to be more personal for some than others, but it is a must have for lovers of the horror genre, and an interesting experiment even for those who don't normally find a good time in such things. Some people will say that the $20 price tag is too steep, but hey... support the independence! Right? Do that and Krillbite will surely be able to make more amazing titles for us in the future!"Among the Sleep"'s story is one that will draw you in and make you want to finish, and therein lies its greatest strength.

Posted: February 18, 2015
Among the Sleep is an atmospheric horror game with a unique perspective: you play as a toddler.Krillbite did a great job immersing the player in this role - everything is huge, with a slightly skewed perspective; crawling is faster than walking, and you still trip easily while walking or running; your hands and adorably pajama-clad feet are constantly visible as you climb the furniture or balance precariously on a narrow path.The environments are well-crafted - a surreal mix of mundane, dramatic, and imaginatively fantastic.I spent between 4 and 5 hours exploring the main story and the prologue, and would invite you to do the same.I nominated this for the "I'm Not Crying, There's Something in My Eye" Steam Award 2016.

Posted: June 5, 2014
												You carry around a teddy bear that you can hug :)Among the Sleep is a well polished indie horror game which has an interesting concept. You are a two year old toddler and the world you see is from the perspective of a child. A lot of ordinary items and rooms seem much more scary and the developers have nailed it. The graphics are decent but feel sometimes unoptimized. Gameplay is nice and and the game does not sail on cliches. The story is very good and rather than leaving you scared it draws it all nicely together in the end. Personally, the length of the game didn't bother me because the experience was intense.Graphics 7/10Story 10/10Gameplay 8/10Concept 8/10

Posted: November 29, 2014
												Peli antoi sen elämyksen minkä siltä odottikin, eli siis 2-vuotiaan lapsen perspektiivin painajaiseen. Tarina oli uusi, erilainen ja hyvä. Visuaalinen toteutus oli myös hieno. Peli oli enemmänkin tarina jossa mentiin alueita läpi, piirroksia ja muita asioita tutkien, kuin että olisi piileskelty monstereilta ja ratkottu ongelmia. Miinuksena pelin lyhyys ja pulmatehtävien helppous.

Posted: July 23, 2014
												Among the Sleep is a first-person, atmospheric horror adventure game for the perspective of a 2-year old child. Everything is huge. Crawling and staggered walking are integral to how you move around. Your childlike imagination is incredibly active. Norwegian developer, Krillbite Studio, have done an amazing job at placing you in the onesie of a toddler and then subsequently placing you in a night where everything is going bump.Among the Sleep uses a whole arsenal of horror techniques to keep you sweating and on the edge of your seat. As I mentioned, it is an atmospheric horror game. A dark house on a stormy night full of creaks, with the faint noise of a plate breaking or muffled voices can be terrifying. Especially at first when you’re wandering through the house as doors creak open behind you, the sound of heavy footsteps echo throughout the house, and there are shadows framing what I assumed at the time were burly, axe-wielding convicts. I would advise playing the game slightly brighter than recommended setting. Not because I’m a coward, but more because the recommended gamma setting was too dark and I couldn’t actually see what I was doing. Though the game does provides a solution to this. There is a “Hug Teddy” button which causes Teddy to light up, softly illuminating the darkness around you.While I’m generally not a huge fan of horror games due to being a bit flighty and preferring games that empower. But I still enjoyed the horror in Among the Sleep academically. Having you play a toddler was an interesting game elements that I’ve never seen it before and thoroughly enjoyed. The game might seem steep in price for a 5-6 hour game, but you pay more for a 2 hour movie, and a lot more for games that that far less unique and well-thought out.For full review, visithttp://icarusreviews.net/2014/07/11/among-the-sleep/
