Posted: April 12, 2015
												Disclaimer: I had fun playing this game, so this is why I put Thumbs up (Recommend) But I'd put a ''meh'' thumbs for the rest.The game is really short (about 2 hours) and the ending is... really disapointing. I won't spoil anything, but I expected more than the cliché it delivered.You are a 2 year old child, and it feels charming. The game, in itself is gorgeous I believe. The controls are simple and ok and I just love the Teddy. But the game is a bit ''too simple'' and too easy. The only part I had a hard time with is finding the last exit after running around an hour (I was really tired, so it's not even the game's fault).This is clearly meant to be a game that you see the world from the eye and the mind of a child and I get that the world he sees is not really the world as it is.The real con is... The game is not scary... in any way. It's not scary as an experience (I didn't felt helpless), it's not jumpscary (yes, there are monsters... 2 times) it's not freaky. I mean, there should've been emphasis on the child's feeling and how it changes his perception of the world, and no emphasis on the child's body. We get it... he's small and can't climb a lot of things. I want to know how he/she feels (I am still not sure about the sex of the infant) not how it moves... we pretty much all know how a baby moves. A child sees his furniture big: MAKE IT BIG! Don't make it real size, make it like the baby sees it!Also, the Teddy, while being cute, puts too much emphasis on the ''It's dark here, I don't like it'' and... nothing happens.The ''puzzles'' are too simple (yes I know, it reflects the child's capabilities... but as a player I would've like to be challenge in a new way like ''What would a baby do in that situation''. Not... ''Oh... there is 6 holes here... there 6 owls to find... I am not sure what i am supose to do''So I would kind of recommend it, because it is fun... and that the adventures worth the game. But... THE PRICE! This game isn't worth 19.99$. There is no exploration per se (the only places you ''explore'' are to find ''keys'' to put in ''switches'') and the rest are just narrow spaces that you go from point A to point B.The overall design is great though. The music is awesome, the visuals are great and the sounds are also great. The word ''Atmospheric'' really pin point the game, as it surrounds you with beautifulness.But the story... and the gameplay are a bit disapointing. Not BAD, disapointing! It could've been more (Well, every game could bee more, but I mean, as this game in itself, it could've been more)Finish it! (Completionist Ranking)

												This game gave me some surreal feelings of those times when I was a child, had a nightmare, and woke up to no one else in the house and scared the bejeezus out of me. Posted: January 1, 2015
												Among the Sleep is really something. It's such a unique game and a fresh and new take into horror - something original that hasn't been done before. The story and game are really short, but the story-telling is incredible and beautiful and so well done.You play the protagonist role of a 2 year old toddler, you're movement is slow and sluggish, you can't travel anywhere too fast or you'll fall over, but crawling around is great because you're used to that! You can interact with the world around you by pushing buttons, picking things up, turning them around and looking at them and doing other things as you explore the world around you and develop. However, this is where the story telling begins. You experience the story in such a parculiar yet fascinating perspective of the young and still developing mind of this 2 year old. So things aren't as they seem, things are confusing and odd, but a key piece of detail I love the developers for is simple yet so effective.The world around you is new and scary. There's not a great deal I can tell you without spoiling the game and I don't intend to as it is an experience that is satisfying to indulge into.  Is this game worth buying? Yes, but be sure to pick it up on a sale as it is REALLY short. You can get through the game and its DLC in a matter of a couple of hours, but don't let that put you off, it is a truly interesting and amazing game that almost brought a tear to my eye when I understood the story behind it. I rate this game a strong 8.9/10 I recommend this game to horror go-getters, people who want an interesting short story to experience and anyone who can appreciate a new take on this genre.

Posted: September 13, 2014
												Ok, I will admit, I put off picking this game up because other reviews mentioned it as being short.   Maybe it is if you play it strait through.  However, I will say that this dark "American McGee's Alice in wonderland-esk" game is quite well made and a very nice distraction if you love stories that take place in brooding nightmarish environments.  It definately made me jump a few times, and kept me on the edge of my seat. Posted: September 14, 2016
												Among the Sleep is a horror game from the perspective of a baby. I really wish I could say I liked it more. I mean, your walking animation is just adorable, with your little star pajamas and clenched fists waving around full of infant determination. Sprinting is walking on all fours, which is also clever.Other than that, there's not much to the game. How could there be? The game can be finished in about two hours, including the prequel free DLC and even then it doesn’t have much to show for those two hours. The boogeyman can barely catch you, except when he's scripted to show up on your tail. There are no mechanics except some very light climbing and block pushing. It's baby's first puzzle game, which is odd, since it seemed to be a game with a child, not a game for a child. By the end, the game does have some interesting elements with adult themes that a baby couldn't understand, but it's not much to go on. Seeing normal things from a very low perspective also make some mundane things very menacing, but there's not much more to that either. The game is set in a well-realised, but a bit trite nightmare otherworld that almost every other horror game has been putting out since Silent Hill.Among the Sleep is okay, but I would not recommend it to anyone but a diehard horror fan that wants to try everything.

Posted: June 23, 2016
 "Among the Sleep" is an original game with far too few original idea's. During the (only) 3 hours it takes you to play through the game in its entirety you will find yourself bored, not scared and wondering if you payed far too much for a game with far too little scares or fun (I personally believe I did). Posted: June 2, 2014
												Cool premise but clumsy execution is what lets down Among the Sleep in the long run. That said the atmosphere and settings are pretty solid, its just too bad that the gameplay elements are very shallow. And it doesn't help either that the games puzzle elements are very basic and i would be impressed if anyone even remotely familiar with games would get stuck in any of them.Sound design is decent, ambient noises being the best of them while the music can be very haunting. The dialogues and voice acting is serviceable but nothing really stands out. The strong suits of Among the Sleep's core game elements are definitely the different set pieces and the atmosphere.The story was actually really interesting, i don't think i have ever played a game that tried to tackle this sort of subject. Which i found really refreshing, and actually made it all worth while for me.I took me one and a half hour to finish roughly, and to be honest there is nothing really worth going back for. Once you have experience the story, there is nothing drawing you back for a second time through.I'm not sure if i should recommend it or not. It's by no means a "bad" game at all, but it's not a really good game either. I guess i could say its bordering on mediocrity. If you are a fan of Amnesia, Outlast and the plethora of other survival horror games that's out there now, Among the Sleep won't really fill those shoes. It's not particularly scary nor is is very engaging. But of course that is all subjective and differs from person to person.Bottom line, Among the Sleep does have an interesting story with a subject matter that doesn't come around very often. So for that reason alone i would actually recommend the game alone. But i would suggest you wait for a price reduction.

Posted: June 23, 2015
												This game gave me some surreal feelings of those times when I was a child, had a nightmare, and woke up to no one else in the house and scared the bejeezus out of me. How the real world and its traumas were conceptualized and distorted into this sort of nightmare scenario was very compelling and clever. The general controls, abilities, and movement felt well designed and contributed to the world feeling tangible. I found the areas in the game quite enveloping and endearing in their creepy fashion. The game is quite short, even with the included DLC, and the monsters are a bit bothersome more than scary. All in all, I really enjoyed this peculiar perspective for a horror game and would recommend a playthrough (although at a discounted price.)

Posted: May 22, 2015
												Great game, fun to play, full of atmospheric horror, and interesting premise and elements of puzzle solving and exploration.It is a short game, with little replay value but definitely worth playing.What wasn't obvious to me is the game isn't 'set in the house' of the trailer, most of the game is in outdoor, and dark twisted environments.  Most of these areas are actually quite and small, and there isn't really much to look at most of the time, but there are elements of puzzle-solving and hiding which flesh out the game a bit.  The controls are very well designed, and suit the xbox 360 controller very well.I look forward to anything else the devs come up with, and will recommend this game to anyone, especially if it can be had in a sale.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												Among the Sleep is really something. It's such a unique game and a fresh and new take into horror - something original that hasn't been done before. The story and game are really short, but the story-telling is incredible and beautiful and so well done.You play the protagonist role of a 2 year old toddler, you're movement is slow and sluggish, you can't travel anywhere too fast or you'll fall over, but crawling around is great because you're used to that! You can interact with the world around you by pushing buttons, picking things up, turning them around and looking at them and doing other things as you explore the world around you and develop. However, this is where the story telling begins. You experience the story in such a parculiar yet fascinating perspective of the young and still developing mind of this 2 year old. So things aren't as they seem, things are confusing and odd, but a key piece of detail I love the developers for is simple yet so effective.The world around you is new and scary. There's not a great deal I can tell you without spoiling the game and I don't intend to as it is an experience that is satisfying to indulge into.  Is this game worth buying? Yes, but be sure to pick it up on a sale as it is REALLY short. You can get through the game and its DLC in a matter of a couple of hours, but don't let that put you off, it is a truly interesting and amazing game that almost brought a tear to my eye when I understood the story behind it. I rate this game a strong 8.9/10 I recommend this game to horror go-getters, people who want an interesting short story to experience and anyone who can appreciate a new take on this genre.

Posted: June 10, 2014
												So here's what I felt about the story and atmosphere of this game in particular hopefully without spoiling anything:At first it didn't make too much sense and I felt as if it were just going to throw me, a two year old man, into a dark helpless environment where everything was out to kill me. However it only did part of that. The atmosphere was very well constructed to resemble what a two year old could possibly be taking in if it were scared of something. Everything that was around me that I would look to for direction and expected to be able to read was surprisingly to me, not in English. It was symbols and characters that made me think that it was the doing of aliens. However, looking back on it after completing the game, and realizing the message of the game, it wasn't in English because I was just a two year old. That struck me as interesting. Another thing on the topic of me being scared ♥♥♥♥less looking to the environment for direction is that there were drawings. In all the little nooks and cranny's that I would crawl to to hide from whatever I thought was chasing me had a little drawing of what a child would interpret towards whatever the ♥♥♥♥ was going down. That was another thing that I was impressed with. Now, when it comes to scary♥♥♥♥♥♥ I do not like to be a part of it. Sure I'll watch it, but ♥♥♥♥ everything about participating in it and leading the charge. But this game really got me hooked. I was a little sad but relieved that it was so short, but I feel like they timed everything just perfectly. And the noises... ♥♥♥♥ those noises. But back to the point here. The game didn't focus on jump-scaring a ♥♥♥♥♥, but instead it focused on timing events just right to where the smallest mistake you make would scare the junk out of you. It really made you pay attention to what you were doing, where you were crawling/walking/bumping into, and why you were seeing the things you were. Unlike Amnesia, it really plays with more emotions than just fear. It gives you that feeling of "Why" rather than "Okay, that just happened" forcing you to investigate and become more interested in what happens rather than making you feel like you have to just escape from what happened. Also, as Halo has proven, if you can see your feet it's a good game. You can see your feet. On that note, your character acts as a 2 year old would if it was scared. (Constantly playing with it's belly button, making little squeeking noises, hugging your bear for security, etc) As the story progresses,♥♥♥♥♥♥naturally gets more freaky, but starts to foreshadow into what you ultimately discover at the end. I can't really go further into it without spoiling, but its really just a fantastic game. I hated the feels the whole way through in a good way, but I just couldn't get enough of it. I had to know, and when I found out, it was a wrecking ball of awesome. The key to this game is immersion. Without it, you're wasting your time. I recommend this game to any player who enjoys a good story. You will not be disappointed.TL;DR: Among the Sleep = bigger man-tears boner than The Notebook could ever dream to present.

Posted: December 25, 2014
												A creative, if short, experience for those looking for a new horror fix.GAMEPLAY: Mostly consists of exploring environments and solving fairly simple physics-based puzzles (think Penumbra/Amnesia), with the odd stealth/hiding section to avoid enemies. It's not groundbreaking, but this game does some cool things, adapting the gameplay mechanics to fit its subject matter. Given that you play as a toddler, you crawl faster than you can run, and you can fall down if you run for too long. However, crawling can limit your perception of the environment somewhat, and just "feels" strange. It adds an interesting dimension to the gameplay. Furthermore, rather than just giving you a flashlight, your source of light comes from cuddling your teddy bear. Sure, the effect is mostly the same (albeit with a more limited radius) but it's creative and serves to immerse the player.GRAPHICS: Looks pretty good. There's a nice contrast between bright coloured objects in dark environments, and the lighting adds to the environments by bathing them in an eerie glow. ENVIRONMENTS: Surreal, they seem like dark fairytales and nightmares, but with a lighthearted twist at once. They're not overbearingly scary, but rather, serve to make the player feel lost in a dream. Perhaps their most interesting attribute is that everything is "big" (sometimes disproportionately so), reflecting the youth of the protagonist. On the downside, they're sparsely decorated at times and there isn't a whole lot to explore along the fairly linear paths.AUDIO: Good sound effects all around, and the music is ambient and serves it pretty well. The highlight is definitely Roger L. Jackson as Teddy (of American McGee's Alice fame) whose distinctive voice lends its warmth and sense of curiosity to the story. Some creepy sound effects punctuate the generally quiet of the game, with one enemy noise in particular being pretty jarring.ENEMIES: There aren't many (only two from what I recall) but they're pretty eerie and are the impetus for the stealth sections. They continue the theme of childlike wonder, being large and overbearing. One seems like a creature from a fairy tale, with another looking like something a child would see in the shadows at night from everyday objects. HORROR: This is the department that the game falls a bit short in. I don't think this game was going for Amnesia-style horror here, but it still isn't particularly scary. For me, it was quite tense at the beginning, but I found that it wore off unless I knew there were monsters present.STORY: Without giving away anything, it pulls a few punches and is very good. The ending is quite impactful, and I was quite surprised at the direction it took.VALUE: It's a pretty short game, so I'd recommend getting it on sale.

Posted: December 25, 2014
												I'm pretty impressed with this horror game. While the short length might be off-putting for some, I think the game is exactly as long as it should be; lengthening this sort of game would produce fluff, and I dislike fluff more than a short game.  Among the Sleep is well executed in terms of mechanics, tone, and narrative.  The story is better than I gave it credit for when I started playing, and it is told well through the environment and character design.   **minor spoilers**While the mechanics are simple, there are design choices worth noting.  For one, the option to crawl or walk is done in an interesting way; the player can't grab things or clutch the teddy bear for light while he crawls, but he moves faster, has a lower profile, and is not prone to falling.  I felt much more comfortable and "safer" while crawling.  Walking is clearly made the riskier choice, but  the player has to do it regularly in order to progress.  The player is faced with a similar delima with holding the teddy bear.  It sheds some light, but the toddler can't interact with objects while he holds the bear.  I thought  the developers made some very good choices with even the limitted mechanics options.  The player had to consistantly perform actions outside of a toddler's comfort zone (and mine; I would have liked to crawl  the whole game) in order to continue processing what was happening to him.The environmental design (visual and sound) is wonderful, sets a consistant tone, and is meaningful.  Look at the screen shots and trailer.  Enough said.  I won't say much about the character design except that when I first saw it, I hid under the bed for like two minutes (in game, of course...).I won't spoil much about the story either, but it is great to see more video games using things like themes, motifs, mechanics, symbolism, and subtlty to tell a story rather than strictly dialogue/text.  I thought all of the "words" in the game being random squiggles was a very cute yet alienating detail.Overall, this is one of the most well-executed games I've played recently.  There are a few parts that drag a bit toward the beginning, but the game as a whole is worth the slow parts.  Movement, opening drawers, and throwing objects is cumbersome at times, but, well, you're playing as a baby.  It kind of comes with the territory.Fans of horror and story-centric games would probably enjoy this.

Posted: June 2, 2014
												Cool premise but clumsy execution is what lets down Among the Sleep in the long run. That said the atmosphere and settings are pretty solid, its just too bad that the gameplay elements are very shallow. And it doesn't help either that the games puzzle elements are very basic and i would be impressed if anyone even remotely familiar with games would get stuck in any of them.Sound design is decent, ambient noises being the best of them while the music can be very haunting. The dialogues and voice acting is serviceable but nothing really stands out. The strong suits of Among the Sleep's core game elements are definitely the different set pieces and the atmosphere.The story was actually really interesting, i don't think i have ever played a game that tried to tackle this sort of subject. Which i found really refreshing, and actually made it all worth while for me.I took me one and a half hour to finish roughly, and to be honest there is nothing really worth going back for. Once you have experience the story, there is nothing drawing you back for a second time through.I'm not sure if i should recommend it or not. It's by no means a "bad" game at all, but it's not a really good game either. I guess i could say its bordering on mediocrity. If you are a fan of Amnesia, Outlast and the plethora of other survival horror games that's out there now, Among the Sleep won't really fill those shoes. It's not particularly scary nor is is very engaging. But of course that is all subjective and differs from person to person.Bottom line, Among the Sleep does have an interesting story with a subject matter that doesn't come around very often. So for that reason alone i would actually recommend the game alone. But i would suggest you wait for a price reduction.

Posted: January 9, 2015
												Among the Sleep is a psychological adventure game where you are put in the shoes (so to speak) of a toddler while he tries to find her missing mother during nighttime with the help of his fellow, rather talkative teddy bear companion.You navigate the various environments of the game from the very eyes of the toddler: you are mainly tasked to overcome various obstacles along your path (by either crowling, climbing or rarely use some items you collected and put in an inventory) and advance further through the chapters. You can also hug Teddy to illuminate your surrondings (even if, sadly, this feature isn't brought up as much as one would expect).While many believe this is a full-fledged horror game, Among the Sleep is more interested into make you see how disturbing reality can be when saw from a toddler's point of view and how it twists everything it touches. Therefore, don't expect any jump scare or chases: the game is very tense and will sometime try to screw with you, but that's pretty much about it.The graphics are stylized enough, with their strongest suit being the peculiar and warped level design. The same cannot be said for other models in the game, but they don't tend to stand out that much.If you love that kind of games that can offer you an unique and "artistic" experience without being that keen on a superb gameplay, Among the Sleep could be yet another game to add to your Steam library

Posted: September 14, 2016
												Among the Sleep is a horror game from the perspective of a baby. I really wish I could say I liked it more. I mean, your walking animation is just adorable, with your little star pajamas and clenched fists waving around full of infant determination. Sprinting is walking on all fours, which is also clever.Other than that, there's not much to the game. How could there be? The game can be finished in about two hours, including the prequel free DLC and even then it doesn’t have much to show for those two hours. The boogeyman can barely catch you, except when he's scripted to show up on your tail. There are no mechanics except some very light climbing and block pushing. It's baby's first puzzle game, which is odd, since it seemed to be a game with a child, not a game for a child. By the end, the game does have some interesting elements with adult themes that a baby couldn't understand, but it's not much to go on. Seeing normal things from a very low perspective also make some mundane things very menacing, but there's not much more to that either. The game is set in a well-realised, but a bit trite nightmare otherworld that almost every other horror game has been putting out since Silent Hill.Among the Sleep is okay, but I would not recommend it to anyone but a diehard horror fan that wants to try everything.

												This was actually a nice little game with an unexpected ending. Posted: May 14, 2015
												At first I didn't really see what all the fuss was about. I didn't find the game scary at all. Even when the harmless enemy character started appearing, it felt more like a half-hearted haunted house ride.However, about halfway through the game, the enemy character starts being able to attack you, and that's when things got really scary. So scary in fact, that I had to play the song Spanish Flea in the background to lighten up the mood so I could get through it.At points it can be difficult to figure out where to go, but otherwise it's a very creepy and atmospheric game.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												This is one of the best horror games I have ever played by far, and the fact that it is brilliantly immersive makes it incredibly enjoyable. I would definitely not reccomend it, however, because it's like one and a half hours long and it's not worth anything more than like 5 bucks. Only buy it if it's on sale.

Posted: June 10, 2014
												So here's what I felt about the story and atmosphere of this game in particular hopefully without spoiling anything:At first it didn't make too much sense and I felt as if it were just going to throw me, a two year old man, into a dark helpless environment where everything was out to kill me. However it only did part of that. The atmosphere was very well constructed to resemble what a two year old could possibly be taking in if it were scared of something. Everything that was around me that I would look to for direction and expected to be able to read was surprisingly to me, not in English. It was symbols and characters that made me think that it was the doing of aliens. However, looking back on it after completing the game, and realizing the message of the game, it wasn't in English because I was just a two year old. That struck me as interesting. Another thing on the topic of me being scared ♥♥♥♥less looking to the environment for direction is that there were drawings. In all the little nooks and cranny's that I would crawl to to hide from whatever I thought was chasing me had a little drawing of what a child would interpret towards whatever the ♥♥♥♥ was going down. That was another thing that I was impressed with. Now, when it comes to scary♥♥♥♥♥♥ I do not like to be a part of it. Sure I'll watch it, but ♥♥♥♥ everything about participating in it and leading the charge. But this game really got me hooked. I was a little sad but relieved that it was so short, but I feel like they timed everything just perfectly. And the noises... ♥♥♥♥ those noises. But back to the point here. The game didn't focus on jump-scaring a ♥♥♥♥♥, but instead it focused on timing events just right to where the smallest mistake you make would scare the junk out of you. It really made you pay attention to what you were doing, where you were crawling/walking/bumping into, and why you were seeing the things you were. Unlike Amnesia, it really plays with more emotions than just fear. It gives you that feeling of "Why" rather than "Okay, that just happened" forcing you to investigate and become more interested in what happens rather than making you feel like you have to just escape from what happened. Also, as Halo has proven, if you can see your feet it's a good game. You can see your feet. On that note, your character acts as a 2 year old would if it was scared. (Constantly playing with it's belly button, making little squeeking noises, hugging your bear for security, etc) As the story progresses,♥♥♥♥♥♥naturally gets more freaky, but starts to foreshadow into what you ultimately discover at the end. I can't really go further into it without spoiling, but its really just a fantastic game. I hated the feels the whole way through in a good way, but I just couldn't get enough of it. I had to know, and when I found out, it was a wrecking ball of awesome. The key to this game is immersion. Without it, you're wasting your time. I recommend this game to any player who enjoys a good story. You will not be disappointed.TL;DR: Among the Sleep = bigger man-tears boner than The Notebook could ever dream to present.

												This game is short, but the adventure it takes you on is very enjoyable. Posted: April 12, 2015
												Disclaimer: I had fun playing this game, so this is why I put Thumbs up (Recommend) But I'd put a ''meh'' thumbs for the rest.The game is really short (about 2 hours) and the ending is... really disapointing. I won't spoil anything, but I expected more than the cliché it delivered.You are a 2 year old child, and it feels charming. The game, in itself is gorgeous I believe. The controls are simple and ok and I just love the Teddy. But the game is a bit ''too simple'' and too easy. The only part I had a hard time with is finding the last exit after running around an hour (I was really tired, so it's not even the game's fault).This is clearly meant to be a game that you see the world from the eye and the mind of a child and I get that the world he sees is not really the world as it is.The real con is... The game is not scary... in any way. It's not scary as an experience (I didn't felt helpless), it's not jumpscary (yes, there are monsters... 2 times) it's not freaky. I mean, there should've been emphasis on the child's feeling and how it changes his perception of the world, and no emphasis on the child's body. We get it... he's small and can't climb a lot of things. I want to know how he/she feels (I am still not sure about the sex of the infant) not how it moves... we pretty much all know how a baby moves. A child sees his furniture big: MAKE IT BIG! Don't make it real size, make it like the baby sees it!Also, the Teddy, while being cute, puts too much emphasis on the ''It's dark here, I don't like it'' and... nothing happens.The ''puzzles'' are too simple (yes I know, it reflects the child's capabilities... but as a player I would've like to be challenge in a new way like ''What would a baby do in that situation''. Not... ''Oh... there is 6 holes here... there 6 owls to find... I am not sure what i am supose to do''So I would kind of recommend it, because it is fun... and that the adventures worth the game. But... THE PRICE! This game isn't worth 19.99$. There is no exploration per se (the only places you ''explore'' are to find ''keys'' to put in ''switches'') and the rest are just narrow spaces that you go from point A to point B.The overall design is great though. The music is awesome, the visuals are great and the sounds are also great. The word ''Atmospheric'' really pin point the game, as it surrounds you with beautifulness.But the story... and the gameplay are a bit disapointing. Not BAD, disapointing! It could've been more (Well, every game could bee more, but I mean, as this game in itself, it could've been more)Finish it! (Completionist Ranking)

Posted: January 26, 2015
												As others have stated, Among the Sleep is a short game, but a rather enjoyable one. For those thrill seekers looking for nightmares and psychological scarring, this isn't the game for you, but if you can put yourself in the mindframe of a toddler, it has some good 'jump scare' moments. Overall I would give this an 8.5 out of 10 rating. I'd like to see a sequel made, perhaps even when the child is another year or two older and the challenges are a bit more difficult. There is potential for a series of games that one can grow with, if the creators can stay true to the original style of game play, but advance with each storyline.

Posted: March 29, 2015
												Among the Sleep is an interesting idea in storytelling, done in such a way that you truly feel for the mission of the main character; however, I had some minor issues with it.(As i haven't played it in a good deal of time, prior to this review, I'll keep this brief):CONS: - Can be confusing; had a few issues finding where to go, or what I was looking for, due to the odd layout of a few stages- Protagonist sure can do a lot for a child... kind of hurts immersion, but only if you're picky, like I am.PROS: - Nice visuals and atmosphere- Brilliant concept- Lots of heart and dedication went into this game, and it shows.So, if you are looking for a fairly casual, yet still captivating in it's own right kind of game, then pick up Among the Sleep.You won't be disappointed.Recommended, but on sale is always best :)

Posted: December 26, 2014
												I really liked Among the Sleep. They did a good job with putting the player in the role of a 2 year old and seeing the world through his eyes. The game isn't really scary. It does have tense moments, though. It's dark, disorienting and sometimes confusing...like how the world can seem to little kids at night. This is a fantasy game set in the world of the kids projections of his surroundings as he tries to find his mom. There was one part in the beginning that really creeped me out. The kid is seemingly all alone in his room, but a man's voice is clearly heard giggling from somewhere nearby, unseen, like a psycho murderous clown waiting to leap out and murder the kid. I'll say no more about that! The puzzles of the game were really easy to figure out, but this was a really fun and interesting world to explore. The art direction is fantastic. The atmosphere of the game is really well done. The game is only a few hours long. I'm a busy guy and I appreciate that I was able to start and finish it in one night. The only part that actually seemed like padding is the added DLC that is essentially a side story that was only slightly related to the main game. Still, it was nice to have that extra little bit to play when the game was done. I suggest playing this one in the dark with head phones, and turning the brightness down. Among the Sleep is solid and an easy recommendation.

Posted: February 25, 2015
Among The Sleep is a stellar little interactive adventure with some light horror elements and some good-looking surreal imagery. You play as a toddler of unspecified gender who wakes up one night to find his mother and his trusty teddy bear missing. You have to navigate the intricacies of the dream world, solving puzzles, finding keys, and avoiding a horrible monster that's totally not meant to be symbolic of anything, honest.It's really short; I wouldn't recommend buying it at the current price, but at a price drop, it's definitely a pleasant interactive experience and the light horor elements are done really well. It's also very similar to Amnesia and other games in that genre, so if you're not into the whole First Person Horror Adventure thing, I'd probably give this pass.If you played Amnesia, and felt it would be better if you were 4 feet shorter and had a best friend Teddy Bear, Among The Sleep is for you.

Posted: May 31, 2014
												Are you searching for a rather unique type of horror experience? Has your thirst for psychological torment this year not been quenched yet? Do you crave to relive old childhood nightmares? Then Among The Sleep might be for you...This delightfully terrifying experience grants gamers the opportunity to explore a creepy Silent Hill-esque world of terror through the eyes of a toddler. That premise alone should capture anyone's curiosity. For what does a helpless baby represent the most? Exactly... Helplessness. You are no soldier, no athletic investigator - just a baby in the land of giants. One that can barely walk on two feet. You don't get to see that type of scenario every day. But what can be said about the game itself?Both music and sounds, arguably the most important parts of any horror game, do not disappoint. You'll often be looking over your shoulder to check whether that ominous noise in the distance was really just part of the ambiance or instead a sinister monster stalking you. Among The Sleep definitely plays it's cards well, and spends a good quarter of it's length on excellent build-up to the main events. Especially the first big area, a forested house located within a foggy swamp, managed to freak me out again and again. I'd not want to return there anytime soon, that's for sure.In terms of gameplay you'll be collecting stuff in order to access new places. A lot of stuff. Perhaps too much stuff? Eh, it didn't bother me in all honesty. The environments are beautifully designed, and keep things interesting enough to overshadow the simplistic puzzles. I swear to god though... That evil forest. Or the playground before it. The atmosphere oozes greatness around every corner. You'll never know what to expect next. Better grow used to being all alone, for your only "companion" happens to be a teddy bear - one who also serves as a sort of light source if hugged tightly. How charming. Well, you take what you can get as a toddler. Flashlights ain't cheap!HOWEVER... Among The Sleep unfortunately isn't perfect. The second half of it, in my opinion, happens to be much weaker than the first, which feels as if the developers spent most of their budget on it, only to run out of significant ideas later on. This is quite a shame indeed. And it doesn't stop there. The game is also a rather short experience. Two - three hours, maybe four if you take it slow, are what most players will probably get out of it. And that length is somewhat disappointing, considering that you need to pay 20 bucks for it. Even the story, despite feeling intriguing at points, ultimately fails to outweigh these negatives. After reaching the end, you'll be left with that bothersome "is it over already?" feeling in your gut. Such wasted potential.In conclusion, I'd say that you should give Among The Sleep a try. I greatly enjoyed my time with it, despite some flaws along the way. And chances are you will as well. But it might be wise to wait for a price drop. Chances are you'd probably feel a little cheated to pay 20 bucks for a game that only last two hours if you play through it in a fast-paced manner.TL;DR: Good horror. Starts out strong, leaves a little to be desired in the second half. Overall too short for 20 bucks.FINAL VERDICT: 7 / 10

Posted: March 15, 2015
												A very unique take on FPS horror, the first 30-45 minutes along were worth buying the game. Its difficult to maintain the same tension of the early portions of the game, but the developers sensed this and introduced some puzzle dynamics. In a way I wanted the early tension to continue, but the level design and "encounters" in the later game were very worth it and I loved the ending. Its very short, but it took me a while to beat it because I only played 30 minutes to an hour at a time before being worn out (in a good way). Very worth the money.

Posted: March 16, 2015
												I enjoyed this game. It is however quite short.The gameplay is quite similar to the Amnesia series, where in you are given an objective to complete but there is a monster lurking, and your only options is to go unnoticed.  Since this game has you you playing as a 2 year old child in a suburban household, rather than a student of the occult in a victorian era castle the subject matter is lighter, but only slightly.  It would seem that a child imagination is a powerful thing, and that left alone in a dark house with a very real threat lurking things can get dark quickly. It is however quite short.  I was able to get through all of the story and the free DLC in ~4 hours. Definitely wait for a sale for this, < $10 seems more appropriate.

Posted: July 2, 2015
												You're a baby!  I mean, in the GAME "Among the Sleep" you play as a baby.  I real life, you may or may not actually be a baby.  I don't know.The game, just so you know, only took me about two and half hours to complete.  I'm assuming that's because most babies have the attention span of a squirrel that got one too many jolts from a taser.  I don't speak from experience.  Honest.Where was I?  My attention wavered ...So it's baby's birthday, and Mom gives the little bxxxxxd cake loaded with LSD (I'm assuming, 'cause the game goes totally bxxxxxt later), and a broken 3rd-rate pirate knock-off of Teddy Ruxpin.  I was disappointed, 'cause I was kinda hoping he'd be vulgar like the bear from Ted.  Bummer.So baby goes exploring and has some adventures, and he finds all these crayon drawings somebody drew (maybe his Mom.  I mean, she IS the one that dosed his cake with LSD).And if you bother to look at the sxxxxy drawings, they kinda tell a story ... if you're into that.  Story's not very clear, 'cause whoever crayoned those pictures can't draw for sxxt.Anyway, as baby crawls and stumbles around his increasingly twisted and psychedelic home, he starts getting stalked by a monster.  The monster is really scary, so I don't know why baby wasn't screaming hysterically and leaving sxxt-trails everywhere (like I woulda been, had I been in that situation), but I suppose maybe there were downers in the cake too, so baby's fine.  Hides under stuff.  Spies.Eventually you reach the end, and it's poignant and sxxt.It's a beautiful game.  It's an original idea.  Never played a baby before.  Story's cool ... what I understood of it from those awful crayonings.  But it's two and half hours long.They coulda done a lot more with it.  I hope they have some dlc ... "Among the sleep ... with knives" or something.

												Probably the only game where protagonist is a toddler in pajamas and your sidekick is a teddy bear. I mean, imagine Alien:Isolation, but where you are a toddler. Total mind♥♥♥♥. It seems like Alien:Isolation devs kinda got inspiration from this game...The game is incredibly short (a bit over 3 hours including DLC gameplay), so much that despite liking it, I'm unsure if I could justify 20 € on it. 10 € yes, at any time. But if you want to support developers fully, just buy it. It's really good.

Posted: April 15
												Unusual little horror game with some creepy moments and fairly dark subject matter. I enjoyed the added dimensions of playing as a child and found it really interesting way to show a different perspective and add to the atmosphere. Posted: April 18
												I loved the concept of Among the Sleep.  How many games have you play through the eyes of a toddler? This is certainly the only one I am aware of.  I can give bonus points for originality here and in a horror title no less, which is no easy thing to do these days.  Among the Sleep does a terrific job at immersing you into the world because of its engrossing atmosphere and ambiance. I will admit I was pretty spooked at certain points.  The mechanics are reminiscent of Frictional Games' Amnesia and Penumbra titles; you can interact with items in the world but there is zero puzzle solving that you will find in the aforementioned games.  It is more so a matter of finding and interacting with objects that help you progress through the game. You cannot fight the few enemies encountered, instead, you must avoid them at all costs and make your way past them.  This characteristic of horror games I have found is either absolutely loved or hated typically.  I personally enjoy it because it puts the player in a helpless state and gives you all the more reason to be scared.  This is, after all, the effect all horror games should invoke.  But there are those who are annoyed or frustrated by this and I can understand that.Among the Sleep unfortunately suffers from a few issues however.  My biggest problem with it is the technical issues I have experienced.  The amount of stuttering I encountered was surprisingly bothersome.  Considering the very short length of the game (anywhere between 1 and 4 hours depending on your playstyle and if you are hunting for achievements), you would have expected it to be significantly more polished.  The stuttering and major fps drops are distracting and certainly take away from game's immersion.  I could have 150 fps for a moment then suddenly it drops just below 60 and it is awfully noticeable.  My rig also is running on an 6600k, gtx 980, and 16 gb of ram, way above the game's recommended requirements.The last but smaller problem I had with the game is the save system.  Throughout each chapter, as you play, the game will notify you that it's saving which is all well and good if you die because you will restart from your last save point.  Unfortunately though, if you quit a chapter mid game, you will have to start that chapter from the very beginning.  Not a huge deal given its short length but misleading because when you see the game autosaving, you assume you can just quit and return at the moment of the auto save, not the case here.All this aside, Among the Sleep is a unique experience and is definitely worth adding to your library.  I would suggest waiting for a nice sale to pick it up though.

Posted: December 28, 2016
												Another in the long line of indie horror games that never gets going, has an interesting concept that's quickly abandoned with left-field developments, all filled out with a clichéd and predictable plot.For the horror aspect, well it's best to say: even I wasn't scared by this game. I don't play many horror games, I'm easily scared by their shenanigans, but this one never really tried. It was certainly unsettling, but that's only down to you and how long it takes you to realise you can run around and make as much noise as you like when no demons come out to get you.The concept seemed to be that you're roaming a hunted house or being attacked by demons, but with the killer twist that you're just a baby. This concept is explored for all of 20 minutes, after which you enter alternate worlds (the classic MC Escher-inspired linear platforming, toddler style). It doesn't help that you'll likely guess the ending and major plot points in the first 10 minutes. The characters say or do a couple of things at the start which appear to be hinting and foreshadowing, only for it to turn out they were just saying random crap you shouldn't have analysed.This feels like a 3-hour concept video or game a developer would show publishers to get them to invest and publish a hypothetical full game. It's tempting to recommend this just for the potential it has even though it never used it. Instead it's another game that's best right at the start, then they go "I guess we better put some generic gameplay crap in there so it's a game" and it's done.

Posted: December 25, 2014
												Great aesthetics and presentation but one of the shortest games released this year. If you liked Gone Home and care more about story than gameplay, then you're going to love this. If you're looking for a horror game to challenge and scare you, this is not that game.

Posted: February 21, 2015
TL;DR:Kept me horified for hours after playtrough!A tremendous execution of a horror game!If you're in to horror games, I can really recomend you give it a go!Long / Pros / Cons VersionPros:A new angle on survival horror trough a 2 year old's eyes.Made me, trough the story, identify somewhat with the protagonist todler.Music and sound was great and really enhanced the mood!Graphics and lighting, although a little cartoony, a great fit for this game!Atmosphere was, due to all of the above and the scares, terrifying!Cons:...there were a few things that broke the immersion of the game...When climbing, drawers for example, from prone/crawling position the camera clips trough to the inside of the drawer while you climb.I once fell trough the world, although I'm kind of an explorer so I don't expect this to happen to that many ppl......so, this might not really be a con... but, although I don't know if I'd really want it any longer, the game was kinda short... and it really left me longing for more!OK, I might have forgotten something in the list above, but know this:This short, dark and atmospheric, singleplayer puzzle adventure survival horror game kept me horified for hours after playtrough!It's a tremendous execution of a horror game!So if you're in to horror games, I can really recomend you give it a go!

Posted: June 19, 2015
												I really like this game a lot--it's short, sad, and sweet. What makes it unique is the perspective; it's a first person perspective horror game where you play as a 2-year-old toddler. The game really makes you see the world through the imagination and fears of a little child. The visual design of the game succeeds in making benign everyday objects look menacing when in the dark. Is that some sort of monster standing there watching you? Or is it simply a coat on a coat rack with some boots sticking out the bottom of it? Even your own toys can sometimes seem unsettling. I liked how, whenever you see written text in the game, like in an open book, for example, it looks like gibberish, since your character can't read. Sound effects are used effectively at the right times to evoke a sense of dread and fear.In my opinion, the star of the show here is Teddy, your imaginary friend teddy bear who seems alive and who is with you you traverse the dark, avoiding a monster and looking for your missing mother. Teddy is an ambiguous character; cute n' creepy. Is he there to help you or is he not to be trusted? He is well voice-acted, but there are long sections of the game where you almost forget he is with you because he doesn't have much to say. I realize this is under the pretense that you both have to be quite so as not to alert the monster to your presence, but I just feel like Teddy could have been used more in some of the middle sections of the game.I'm not going lie, this game can really get you into the mindset of a small child and I did find myself weeping after the climax and at the end. The game can be scary, but there's no blood and guts or anything. But be aware that the game delves into issues that kids shouldn't have to face, but sometimes do. The evidence to me that this game successfully told a story with some emotional impact was the fact that it gave me the feels even though I had a pretty stable and happy childhood.

Posted: April 26
												Good game.

Posted: April 21
												This game will impress you. And it will shock you. At first it may seem like a mindless fun little creepy game, but it's not. The story has a true depth to it, one you wouldn't expect. It's an horror game that manages to be real and believable - even relatable for some people with a particular infancy - and that's what makes it truly scary. Something that very few games of this genre have been able to achieve. Given its short duration, about 2-3 hours, some may prefer to grab it on sale for best value.But, by all means, this is a little gem that is certainly worth to add to your collection!

Posted: August 23, 2014
												Beautiful, unique, and allegorical, Among the Sleep is a masterpiece of the horror genre.While it probably doesn't have enough jumpscares to satisfy your average horror junkie, this game is absolutely packed with terrifying psychological horror, radiant surrealist imagery, and immersive atmospheres, as well as a tragic story.Reminiscent of Yume Nikki (another game very worth checking out), I found both its dreamy visual style and abstract method of storytelling very impressive. I will say, it was quite short--in fact, I finished it in one night--but it was still every bit worth its pricetag. I would not hesitate to give this game a 10/10.

Posted: June 18, 2014
												This game was, in all, pretty nice.I'm not a real connoisseur of horror games, but this was a good kind of pseudo-horror that doesn't cram so many jumpscares down your throat that you have multiple heart attacks in one sitting. I did, however, find myself craving something more in the "scare factor" of this game, I find it more of a puzzle game at heart, with some big monsters that you hardly ever see. There's a lot of ambience, and a few forced encounters, but I didn't fail once in the entire game(Okay, so I fell of a cliff, but that doesn't count).I thought the map design and the mechanics were exquisite, crawling up stuff and using chairs to reach doorknobs added a new factor that made the game more intimate(keys and pressure plates are so old), but in all, it was far too short.With all of the crowd-sourced funding and open map design, I think this should have been a $9.99-$14.99 game because there is no replay value, once you solve the puzzle, there's no other way to spend time. Hopefully, Krillbite will have FREE DLC for the game(Like adding chapter 5 maybe), or some more achievements, or an alternate path through the game, or anything...That all aside, I suggest people get this game; but wait for a sale or a mark down in price.

Posted: December 31, 2015
												Among the Sleep takes the horror of helplessness a step further by putting the player in the footie pajamas of a small child. The first person camera wobbles and drags on the ground to simulate the perspective of a child that hasn't quite mastered walking yet, but somehow I still found myself trying to translate the distorted reality the child was seeing instead of living it. The unraveling of that mystery is engaging and I was always left wondering. I didn't manage to sort through it all until everything was properly revealed. But other mediums are just as good if not better at keeping the audience guessing. What games do so well, and what Among the Sleep did not succeed at, is dropping the player in a situation and asking how would they react. As the game itself is as simple to play as it is short, the understanding born of that process never has a chance to come about. Shortness isn't a bad thing though. The game doesn't wear out its welcome and it doesn't take more than it gives. It does have an interesting story to tell, and tells it well, just not better than a movie might.

Posted: August 28, 2014
												So someone had the thought, "You know what would be more messed up than experiencing Silent Hill? Expereincing Silent Hill as a toddler."That is Among the Sleep in a nutshell; Silent Hill 2 except the main character is a baby. The game can be finished in a handful of hours, but it's a surprisingly effective horror game, and the pictures and symbolism scattered throughout tells a sad story about both the kid and the monster that stalks him thoughtout the nightmarish landscapes.I highly recommend this game for fans of psychological horror.

												This game is mostly a game about exploration through the mind of a toddler. Playing through I did not find many hazards that were of threat, just more creepy than anything. Posted: July 29, 2015
												Holy ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥balls. And all of that first sentence is stars immediately. This game is absolutely incredible. If only sheerly for the perspective not only in gameplay, but in narration...Just like the more well known FNAF, there's a lot of stuff hiding in plain sight that reveals some history and the going ons that lead to what's happening right now. Although this time you're not a security guard and they aren't animatronics. You're a very very young toddler of 2, and your life is depicted in drawings. Crude ones, as you'd suspect. As you make your way through hell and back you get tidbits of information that lead suspicions to reality. Soon enough, you live that reality.Some say the imagination of a child is the strongest. Perhaps that is true, as is depicted in this game. What is real and what isn't real doesn't matter any more. You're 2. The world is a big scary place and you're... You, in comparison. Tiny. Dfenseless. Horrified.I found my self mesmerized, comforted, calmed... Then was thrust head first into hell. With incredibly atmospheric gameplay and stunning music this game had me balls deep before the ♥♥♥♥ing tutorial ended. Sucking me in quicker than a whirl pool. Before I knew it the world was like I said, big, terrifying... And I'm all alone... Well, not entirely. Teddy comes  along to aid you but ultimately does nothing other than exposition and plot driving through the stuff that can't be explained so well with out actually telling the player.Teddy tags along and acts mainly as your flashlight. And my god was it comforting to have some ♥♥♥♥ing light. Keep the gama down, play in the dark, keep the sound a little high.It can be rather hard to see and actually explore with the gama too low and too high it ruins the experience. Finding the right balance of both lighting and sound is a bit tricky at first but once done the game is that much more amazing.Its a bit hard to find places to hide when you can't see though, and you can't use Teddy's flashlight ability when crawling and you can't run when using him. You have to stand and meander, which makes it even more stressful when running from the pants fillingly terrifying monsters chasing you. Don't forget, this game is incredibly immersive. If you get immersed, you'd be filling your pants too.The game is a cocktail of smooth relaxing and haunting moments of serenity while momma hums for you, or a music box alludes to peace. Then you get to a puzzle. The puzzles in this game are exceptionally well done as they force the player to explore places they may not have explored. Although it can cause backtracking and a bit of confusion. The game looks, sounds, and feels great though so meandering through the dark, in the dark, scared out of your mind can't be all that bad. After, and sometimes durring, puzzles there's sections of horror. Your little tiny baby legs take you in and out of the gates of hell over and over as the nightmares of the real world /are/ your real world. Constantly being stalked by gargantuant shadowy beings that are seemingly always 3 steps behind you. Always on your heels. Always around the corner.The screen gets a weird loopy filter and its Amnesia all over again. "Runrunrunrunrun! OOOH FUUUUH-UUCK!" Sometimes escaping is easy, sometimes not so much as you bump your baby head into the upper part of a hidey hole and get eaten by a hellish nightmare.If you liked Amnesia but want something a little different, this is the game for you. Had a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ childhood? Want to relive the terror of said childhood? This is the game for you. New to horror? Want to try horror? This is the game for you. Want a cream pie on the outside, but on the inside its the heart of Chtulu? This is the game for you.Pros: Stunning atmospheric gameplay elements and music creating instant immersion. Simple control scheme that's easy to get used to. Pulse pounding horror as you run for your godamn life. Kinda casual. Best when played alone in your room with all the lights off. And no wall pressed against your back... Don't worry, daddy's comin'. Just don't look over your shoulder.Cons: Climbing and general mantling is a bit wonk and a bit hard to get used to. Perfect lighting is hard to balance because some areas are just so damn dark, which makes hiding a little tedious at times. Maybe a little too forgiving as each death starts you 15 feet from where you died with all of your previous inputs, that means everything- including enviornmental changes, still in play. Some puzzles are a little too ambiguous with what they want out of you. The answer is sitting right in front of your face, but that's the problem. Its sometimes a little too obvious. Sometimes a little too hidden. Either way it was an absolutely incredible game. If you have the money laying around I would suggest picking it up and giving it a go. If you have headphones you're in for a treat. Definitely one of my best, if second or third, horror experiences.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												 Among the Sleep is unlike anyother horror game I have ever played.  You really do feel like a baby. You're small slow, and completely defenseless in big forbodding world. Now... I am a horror veteran and this game admittedly managed to creep me out and put me on edge. I had to pause and tell myself "do it you big baby do it!" XD  I love some of the creative visusals in the game. Some places like your home look warm and welcomeing (at first) and other places like the playground look slightly surreal. The sound design is great espcially with headphones. I grew fond of Teddy and his friendly face. A baby and his teddy added a bit of charm and warmth to the other wise dark surroundings.  I have just few gripes with the game. WAY TOO SHORT. I am slow with puzzles, and I take my sweet time exploring. Yet I clocked in at 3 hours. Also while the ending did have twist that I didn't see coming the last chapter is rather anticlimatic.  Not that the ending is bad. I actually liked it. It just could have used a bit more oomph and though. Despite my two problems I really enjoyed this game. However... for being only 3 hours it's a bit hard to justify the price right now. Hopefully we will get some great DLC soon!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												Vulnerability is a long forgotten element in what made video gaming horror such a powerful thing.  But Among The Sleep has gone to great lengths not to forget this. It casts you into the role of a toddler, turns out the lights, and asks you to explore the shadows.  Vulnerability is effortlessly achieved when the character you control can barely walk on its own. Wobbling along on uncertain feet leads your first person view to bobble from side to side as you advance. Keep it up for too long, and you’ll fall onto your hands and knees where you’ll crawl instead at a much brisker pace. Tilt your view enough to see yourself, and you glance tiny grasping hands, and a body clad in a dark blue onesie with a star and moon print. Pause the game, and the static options menu is brought up only after the infant has covered their eyes with their little hands. It’s occasionally adorable. It’s always, always nerve-racking. There’s something out there in the dark -- how are you supposed to fend it off?Full review // http://www.honestgamers.com/12295/miscellaneous/among-the-sleep/review.html

												Among The Sleep manages to be both scary and original. No cheap jump scares here. The story is actually very interesting and the gameplay is original and new. Playing from a toddler's point of view is definitely an interesting experience not seen before. The asking price is too high compared to the game's length so I highly recommend waiting for a sale. Still, I recommend getting this game for its uniqueness and originality. Very Good!  7.5/10

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												I bought this game shortly after spotting a post by someone who stated that they were extremely moved by this game and could personally relate to it as they were currently going through similar circumstances. Not realizing that this game 'could' be based on a true story I decided to give it a gander.Let me first start off with saying that if you are able to relate to the things this kid goes through, then I feel extremely sorry for you, knowing that your just a couple of steps away from blending in with the Addams family. I would also like to state that I will try my hardest not to ruin any surprises in this game as the game has very 'little' to 'no' replay-ability value.After playing most games I ask myself, 'Am i a better person now for having played it?', more often than not the answer is 'no!' In fact some times its even 'I am worse for having played it'. Not so with this game. In fact I left the game having a better appreciation for certain things than when I entered into it. Here's the beauty of the game and where the game shines. Basically your paying for the experience you get from having played this game and it's concept of making you view life from another perspective, that being said ... a 2 yr old.Here's where I began to appreciate things more. I began to appreciate how dangerous life is for a 2 yr old, a small puddle is something I can potentially drown in and a drawer in the kitchen is a ladder I can use to get to that toaster which could easily burn my face off.That being said, the main enemy in the game is a handful of monsters and the main one being a cross breed between a clump of seaweed, a Triffid and a stick of Broccoli drawn by Timothy Burton. The game has nothing to do with the supernatural, however you do know that with the need of avoiding monsters and finding memories, something must be wrong somewhere.The biggest downfall to the game is the controls, they were hardly precise and often felt awkward. For instance the hand icon to show you could interact with an object often appeared even if you were not close enough to 'really' interact with it and the designated controls on a controller for walk or crawl are the same ones needed to rotate handles. Hence instead of rotating you often would spend five minutes not being able to make up your mind if you wanted to walk or crawl on a handle. Granted you can customize controls, but i'm lazy and my idea of going outside is to turn on supermario 64 and get my character to look up into the nice blue sky. Also with the monsters always snapping at your baby feet, every millisecond reaction counts and if an icon appears to say you can interact with something, but you really can't because your not close enough, well it just heightens a players frustration level as they're spine begins to tickle the tonsils of the 'satanic evil brocolli'.There are a couple of ways to avoid the monsters. 1) Hide under beds or in confined cupboards 2) Hug teddy so hard you snap it's neck 3) Soil your pants and hopefully the smell will send the monster away. Unfortunately options like lay a couple proximity mines down are not in the game.The developers have really gone into quite extensive detail with the game which often gets missed by the players. For instance the mother has a pale skin impression on one of her fingers where a wedding ring would have been. All the books and covers in the game seem to have Japanese writing on them, this is because to a 2 yr old everything would look Japanese would it not?I would also like to point out that the developers have a 'credit fetish'. Seriously! The longest credits I have ever seen in a game. After the game finished I felt sorry and took my mum out to lunch, when we got back the credits were still rolling. The best part is, I later discovered that those credits were just a prequel to the real credits. After finishing the game you get to play some DLC and then treated to even more credits. Seriously the credits are so long that even the seasons change and winter steps in.The game will take you 5 hrs at the max. Most of that will be spent watching credits. There are very few games in the market which force you to think in the shoes of someone else and maybe we need more games like this so that we become more conscientious, tolerant and sympathetic . I really do recommend the game, it's worth the experience, but that experience is not worth $20.00 which is the normal price. Wait for it to go on sale. By the way my mum tried to make me eat broccoli soup once and it did feel a lot like what was going on in the swamp in this game. So yes you could say it's based on a true story...Addams family here I come!

												one thing to keep in mind: as all previous reviewers have said, this game is a shorter one.despite this, i would definitely recommend itit's fun and interesting, especially the concept. a lot of the scare aspect comes from you: you're a toddler, exploring the big, bad world. it will be dark. things will move around. you'll have no idea what's following you.a lot of it is the atmosphere; being a toddler, of course the world is scary. it sounds like a monster is constantly at your tail, whether it be a breath, a shift, a scuffle; turn, and there's nothing there. or is there?it starts off so happy, so care-free; your mother baking you a cake, big smile. has it really been two years?as time passes, however, things just aren't as they seem....if the price tag and game length haven't scared you off, i would definitely recommend giving this bad boy a spin

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												If you're a fan of horror games this is worth playing.  You play as a 2 yr old and venture through a dream world, or should I say nightmare world.  The game starts out a little slow and seems more like a "baby simulator" but shortly after things pick up it gets creepy!  This horror adventure game does have its scares and environmental chill but it's not the scariest game out there.  In my opinion it's perfect for those who are trying to ease into the horror genre or just don't want anything too extreme.  But this game shouldn't be dismissed.  Like the other best horror games you can't fight the thing chasing you, all you can do is run and hide.  With a first person view and dark environments Among the Sleep gives you a feeling of being a child all alone.  There are items to find on you're way and places to hide.  If you want a creepy adventure this game is a must.Pros:+Graphics (not the best but still very good)+First-person view+Scares and environment+Not boringCons:-Sometimes climbing is finicky-The game is a bit short-The ending was anticlimactic

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												They nailed the atmosphere on this one, and the story is really good.  The toddler movement mechanics were a nice touch as well; I kept getting frustrated when I would run and fall down, but it wasn't frustration at the game... it was the frustration of walking around as a cumbersome 2 year old.There were only a few drawbacks.  The graphics are dated, but I didn't really notice.  Also, the game is a bit short for how much it costs (maybe a couple of hours long), but it was still a very satisfying experience.I played this game both in the middle of the night and during the day, and on both occasions I was sufficiently freaked out.  Excellent job on this one.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												Among the Sleep is a freshly distinct title to the PC gaming franchise, which leads up to why I give it its 9 points.For an indie game, it's is almost one of the best of its kind. One thing being the good 3D graphics, despite the texture quality being a little bit on the low side, losing its 1 point. The game play keeps you on the edge of your seat as a baby having to deal with its mom disappearing due to a metaphorical storyline, making you ponder about all the possibilities. Leading to a climactic ending to which no one could have expected! The puzzles may be simplistic, but only adds to the realism that the main protagonist's mind is still developing as a young baby. Can't say that the game itself is very long, but it's a game you can play over and over and not get tired of the grim storyline and climactic events.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												Among the Sleep Review -NO SPOILERS!-(except for the part about the footie pajamas)Among the Sleep is a unique game that is played in the innocent eyes of a young child. I enjoyed this game - not only because of the horror element, which was very well done - but also because it told a valuable and emotional story with only a few words. In the minds of toddlers, many things and situations that happen in their lives sometimes don’t make sense. This game did a great job “translating” what was really happening into something that a toddler would see and understand. Moreover, it was absolutely terrifying. Many things make this game unique and different from most other first person games. First of all, the only way to transport yourself is toddling or crawling-which can make running away from certain death quite tense at times. Second, you play only two feet from the ground making everything around huge and curious. Third, you can see your body if you look down! You’re not a floating head bobbing around! Also, the baby footie pajamas are very nice. There will never be a dull moment when this incredible game is played and it may or may not make one speechless for a few days. I recommend it for anyone who is looking for a clean and eerie game that has good morals and lessons to be learned - including not making a single noise. There is one thing all must know when playing this: don’t break a bottle.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												8'110 backers. $248'358 pledged out of $200'000 goal. Delayed 5 months.All of that for 119 minutes of not even actual gameplay, since Steam counted the time I spent in the settings.Among The Sleep is a huge disapointment. Not only delivering 2 mere hours of entertainment after so much hype and tease is Ubisoft-level ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥gery, but the game itself doesn't make it up for it.Animations are stiff and clunky, lots of graphic bugs and glitches, textures are low res, particle effects are cheap, audio samples are butchered, the very few objectives present are basic, the maps couldn't be more linear...One can see the good ideas Krillbite had. The environments are detailed, the layouts carefully crafted to make you feel oppresed and vulnerable to the darkness. But because the whole game is poorly realised, it just doesn't work. Instead of tension, you feel boredom. Instead of fear, annoyance. And worst: Instead of compassion, the only though that crosses your mind is "Thank God it's over".Clearly Krillbite failed to deliver what the trailer and the demo promised. And after all the means and time they had, I have a hard time understanding how.I do not recommend Among The Sleep because I wouldn't recommend any $18 game that would only last 2 hours, but if one day you can catch it for free or, let's say, a couple of bucks, going through ATS might be worth the (very short) time to explore the mechanics Krillbite intended to use, and the original take on survival horror that made ATS so appealing in the first place.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												Among the Sleep proves that even indie devs are capable of hyping up a two hour walking simulation with poor sound and barely any scares. Perhaps you all saw that Kickstarter video where it seemed like a stealth game with high amounts of interactivity in its environment with a dense sense of climbable objects and places to hide? Well, guess what. It's not. In fact, nothing is particularly done well here. Any "horror" done in this game consists of only 10 mins of game time hiding from a swamp monster and a coat. Which was all done better in Penumbra and Amnesia anyway. Because even IN THIS GAME any sense of challenge flies out the window when you even the game over screen and are sent RIGHT BACK to a checkpoint with all progress still in. As in any items you got or objects moved etc. are still in the same place. There's no real puzzles. Not a single moment that sticks out. Everything was already done BETTER in other horror games. Even the innovation of being a two year old child falls flat on its face with terrible execution.The sound effects are particularly dreadful. The quality ranges from well done to something from a DOS game. You'll get random whistle noises that cut off abruptly. Monster sound effects that sound like they came out of a really bad TMNT cartoon, bottles that sound like bell chimes, and even no sound effects at all! REALLY! You can drop soap and you won't even hear a single thud!As far as the story goes. It's the bare ♥♥♥♥ing minimum for being "subtle". A child is being taken away from a drunk parent? It's not like this was easily foreshadowed by the swamp monster 30 minutes in the game. The characters never develop. The incredibly forgettable teddy bear doesn't have a personality. Yet the game tries its hardest to make you FEEL bad for him later. Which you won't feel anything at all because he was merely around to babysit the player and destroy whatever atmosphere the game had.The visuals are pretty nice I guess. Each section in the game has its own sense of aesthetics and the scale of being a two year old toddler is well replicated.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												It's a game that demands that you put your head and heart in the game. If you play it with the head and heart of an adult, the smoke and mirrors will not fool you. It demands that you role-play it and if you do, it rewards you with a great sureal and eerie nightmare. It reminds a bit of Pan's Labryinth. If there is one issue I have with the game, it's that the ending could have escalated the drama a bit. It's not that much that is needed, just some extra dialogue to end at a higher note.

content:
Posted: April 6
												If there were a neutral rating... I'd be on the fence between it and positive.  4 out of 5 as it were.First, I love the concept.  The crawling vs toddling mechanic worked very well.  And the first part of the game (the bit you see in the demo) before you (minor spoiler) leave the house is creepy as (smurf).  The end bit is also, creepy on an amazing scale.  Unfortunately, once you leave the house for the more fantastical areas outside...  it looses a lot of the creep factor.  I think the lessened familiarity lessenes the horror effect.  At least it did for me.    So, awesome beginning and end... less impressive middle bit.  (Though it was still good.)  Sadly, the middle bit is the larger portion of the game so...I do put in a recomendation for this.  (With minor reservations.)
