number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												So I just finished Among the Sleep, and I have to say it's one of the best explorational games I've ever played. To call it a horror is up to the player. Since there's a flowing narrative and not many survival elements, I think calling it a psychological drama would be more fitting.When I came into the game I was pleasantly surprised at how much detail had gone into the world (after my controls decided to work), and really enjoyed the cartoonish art style. The character models could have been better but that's a minor nitpick.Something else I noticed was the lack of deep sentiment in the early stages, and felt somewhat let down. However upon completing the game I realised what this all amassed to and why it seemed so by-the-books. I won't spoil anything but the moments leading up to the game's incredible ending are genuinely enthralling and some of the best I've ever experienced in gaming.I think the game's ~2 hour length is perfect, as it allows for an incredibly streamlined experience. None of the game feels like filler. I am however disappointed at the slightly disgusting price of £15. Yes, it is an incredible experience, but for 2 hours of gameplay I would never pay more than maybe £8. Of course I made an exception for this as I've been waiting a long time for its release.In conclusion, if you're looking for a PewDiePie-esque jumpscare fest then I really couldn't recommend this game to you. This game's horror comes from its subject matter and subtlely disturbing imagery. If you're a big fan of explorational games (Dear Esther, Amnesia: AMFP) then I highly recommend it, although I'd wait for a steam sale if I were you.Graphics: 8/10 (Incredible art style let down by occasional bugs and performance issues)Sound: 7/10 (Fittingly cheesy voice acting, and good ambient effects, however playing through I can see they missed a few solid opportunities for a good audio scare)Gameplay: 9/10 (If you like explorational games then this is basically flawless as far as walking around goes. If you don't, its minimalistic mechanics may leave you bored)Overall: 8/10

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Among the Sleep is an indie horror game that  was originally released as a demo way back in 2012 or so,and then got an official release on Steam in 2014(this version).I tried it out since it looked really cool after seeing a lot of other people play it,and I can say I will never regret playing it :)The plot: You play as a 2 year old toddler,with a teddy bear as a birthday present(and as a light source in the game).  You have to go around finding these items called"memories",uncovering the truth about your mother in the process.The gameplay is really interesting because instead of taking the POV of a normal horror protagonist(say,an adult or teen),it takes place in the POV of a 2 year old toddler.You get a teddy bear as flashlight in the game,which helps with some low-light sections throughout.The characters are pretty good,the mother especially because of the creepy things you find out about her(just what tho I won't spoil)The voice acting is well done as well.The horror aspects of the game are VERY well done,and managed to scare me more than once(keeping in mind I tend to be brave when playing horror games).The game is kind of buggy,but that hardly takes away from the value of the game. The game doesn't take too long to complete on your first playthrough(it should take you 2-4 hours or so on average),but everything that's good about the game makes up for that for the most part.9.5/10 from me :)

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												No spoilers to follow:I have a difficult time recommending this game.  I will break it down into the things it does well and things it missed this mark on.Pros:The gameplay design is great.  You are faster while crawling, but are also at certain disadvantages for doing so.The design of the environments is also well done which includes sound design!  The locations felt important and palpable.Cons:I have to mention length first.  It takes under three hours to beat, and while that alone does not make me hesitant to recommend the game, it does not help.The story is full of foreshadowing which is good, but does so in a way that makes everything incredibly predictable.  The story  exists only to allow for the game to take place.The scariness of the game is incredibly subjective, but I did not feel scared with the exception of one area of the game.  I will not spoil what makes me say this because that would ruin the fear that this game attempts to make you feel.  If you are observant, you will not be scared.I played this game without an Occulus Rift which may be part of my lack of enthusiasm, but it does seem more like a tech demo for this device in its length and environments.  When the price drops on it, it may be worth it.  Twenty dollars seems high for a couple hours of scenery.  I also want to point out that the demo includes the best portion of the game since it occurs before the supernatural/dreamy location.  While some may appreciate the supernatural areas more so (and I agree that it allows for the game to become less predictable as it deviates from reality), I felt that it loses a large part of the empathy required to feel fear.

content:
Posted: January 18
												    It's a good game, despite my not recommeding it, but $15 USD for a 2 hour experience is a little steep. I beat the entire game in about two hours, and that's with getting lost twice. If you can get it on sale, I would highly recommend it, as the story is worth experiencing. Don't ruin this one by watching a Let's Play.    It does a good job being suspenceful, but after the first 20 or so minutes, I didn't really feel any danger anymore, and all those sound effects just started to give me a headache. By the time I finally saw the enemy walk past my hiding spot, I lost all suspense. Once I started to peice together the narritive, I spent the latter part of the game more sad than afraid, which I guess is what the developers were aiming for.   Screeching and jumpscares aside, the puzzles were actually pretty entertaining, albeit easy. Your biggest problem is going to be seeing where you're going. Like I mentioned previously, I got lost twice because of how pitch black the game gets at times. The game gives you a teddy bear that casts a little illumination, but it blocks half the screen, and completely obscures it if you happen to look down.   All things considered, the game is absolutely brilliant, but the price tag is what keeps me from recommending it.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												This game is a little disappointing. From some let's play footage or trailers you might think it's "Amnesia" meets "Rugrats."  It's unfortunately not. Calling this a horror game is... generous. Atmospheric to be sure, but a horror game it is not. And it's a damn shame too, as there are plenty of elements that would have made this a perfect mixture of scary and creative.Elements such as pulling out shelves and chairs to reach destinations or hide; a teddy bear that glows to comfort you, but lures monsters; or a running mechanic that makes you trip because you are only 2 years old. Hells yeah I'm all about it.However, this is all meaningless as you will have a total of 2, maybe 3, encounters with a monster. It's mostly you just crawling around with a light source you'll rarely need, finding treasure and looking at beautiful environments. The developers look like they put a lot of effort into the maps, and it looks like they had more planned for the game play with plenty of places to hide.  Unfortunately, most are a pointless decoration.Also, I saw the story coming a mile away. Maybe that's the point? But crawling around Manor de Grand Mariner to find out your mom is a turd burglar wasn't all that impressive to me.At the end of the day you get a 2 hour, semi-pretentious, game that's overpriced at $20 dollars. 6/10 worth a buy if you buy it on sale.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!This is a first person Horror game.Interface/Menu/SettingsThere is a master volume slidebar available with %.There is an effect volume slidebar available with %.There is a music volume slidebar available with %.There is an ambient volume slidebar available with %.There are some resolution sizes available.You are able to change the controls on the keyboard.Able to toggle the subtitles.There is a chapter selection.Most of the languages are available for the game. If not All,You can play this game with the xbox controller.About the game.You are playing as a baby that is able to crawl and walk. This baby as probaly the most strongest legs on the world because i was falling off from tables/drawers from a decent height and he didn't even get a single scratch! Your best friend is a teddy, who gives light. (So basically a glow in the dark teddy bear) What i really like about the game aswell is that you have to move an object (like drawers or doors) Into the direction like they should be opening, so if u have to push them to the right, you have to control your buttons into the right direction, same goes rotating valve, You have to rotate valves my moving the control into that direction(so making circles)I have to say that this horror "childish" game is very well done :DI like the atmosphere and the shadow effects in the game.There are collectables.The camera angles are nicely done when being moved by someone.The game does try to scare you with big giant jackets/coats.This baby is also probaly the most smartest baby on the planet.however the animations are sometimes weird.THE GAME IS QUITE SHORT.Other things.Teddy is sometimes very quiet, even on some locations that he should be talking.This baby will probaly be "superman" later.This is the strongest baby too. HE CAN MOVE OBJECTS LIKE CHAIRS AND WOODEN BOXES ALL BY HIMSELF!-------------------I Give this game a 9/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												I played for over 3 hours so far and I don't see it ending during the following hour. If someone is running forward like a fool he has only himself to blame if the game ended 'too soon' for him.I love how the game eased on players after some time (I even started whining that it's not Amnesia-scary anymore) just to go after the player after soon enough. Made me swollow my prior words :) If you like horror and 'outside-the-box' games, buy it!What can I add after finishing the game? Around the half I started getting afraid that it would turn into yet another 'collect 3 puzzles to unlock all 3 passages and off you go' kind of game. Fortunately I was wrong. It eased on that to focus on psyche later on. All in all a great thrill ride! It took me over 5 hours to finish the game (without getting lost).The only cons I've found are poor quality assets from time to time. Sub-par models and textures in the outdoor levels, some missing sounds (from interactive objects) and terribly looped sounds (washing machine). Lack of positional audio (binaural, HRTF etc.) is also a downside.Graphics: 8/10Audio: 7/10Overall: 8.5/10Prologue DLC comments:This is obviously meant as a small update. Also, the in the following notes I'm unable to distinguish vs improvements made in the DLC itself and improvements to the entire game introduced with the updates released after I've finished the original game.+ better music, MUCH more dark and tense+ new reaction of the toddler to danger+ it seemed to me that textures quality were better than in the original game- there's little of challenge- the gameplay feels a bit like a mini-game rather than a short story-driven gameplay

If not All,You can play this game with the xbox controller.About the game.You are playing as a baby that is able to crawl and walk. This baby as probaly the most strongest legs on the world because i was falling off from tables/drawers from a decent height and he didn't even get a single scratch! Your best friend is a teddy, who gives light. (So basically a glow in the dark teddy bear) What i really like about the game aswell is that you have to move an object (like drawers or doors) Into the direction like they should be opening, so if u have to push them to the right, you have to control your buttons into the right direction, same goes rotating valve, You have to rotate valves my moving the control into that direction(so making circles)I have to say that this horror "childish" game is very well done :DI like the atmosphere and the shadow effects in the game.There are collectables.The camera angles are nicely done when being moved by someone.The game does try to scare you with big giant jackets/coats.This baby is also probaly the most smartest baby on the planet.however the animations are sometimes weird.THE GAME IS QUITE SHORT.Other things.Teddy is sometimes very quiet, even on some locations that he should be talking.This baby will probaly be "superman" later.This is the strongest baby too. HE CAN MOVE OBJECTS LIKE CHAIRS AND WOODEN BOXES ALL BY HIMSELF!-------------------I Give this game a 9/10

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												It's a decent game. It's got a pretty nice and whimsical atmosphere. Having a toddler as a protagonist is a fresh idea for a horror game. So why the thumbs down?Among the Sleep starts out in a creepy way, but in the end it's not really that scary apart from one or two jump scares. There's hardly any challenge and hardly anything to hide from. Honestly, the scariest thing in this game is probably the baby itself. The story tries to wrap everything up into a profound twist, but I thought that the result was lame and prententious. The game has potential, but it just feels bland and repetitive. There aren't any real puzzles either, unless knocking down a bottle from a shelf constitutes as a puzzle. The most fun I had was arranging alphabet toy blocks into obscene words...

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												EDIT: I endured the lag through the last chapter only to be met with a short an disappointing ending. The game was incredibly short (2 hours tops if you don't have the lag), levels laughably easy, and there is no consiquences if you were to fail (I jumped off a ledge and 'died' simply to see what would happen... big surprise. Nothing). It is still bizarre why I lag only on chapter four whereas any other part of the game plays smoothly and on high res graphics. This game simply isn't the horror experiance you think it is.  I'm sticking with my 2/10 rating. Though the concept held so much potential and the graphics not being too shabby; the bugs/lags, disappointing gameplay is what really killed it for me. If you happen to have the $20 to blow and an hour or two to spare, then this is the game for you. Otherwise, just go watch Pewdiepie play it.~The Proxie Kid

												小熊应该是已经和妈妈离婚的爸爸送来的，妈妈因为一些悲伤的事酗酒，迁怒于爸爸送来的小熊，小孩子的世界幻真幻假，将一些事情加以想象和联想，也就成了游戏中的 世界，会保护自己的小熊，在一个奇异的世界寻找和妈妈过去的回忆。酗酒后妈妈化作了魔鬼，可怜的小熊也被撕坏了。天亮了，妈妈的心魔消散了吗？宝宝会留下心理阴影吗？善待自己的，身边的孩子，莫让你的冲动，成了孩子童年的阴影。 The teddy bear was supposed to be sent by dad, who probably has been divorced with mama. Due to some terrible experiences, mom had a night time drinking and anger with the teddy given by dad. For children's world, it mix real and fake by imagination. In the world of 'mine'(the kid),teddy led and protected me, mom became a devil. Poor teddy was be destoryed by her. It's daytime now, does everything really be solved? What about mom and kid? Their mind, their lives will be changed. Do something good with the kids. Do not provide them any psychological shadow in their   childhood. 9/10

content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												I purchased this game in January 2015 because the store page said "VR Support". The game did not actually have VR Support, this was "in development". So I waited. On Sept 22, 2015 VR Support was cancelled. Four days later the store page still says VR Support.This is like advertising a game to work on PC and Mac, buying it and finding out it doesn't actually work on PC yet. But it's coming... so you wait... then PC support is cancelled... too late to return it to Steam so you end up with a useless game.If you advertise VR on the store page the game should already be VR. I'm sure some people will enjoy the game but I'll never know beyond the 7 minutes I tried to get VR to work.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												[MILD SPOILERS]Great ideas executed fairly poorly. The first 20 minutes are really good and drew me into the game completely. The intro with your mother, the teddy and the lead-in to the wardrobe world were great.However, finicky climbing, not being sure if I can fit under things and ultimately not really being able to decipher the rules of the scares make the game a bit of a trudge. It gets really repetitive, even in the short period of time you actually have with the game. The story unfolds itself well and you end up having a good sense of what it has been trying to convey to you, but ends by just slapping you with it, just in case you hadn't figured it out on your own yet.It started you off with something great and ultimately goes nowhere with it. The DLC is very much the same, it gives you something really interesting, gets repetitive and goes nowhere.I wouldn't recommend this at its base price, it's far too short for that. Pick it up on sale if you're curious or give it a miss completely, I'm pretty indifferent to the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												If you enjoy stories where the plot isn't spoon fed to you, then this can be a great game. It's interesting to draw parelles and understand what the meaning of everything in the game is. As you play you can see how a toddler might see his world in the way that this one does. Things that aren't really dangerous can seem very scary to a child not old enough to understand what's what.That said, the game is short, but maybe that's for the better. The gameplay itself does not stand on its own apart from the story, and I found it to start becoming tedious towards the end. I got the game (and others) for $5 from Humble Bundle, and I think it was well worth that purchase, though I don't think I'd want to pay much more than that. All in all, a good way to burn 2 or 3 hours in a lazy afternoon.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												Update: I did a second playthrough for the new achievements they added, to find 10 drawings in each level of the game including the prologue. They made a few changes since I last played it in 2014.The changes I only noticed was at the finale so they'll be in a spoiler tag.The voices during the finale spoken by the mother under the spotlights were unaudioable, I couldn't make out her words in hearing as the caption would suggest. Same goes for the, assuming, father that greets the child. Eventually his voice become difficult to hear. Not sure if it's a hardware issue, a glitch, or the game itself as my computer wasn't able to handle Among the Sleep very well but decent enough to play at least.Half way Review. (2 hours)Some say this is short and overhyped... I'd say "When is this going to be over?! And where is my mommy!?"Seriously, in a body of a helpless 2 year old, looking for his mother, wondering through a child's imagination nightmare, you begin to wonder what is around that corner, behind the door, or through the window. It may become clear what the creatures represent, but still has you wondering what is happening next.Finished Review. (4 hours)Again I ask, to those saying it's short, how can you possibly make it longer? While it may feel that it should've been longer, it really couldn't.This is a game I waited since the demo. I loved the demo. I wish I could've helped with the KS campaign, but couldn't risk sending any funds due to job unsecurity. That's my only regret about this game, not being a backer.Getting this game as a gift, and playing through it... worth the wait. Absolutely worth the wait. I refused to see any playthroughs of this game until after I played it. And I'm glad I did.The sense of danger and paranoia as a toddler, looking for his mother and the memories. You may think you know what's about, but you may be wrong.Spoilers from here.DLC Review (+ <1 hour)Now I'm a bit more confused with the story, the father was abusive to the mother, in turn the mother become child abusive and a drunk, and the child went into foster care or back to the father? While this does explain what happened between the two parents to be seperated in the first place... it makes the main game story confusing for me... was there something I missed?-----Check out more games I see that deserve more attention from my curator group:BluePaw's Underrated Games ListJoin and/or follow if you wish.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												Potential spoilers and plenty of opinions following the first paragraph.An incredible concept that just did not pan out. The visuals are decent, the sounds are genuinely incredible but the gameplay and story just aren't there. Gameplay is very typical for a first person horror-adventure game, in line with the recent first person horror-adventure games Amnesia and Outlast. You walk, you run, you crouch (excuse me, crawl), you hide and you pick up objects as needed. The hiding mechanic isn't necessary for a majority of the game. Nothing new except in this scenario you're an infant. I do not recommend this game at $19.99 at all. I paid much less and still would not recommend the game just generally unless you're really convinced you'll like it.The game is never really scary and most of the time I felt as if the antagonist was actually helping by conveniently guiding me through opening doors, creating footsteps, etc. The fact that you are an infant did not change anything for me unfortunately. This could be due to the fact that the game is in first person and I didn't feel immersed. I don't think first person works well for this type of game... you're playing a predefined character that is not developed in any way. In Halo, you get Master Chief, a very memorable character built through dialogue and cutscenes. In Skyrim, you're roleplaying a character that is not predefined by the story but by the player. This idea doesn't hold up for every game but doesn't help with this one.Another problem I had was that I often missed what was going on during visual moments. I had no idea things went flying in the kitchen, I feel like I missed things when the lightning flashed in the house. I would just hear these sound cues and look around and not see anything. I guess I was playing wrong during these moments.The story begins holding your hand in the first few minutes and continues to pull you closer like a protective parent. Just to make sure you completely understand the story, we're going to treat you like a child and keep you completely aware of what you're doing and what is going on at all times. There's no thrill or mystery and if you understand what's going on very early in the game it's hard to be fearful of anything to come.I did not enjoy this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												If I was going to recommend this game to anyone, it would be to a two year old who has grasped the basic concept of mouse + keyboard controls. This game is incredibly short, it took me 1 1/2 half hours and for that time I felt that there was so much potential that wasn't being properly utilized. Never did I feel threatened or challenged only mildly disappointed with how mediocre the monsters looked and behaved. For example, one spotted me and as I dashed towards a small hole to hide in, it came charging up behind me, caught up to me and did...nothing. This happened a second time when a trenchcoat with beady eyes swooped down at me, then sort of floated there vibrating before disappearing. The best part of Among the Sleep is the concept and the scariest part is revealed at the beginning when your mother looks at you with what some of us would call a face and others would call terror.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Unique concept for the game, kind of destroyed by somewhat frustrating gameplay. You're a 2 years old kid looking for your mother in a creepy, empty house. Sounds interesting? It is, besides few things that hinder the gameplay for me. Your best way of moving around is crawling. You can't do anything in this position (using your bear as a flashlight, interact with the most important objects in the game) and if you want to get up it takes like a full second to animation to let you move again. You can't run too far, because you're a baby, so you end up tripping and crawling after 2 meters anyway. The game is too dark, so you cant see♥♥♥♥♥♥ unless you activate your bear as a flashlight. This is helpful but you're moving two times slower (a common snail is Usain Bolt compared to you in this regard). The biggest nail to the coffin though is that it's just another corridor game. The puzzles are boring, controls are responding with slight delay, the overall experience is just not that worthwhile.It's not the worst game ever, but I can't recommend it with clear conscience.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												Short and excellent. Top drawer story that satisfies, however it leaves you wishing for a longer experience. First person view from a two year olds perspective. Simple intuitive controls. You are a baby searching for his mommy. Persued through threatening landscapes by towering monsters. You stealth crawl your way to the memories you pushed from your mind. With the help of your courageous teddy and tenacious persistence, you will triumph. This is how games should be! I love it!

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												Great story, absolutely tedious gameplay with crippled controls. The final "boss" was a great concept on paper (muh symbolism), but it was badly done to the point I didn't even realize it was happening. Story made me cry, if you care.However, it's too short to warrant the 20 dollar-ish price. Good thing I got it for free. Wait for a Steam Sale where it's at around 5 bucks.All complaints about length aside, at least it's not Gone Home.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Ugh!While you have to admire the amazing graphics and atmosphere this game has, it's just not fun to play. I get tired of walking (and crawling) around trying to find where the next key is. For someone like me who is directionally impaired it gets really annoying. The entire time I'm playing this my brain is like "Can we please stop now. This is boring. I'm tired of pushing the directional pad trying to figure out where to go."I quit at the part where if you spend too much time trying to figure out where to go a monster jumps out and kills you. I'm just like NOOOO! Stop killing me and just let me get the Hell out of here so I can finish this stupid game!I hear it has a great ending but I may never get that far. I just can't take it. The gameplay is just too awful and boring.And the story is not great. It's just slightly more sophisticated than Super Mario Bros. The only difference is instead of trying to save a princess, you're trying to find out what happened to your mother. It's an exploration game with surreal landscapes that has little to no story.  Just an objective and an ending.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												Wonderful sound design and good use of lighting. There are many little touches that make this a good experience. The child's drawing representing each area and scene work well. IF you're paying attention and analyze the game, you will most likely figure out the outcome to a degree. I thought the full reveal at the end was quite powerful. It's good to see games tackling bigger subject matter as this does. You really get a view of a complex situation from the view of small child. The game only has about 2 hours of gameplay, at this price-point it probably should have been longer. But as a support of indie games and ones that deal with different and important subject matter, it was definitely worth playing.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												I was pretty disappointed by Among the Sleep. Given the reviews and recommendations I expected a solid, story-driven first-person puzzle game a la Master Reboot. It is a fist-person puzzle game, but there's no story and it's just not good.Even though I finished the game in two hours it felt slow. Moving is slow, getting around the world is slow. The controls and interface are clunky, and the viewport is at a weird, warped angle, which just makes things feel worse. Even on extreme settings the graphics are sub-par. And the puzzles themselves are nothing to write home about.This game is an experiment whose success hinges on all of its aspects coming together to form a unique, interesting experience. But despite the contrived situation and player persona, it is neither interesting nor unique. The game doesn't bring anything new to the table.What's there feels like a quickly slapped together tech demo for a game, not something polished or completed....and the achievements are broken on Linux.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												The only thing keeping this game from a perfect score is the length... it IS a short game with nothing to invite the player to try again. No diverging paths, or unlockable items. But it is exactly the way that ATS gets away from video game conventions that makes you love it. You wouldn't think a game with no violence and a toddler for a protagonist could scare you, but I found myself sitting on the cliche edge-of-my-seat both playing and watching. Pricey for the limited run length, but well worth the money for me. My roommates and I had a blast, laughing at each other and screaming at turns, and I have paid many times this price for games that didn't manage to do HALF that.  A solid 8 out of 10 that could've been a ten at about twice the length. Worth a run through, and making me eager to see what else the creators come up with.

content:

												Before I review this game I have to be honest...I LOVE playing horror games and really enjoy the feeling of being put in a situation where the only thing you can really do is hide with no way to fight back. I would be so daring to even say that I have become slightly immune to some of the horror games out there.Now that being said, I have played both the demo and finished the full game with much enjoyment. The scary atmosphere of the game is new and exciting and I love the concept that the game brings with it. To be honest though I did not find it as scary as other people seem to mention it being, but the story is FANTASTIC.I was completely emerged and loved absolutely every minute of the game including the way the story won't stop your brain from trying to interpret what the "true" meaning is behind the story.Unfortunately that feeling of exitement only lasted about 80min until the point where I had beaten the entire game.So do I think it is a great game? Yes I do.Do I think it is worth the 18 euro I paid for it? No I do not.All in all I think it is a game that SHOULD be played but you should wait til it is on sale...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												First of all I would like to say, if you ever see this game on sale, pick it up, no question.Among the sleep is one of those games, comparable to journey, where the actual gameplay tends to step aside for the atmosphere and the meaning of the game. Though this game is a "horror" game, it dosen't feel too much like one, mostly puzzles and an errie enviroment to boot. On top of that the game is quite easy, you could probably go through it without dying once (which I could say on your first playthrough would be quite hard to do, as juding what places you are and aren't allowed to drop to are a bit odd). Mostly what you'll be doing in this is solving several easy puzzles and once in a while hiding from a monster that only appears in a few parts of the game, which I would have to say is my biggest complaint. Many people talk about the length of the game, but to me, the game felt as long as it needed to be (besides the kinda abrupt ending that felt like it was a tad lazy). One thing I will say though, is keeping in mind that the game is easy, you should explore the levels, look at the drawings. The levels have all these extra areas to explore, not to artificially add to the length, but to discover and add to the game. Overall the game is great, if you see it on a sale, pick it up no question. If you are looking for a game that is going to hit your feels and stick with you for a while after, and don't mind the $20 USD price tag, this might be what you're looking for.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												Among the Sleep is short, but sweet. It's an interesting experience, absolutely dripping with atmosphere. Playing as a toddler in a scary world, and knowing you're defenseless, is a very eye-opening and unique experience. All of this is brought together to tell an interesting and troubling story from the eyes of someone who doesn't understand the world.I'm not typically a fan of horror games, but this one just seemed so unique that I had to Kickstart it, and the final product does not disappoint.A few warnings to make sure you know what you're buying:1. Among the Sleep is really short - you can finish it and get 100% achievements in less than three hours, and it doesn't have any replay value unless you want to revisit the exact same experience months or years down the road.2. I ran into a few bugs in my short time with the game (version 1.01). Most of these were small graphical glitches that almost added to the surreal experience, but one actually prevented me from progressing. I spent twenty minutes or so trying to figure out how I was supposed to move forward before finally looking it up and seeing that I had encountered a bug. There is an in-game option to go to the last checkpoint, which I was able to use to fix this while only replaying about three minutes of the game, so it wasn't too bad, but the game is still in an early stage where you might hit a problem now and again.3. I've seen at least one person in the forum complain that this brought up bad memories from their childhood. Presumably the subject matter advertised for the game should be enough to let you know if this will be a problem. It's a horror game where you play as a two year old, so keep that in mind if you have childhood trauma that could resurface.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												Oh my... I just finished the game. The ending had me in shock like wow. My heart was broken. Anyways, this is such a beautiful game, the graphics werw wonderful and the sound was so ominous and amazing. It starts out as just creepy but after about an hour it gets so scary. I actually yelled in fear a few times lol. When you get far into the game you will understand i had PURE anxiety until it ended and i was so relieved. TIPS *NEVER turn around after you get a little far in the game... someone or should i say something may be there to greet you ;)* STAYYY away from water!!, DONT jump into dark pits you just die lolol. I have to say Among the sleep is one of the most interesting games i have played.  I think its so cool to be playing from a babies point of view and seeing through his eyes. You learn how children see things from their POV and how everything affects them. You start off in the kitchen,, then get sent to your bedroom and thats when it gets pretty crazy. Its creepy for an hour but just wait it gets insane after that. The graphics are awesome and when you travel around and discover new places its really trippy & cool. I think i would give this game a 9/10. I think its worth the buy but i would wait till its on sale just because its so short i beat it in 3 hours. But i have to say this game is really creepy and its alot of fun. Overall great game and i totally reccomend.

Posted: April 13
												If you've thoroughly enjoyed games like Amnesia or Slender or any other survival horror game, then I'm sure you'll appreciate Among the Sleep. However, what sets this game apart from the others (for me at least) is the story and perspective of a child. I won't ruin it for you with spoilers and others have summarized the story already, but the ending reminded me of an M. Night Shayamalan plot twist. A nice bonus is the ease of getting 100% completion of the achievements.Although I did really enjoy this game, I would not recommend paying full price for it. I finished the game with all collectables and achievements in under 3.5 hours, and that's after replaying a chapter or two. There is very minimal exploration besides the drawings and the game is extremely linear.Oh, and why is the prologue at the end of the game!?

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												First of all I would like to say, if you ever see this game on sale, pick it up, no question.Among the sleep is one of those games, comparable to journey, where the actual gameplay tends to step aside for the atmosphere and the meaning of the game. Though this game is a "horror" game, it dosen't feel too much like one, mostly puzzles and an errie enviroment to boot. On top of that the game is quite easy, you could probably go through it without dying once (which I could say on your first playthrough would be quite hard to do, as juding what places you are and aren't allowed to drop to are a bit odd). Mostly what you'll be doing in this is solving several easy puzzles and once in a while hiding from a monster that only appears in a few parts of the game, which I would have to say is my biggest complaint. Many people talk about the length of the game, but to me, the game felt as long as it needed to be (besides the kinda abrupt ending that felt like it was a tad lazy). One thing I will say though, is keeping in mind that the game is easy, you should explore the levels, look at the drawings. The levels have all these extra areas to explore, not to artificially add to the length, but to discover and add to the game. Overall the game is great, if you see it on a sale, pick it up no question. If you are looking for a game that is going to hit your feels and stick with you for a while after, and don't mind the $20 USD price tag, this might be what you're looking for.

Posted: February 1, 2015
												The ordinary world can seem fantastic and frightening through the eyes of a child. In Among The Sleep, you take the role of a toddler awakened in the night by strange occurances, and you must explore the world, solving puzzles and avoiding what lurks in the darkness to get to the bottom of these phenomena.Among the Sleep, with its somewhat short story (it should take less than three hours to get through the game from beginning to end), should appeal to casual gamers. However, even hard-core gamers can get a thrill from its atmosphere.

Posted: March 30, 2016
												Among the Sleep, in my opinon, was a great game; Depending on the person you are your either going to like it or hate it. The game was short i beat it in about an hour and a half. Also the game wasnt necessarally "scary" it was more suspensful. Unlike most games this isnt a direct jumpscare game except maybe once. The game is suspensful because everything happens on a pattern. If you figure it out you know whats coming. For example: level three when I bumped into a bottle I knew it was time to go. That is the unsettling feel that I found great in this game. One thing in this game that may be a huge factor for people not liking it is the prolouge. Its kind of streched out a little mre than it needs to be but the developers made up for it with the strong symblic ending.Storyline:10/10Gameplay:7/10Controls:6/10(the doors can be annoying sometimes trying to open)Reccomendation: Buy during sale.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												SPOILERS FOLLOWthe atmosphere in this game is top notch. amazing sound track, visuals, and puzzles that all inspire feelings of suspense and terror. A frightening and compelling nightmare world, made all the moreso by the fact that you play a two year old child. that said, I felt like the twist in the end wasn't well realized. I was sure that things were going a certain way because, in my view, the entire game was setting you up to believe in a certain scenario. when it turned out otherwise it didn't have the impact it could have, because there is exactly zero foreshadowing in the beginning of the game. all of the foreshadowing portends the scenario I thought was going to take place, but didn't. frankly sometimes I think games nowadays try to shoe horn these twists in because it's the thing to do, but (and I felt this a little with The Vanishing of Ethan Carter) it would have been just as good if not better if played straight.Some gameplay quibbles include how damn difficult it is to turn anything with the mouse.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												A heavily atmospheric and dream-like game from the unusual perspective of a toddler. The elements of saturated colors, artistically created environments, and lush soundtrack are well harmonized for a unique experience. If you're tired of stereotypical horror games, this is something fresh.PROS* The visual design is striking. The bright colors and dark shadows play over strangely distorted landscapes. The child's perspective makes even common objects like swings or coats huge and menacing. This is a visual experience that will not soon be forgotten.* The atmosphere is enhanced by the soundscape. There are bumps in the night, rumbling drones, and a haunting melody being hummed far off.* Without spoiling anything, the subject matter is interesting and well paced.* The voice acting of the teddy bear is another high point, being playful and surreal without becoming corny.* This is a very imaginative experience. It felt like reading a storybook, in a similar vein as the movie The Babadook.CONS* The game is extremely linear. It almost felt like a straight line going through each area.* When the monsters are introduced, it detracts greatly from the experience for me. The nightmarish environment lets your imagination run wild, so when the game becomes a hide-and-seek horror trope, the experience suffers.* The monsters become constant by the end. Less really would have been more, both for scares and for letting the environment keep the spotlight.* There's no story. There is a *situation* which you come to understand throughout the game. I feel that if the game developers were going to tackle this subject, there really should have been more depth given to both the "villain" and to the situation. Instead, the treatment feels shallow and even insensitive.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												[Updated with a positive review now I can actually finish the game]I feel I can now recommend this game. Whilst it's a little clunky and can be beaten in just a couple of hours, it more than makes up for that by sheer force of concept.If the idea has been tried before then I haven't seen it. A horror game told from the point of view of a 2-year old. Genius! They find things scary that we don't, and so you end up in a world which heavily blurs the line between reality and imagination. Ever thought innocent objects made scary shadows in the middle of the night? Well, here they do!The level design is very well crafted and you rarely find yourself wandering round in circles looking for something to do. It's a little linear in places, but you feel more like you're being guided in the right direction rather than simply being on rails.However, it's taken six months since release for me to be able to actually play the game as it's been absolutely infested with bugs. One showstopping glitch made it impossible for me to even complete the first chapter, hence the negative review I originally posted here. I still have minor bugs including achievements not working, but at least the game is now completable for me. If it works for you, it's a fascinating original game. Try the demo first to see if it works for you. As one of the original Kickstarter backers it's made me wary about pledging towards the developer's next project though...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												Among the Sleep is a prime example of why horror is my favorite video game genre. The story is great, the monster encounters are exciting, unbearably tense, and are actually challenging unlike Amnesia The Dark Descent. Above all, Among the Sleep is incredibly creative and, despite its dark atmosphere, is very sentimental and succeeds in making the player feel like a little kid again.PROLOGUE DLC REVIEW:Among the Sleep comes with free DLC, which is a prologue which adds about an hour of gameplay mean to be played after the main campaign. Prologue is a skillfully designed addition to Among the Sleep and makes itself stand out from the campaign in several ways:- A chilling winter atmosphere, which is refreshingly different - Improved puzzles which require more thought to solve than what was seen in the campaign - Thoroughly creepy dolls to collect Prologue also expands upon the campaign's story, although since it's a prequel there is sadly no Teddy to keep you company. Prologue is actually very similar to Penumbra: Requiem, a mission pack/sequel to Penumbra: Black Plague. In Requiem there are no monsters to encounter, only environmental hazards and puzzles to solve. Prologue's only fault is that is pointlessly throws in a new monster which is a complete joke and takes the player out of their immersion. Considering that is all Prologue does wrong and the many other things it does right, it is a great bit of free DLC. Give it a go if you've played the campaign.

												If you've thoroughly enjoyed games like Amnesia or Slender or any other survival horror game, then I'm sure you'll appreciate Among the Sleep. However, what sets this game apart from the others (for me at least) is the story and perspective of a child. I won't ruin it for you with spoilers and others have summarized the story already, but the ending reminded me of an M. Night Shayamalan plot twist. A nice bonus is the ease of getting 100% completion of the achievements.Although I did really enjoy this game, I would not recommend paying full price for it. I finished the game with all collectables and achievements in under 3.5 hours, and that's after replaying a chapter or two. There is very minimal exploration besides the drawings and the game is extremely linear.Oh, and why is the prologue at the end of the game!?

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												[Updated with a positive review now I can actually finish the game]I feel I can now recommend this game. Whilst it's a little clunky and can be beaten in just a couple of hours, it more than makes up for that by sheer force of concept.If the idea has been tried before then I haven't seen it. A horror game told from the point of view of a 2-year old. Genius! They find things scary that we don't, and so you end up in a world which heavily blurs the line between reality and imagination. Ever thought innocent objects made scary shadows in the middle of the night? Well, here they do!The level design is very well crafted and you rarely find yourself wandering round in circles looking for something to do. It's a little linear in places, but you feel more like you're being guided in the right direction rather than simply being on rails.However, it's taken six months since release for me to be able to actually play the game as it's been absolutely infested with bugs. One showstopping glitch made it impossible for me to even complete the first chapter, hence the negative review I originally posted here. I still have minor bugs including achievements not working, but at least the game is now completable for me. If it works for you, it's a fascinating original game. Try the demo first to see if it works for you. As one of the original Kickstarter backers it's made me wary about pledging towards the developer's next project though...

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
Please note that this is an in depth review and whilst I have tried to not give any spoilers to the game, reading this review in it's entirety might give some of it away. If you do not wish for your playthrough to be spoiled at all, you may want to skip to the bottom once you've read the "Brief Synopsis" section.Brief Synopsis: Among the Sleep is a fairly short 1st person, on rails game. You play the part of an unnamed toddler who is accompanied by his best friend. While this game is on rails, it does allow to explore the game world quite a bit. The game is simple to play, yet provides a bit of a challenge by the way of puzzles and interactive items. The store page has horror as one of the tags for this game. I would categorise it along the lines of being "heart pounding inducing". There is no blood, no guts, no real violence, but it's still enough to get the heart rate up. Long Review: *The following may contain slight spoilers. Skip to the bottom if you don't want anything about the game spoiled for you*Story: In Among the Sleep, you play as a small toddler who wakes up in the middle of the night. Accompanied only by a teddy bear, you must brave the monster filled darkness to find the source of True Comfort - your mother. Graphics: The game is in 3D first person view and (I believe) is Oculus Rift supported (though you don't need it in order to play). The in world graphics have been beautifully rendered, with a lot of the items you find throughout the game interactable, allowing you to pick up, throw, push, and pull almost everything in the game. Well, everything that a one year old would be able to handle that is. Music/Sounds: Another huge plus for this game is its haunting music and sound effects. They're really well done, to the point where I cringed every time I accidentally broke glass objects while exploring the world. Length: Among the Sleep is not very long at all. Saying that, the plot is done so well that it doesn't need to be long. Indeed, my opinion is if the game was any longer, it would actually be to the games detriment. You don't always need a game to last for hours on end. Often, short and sweet drives the point of the story home more than long and drawn out ever could.Replayability: Unless you want to go for 100% achievements or want to speed run the game after leisurely playing it through the first time, there really isn't any replayability to this game. Overall, Among the Sleep is a short game with a really deep story. I highly recommend this game for that alone. The superb graphics and unforgetable music are just icing on cake, really.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												I was pretty neutral but on the negative side of this game. First I didnt really find it scary at all, and I've always found myself to pretty susceptible to tht sort of thing. It really felt like the developers wanted you to play this game in VR cuz that deffinately would have added to it. Next the visuals were pretty shotty. I dont have the best computer, but things were clipping in and out of each other all the time. This made the game hard to get into. On the brighter side the atmosphere is great. The story is good too. Dispite issuses I had with the gameplay I found myself drawn to finish the story. Unlike a lot of other horror games where you have to go around and read everything in order to get the plot, this game doesnt do that. It does a good job with visual clues to help you figure everything out; building to the final reveal. The last negative would be the play time. I finished the game in just under four hours which was a little shorter than it should have been. There are a few collectables hidden thoughout the game to go back and look for, but seeing as how they arnt anything but incohesive crayon drawings there is no real reason. Conclusion: at five bucks on sale it is hard to say no, but unless you can get this thing to work with a VR headset I say you might want to look around a bit more first

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												As horror games go, with this one I am unimpressed. Decent atmosphere but overall dull material.Pros:1. Good atmosphere with great visuals and sound effects2. The storyline is sort of intriguing3. The free DLC, the Prologue, was cool4. Unique perspectiveCons:1. The storyline, although intriguing, was overall dull and disappointing2. Just wasn't interactive enough3. Not creepy enough for the horror genre4. (Now this is just nitpicking) The 2-year old in the game does not reflect a real-life 2-year old.When you find a horror game "not creepy enough" it's kind of hard to recommend it. If there was a fun mechanic about it or a really cool storyline then maybe this could be overlooked. However, that is not the case here with Among the Sleep. Overall, the material felt dull and underwhelming. If they were to make a new game along the lines of the free DLC, the Prologue, then I could probably get on the "recommended" wagon. There are better horror experiences to be had elsewhere. Quite a disappointment, this one!

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Bought it on sale, but honestly it wasn't really worth the time or money I spent. Not scary at all, not creepy at all and they used no method to force the player to actually care about what happens. You basically just run around just to fall down and crawl and then stand up again all the time. Hardly any game mechanics to speak of, it's just one of those games you can play in around two hours, but if you could actually walk without falling down all the time and move a bit smoother, it would take around 30minutes to run through this game(yeah, I know it's meant to be like this, you're a baby after all, just putting it out there that it's short with almost no content). I like to look around and find items or funny things, but there is hardly anything of that either, just a few childrens paintings to pick up. Extremely easy, not even once did I have to stop and think "what should I do to proceed?", everything was obvious and you just picked up everything you needed on the way forward. The only good thing is that I didn't notice any real bugs, it flows on fairly well. But no real story to speak of whatsoever.If you're really, really, really, REALLY bored and can get this on a sale and you have nothing else to do whatsoever, give this a try and it might help you burn 2-3 hours. I guess it gives what it says it does, you're a baby with super problem solving powers(for a toddler) crawling through a house while seeing illusions created by an infants mind, and I guess it could be considered somewhat creepy, but it's not scary in any way, every time a monster showed up I just ignored it and went on my merry way, when the monsters finally started chasing after you, everything you had to do was hide under a table or something, and usually you didn't even have to care even then as you could just crawl to your goal without minding the "monster", as it hardly aimed at you anyway, while disappearing in just a few seconds. I respect the idea of this game, but I just found it really boring in the end, there is absolutely nothing to keep you hooked and care what happens, as there is really nothing much that happens anyway, way too linear, you just walk through everything and solve a few ridiculously simple puzzles that are so obvious that a toddler could realize what to do instantly. Do yourself a favour and find something else to play, please, anything is better than this, read a book, watch a movie, play another game, this is absolutely not worth your money nor your time, unless you're into linear games with a screwed up atmosphere and no story where you just mindlessly charge through. Even if you get it for free, just play something else and let this game rot in your library, it's way slower than it should have been with the content given, just a waste of time. I have a feeling that most of the people that upvoted this is either one of those people that are "neutral" and thinks it's neither good nor extremely bad and therefore went for thumbs up, or the guys that are total pansies and get scared when they hear cracking in their house, or the people that upvoted it for being "acceptable for the price" or maybe those that didn't like it but thought that it was better than some other games. If this was a free game, I might upvote it due to similar reasons, but even 1 dollar/euro is too much for this.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												So I finished the game and I have to say, although it wasn't as scary as I was expecting, it was creepy enough to give me a few chills.  I loved seeing the world through a childs eyes and the little details were really cool, like the "spooky world" was just the baby's imagination interacting with the house, the key on the baby stairs gate for example, everything was significant to building up a story of this child, the drawings of sad child and grumpy monster etc.I loved the level with the bottles all over the place that could fall and break, you really got a feeling of panic that how angry mummy would be if you made even the slightest noise etc, at least that's the impression I got.It was also really refreshing to have this sad situation where for once it isn't the stereotype drunken father routine, I really liked that.One thing though I would liked to have seen better use off was Teddy.  Although he serves as a kind of "flash light" mechanic, you can literally play through the entire game having never used him if you want to.  It would have been really cool if there was some sort of "upset" meter or something that would have you needing to cuddle him to stop the baby from crying or something and attracting the "monster"  it would also have been good that if after an encounter when the screen goes all crazy because you're scared that you need to cuddle teddy to reset that.  Basically I just felt that teddy wasn't used enough which is a shame.The game should have been longer for the price asked... I paid £8.99 and that was with a 40% discount, and while I don't feel that I have been ripped off, I certainly wish the game was a good bit longer... I kind of feel that we were only really starting to encounter threats when the game started to come to an end.Would very much like to see more of this, hopefully some additional content will come from dlc or a sequel, but either way I would recommend to give this a try.  It's a fresh take on the horror fps genre and it's cute scary and funI'd give Among the sleep 7/10 lossing a little score for its price to duration ratio.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												This is a strange title. First off, the asking price (20$) is entirely too high. As a group, we tried twice to get into this, and just couldn't. Its an interesting idea, but in the end it can be boiled down to basically a walking simulator where you 'find the key' and 'find the door' deal.Pros:+Fresh idea+Makes you feel like a small child+Graphics are decentCons:-Waaayyyyy too high of an asking price-The game takes some seriously weird turns. I thought the whole game took place in the house, but it doesn't. You go down like this garbage shoot and enter another world, which is really strange, and I didn't like it.-Basis of the gameplay is too simple. You basically just walk through the levels trying to open doors and trigger events. Its not terrible - its just bland and has been done a million times before. At this point (and for this price) I would have liked to see some novelty. Something fresh.-While the graphics are nice, there is some parts that odd. Maybe they were done because you are a small child, but I don't think so. Like as an example, you walk by a couch that is entirely too big in comparison to the rest of the room (lamp, coffee table, etc.). It just felt flawed. Or shoes that seemed too big. If it was for the child experience, fine, but I don't think that is the case.I would definately pass on this one. There are other similiar games that are better (and far cheaper). I paid 10 bucks and have buyers remorse.

												You play this game through the eyes of a lovable 2 year old aided by his adorable teddy, but not everything is child's play. 


YouTube™ Video: Among The Sleep Episode 1 | Hold Me Teddy, You Creepy Toy! 

			Views: 15		

			This is an neat little horror game that's been out for a while now, but it was suggested to me to play through it. In this episodes... stuff gets weird fast!		

This is a 'First Person' Horror game and the atmosphere generated is so good, it will make you're skin crawl with terror and adventure. Compared to a lot of these cheap looking 'shovel them out quick' horror games popping up everywhere, in comparison this feels like a AAA game. Yes, you will be afraid, and yes you will be very afraid. I have to admit I jumped a lot.... and that was during the day... I can't imagine playing this in the dead of night....... Superb game!

content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
 "Among the Sleep? More like "Among the Trash!"  ~Oscar Wilde Among the Trash Is where this game belongs. It's an interesting concept, but the story has a dumb, predictable twist, and the game is so full of bugs and glitches that it's hard to even get immersed. It's possible the developers may have patched it since I last played it, but is it too much to ask that your two hour walking simulator at least works properly on release?Let me paint you a picture: There's a game with three characters, and a monster. There are several clues that the monster is supposed to be a metaphor for someone, so logically it'd have to be one of the characters. Is it:A: The protagonistB: The character that never leaves the protagonist's sideorC: A character who is absent for 95% of the gameHmm, I wonder who will be revealed to be secretly a terrible human being in the shoehorned in twist ending?It's another "great idea ruined by hack writers" scenario. I'm disappointed. Oh well, into the trash it goes.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Interesting premise - greatly underperforming -  worth maybe 25% of current full priceAtmosphere: 6/10Gameplay: 3/10Story: 4/10Content/Price: 4/10Graphics: 4/10Being very different from conventional mystery/scary backgrounds, the setting of this game was catching my attention. Sadly, the game remains an empty shell, lacking variety/difficulty/surprise, and therefore is barely able to excite. Thus, I don't recommend buying this game for the current full price of 15/20/20  £/€/$. If anyone, people who are interested in the setting should wait for a HumbeBundle deal and try their luck.Just some of my impressions:- the atmosphere is OK but remains severely behind the full potential of the premise- the few scary moments aren't really scary and seem very artificial (and the "shock" effect is really ugly)- the story can be summed up in a sentence and is nothing special. Nonetheless, towards the end I found myself thinking "OK I'd like to know what happened now", but the ending is rather disappointing- game mechanics seem promising in the beginning but soon slide into tedium - very short play-through time of ~2,5h with no replay value whatsoever- experienced a few glitches, clipping and texture errors

content:
Posted: January 8
												It is sort of like a survival horror game, even though half of the game is just horror and no survival part (unless you fall into the void). It looks beautiful and it is worked out quite well, except for one major flaw: The game wipes your progress in a level completely when you quit the game. Within the levels you have checkpoints and the game pretends to "auto save", but this is just as long as you do not stop playing it. It will simply punish you for stopping. Given the fact that the game has only about 5 levels it basically wipes up to 20% of your progress.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												Among The Sleep is an atmospheric, puzzling game that plays like a horror game but is technically an atmosphere test in disguise. Finally a studio that creates horror that decided to take a frickin' break from all the blood, gore and overexcessive monster designs. Now we have a monster that is completely black, hides in shadows, and each form of it rumored to be the child's parents. I'd favor to talk about each aspect of the game and what it does well.THE STORY: 60% 6/10To be honest I didn't like the story, because it didn't make any sense. Also it was too abbrieviated and ended way too fast. It would be nice to have a couple more levels according to the little video at the end of the ATS demo. Those in my opinion looked way nicer and refined. Also if you were to add the missing levels as DLC I would screech, that would be nice. So basically the story is you are a two year old child who goes to sleep one night only to be awoken by some noises and a supposed paranormal being. It is only until you  find out your mother is missing  and see the first monster you know things are wrong. You take your teddy bear and venture through three stages *Five technically throughout the entire game*. It's... a nice concept but as I said. It doesn't make sense and it's too brief. At least explain in the game how this happened!THE LEVEL DESIGN: 100% (Solid 10/10)The level design is ABSOLUTELY GORGEOUS! I seriously love every single part of it and it's entirety. It kept my one, colorful eye on the screen and it's like a replacement for the story. The story is low brow but the graphics are the highlight of this game. Every single level is amazing and beautiful. It's odd how something so spooky can be such eye candy at the same time. The level design even reminded me of myself since when I was younger I had odd, strange dreams from time to time that resembled this game, and after I saw Among The Sleep's level design I flipped my♥♥♥♥♥♥and went totally crazy over this game. I'm even working on a game similiar to this that will be created on Unity, *Fun fact, Among The Sleep was also made on Unity*THE CHARACTERS 90% (9/10)Now there aren't many characters in Among The Sleep. *If you don't count the monsters, I'm not counting them since they've got no personalities and just want to capture you*, pretty much we have the child themself, the child's mother, Teddy, and the supposed father of the child which we can get traces of in the introduction of the mother in the first chapter. I'll talk about the mother first. The mother is the supposed main antagonist (due to her connection with the odd tree monster in the fourth act) By the end she seems to be a redeemed villain and still loves the main protagonist. Now we should talk about Teddy. He is one of the main protagonist alongside the child and he helps them manuever through the nightmarish parts of his dreams. The ending which involved Teddy is very creative and I love his character.CONCLUSION:Among The Sleep is a great horror game to play at night due to the buildup and spook the game brings. I recommend this game, it gets a 9/10!Have a nice day.

			Views: 0		



IntroAmong The Sleep is a first person horror adventure Indie game developed and published by Krillbite Studios for PC, MAC, Linux and PS4. Krillbite Studios is a Norwegian games Developer who has received over $300,000 Euro or ($500,000 USD) in total donations from The Norwegian Film Institute and from crowd funding..Was their money well spent..StoryIn this adventure you play as a 2 year old child on his birthday, when a stranger knocks on the door… to give you a present. the identity of this person is hidden from the player.Shortly after this event your mum decides its time for you to play with your new gift, the teddy bear, so she takes you upstairs.While going upstairs, the game is quick to kick in the creepy factor by making a wall of darkness follow you as the developer overlays there intro into this section.I won’t tell you anything else beyond this point as it will ruin it for you.Although I wouldn’t call Among the Sleep a horror game but it is still incredibly creepy and presents horror in a new light, more on that shortly.This is essentially the prologue and basic knowledge about Among The Sleep, but it doesn’t really give you to much because I don’t want to give the story away. Any more story elements I lay out for you will completely destroy the story for you.GameplayThe gameplay consists of basic aspects such as crawling, running, object throwing and simple puzzles.The walking animation is by far the best thing in this game :)All jokes aside, the gameplay is simple yet fun and this is probably one of the first horror games with a defenceless protagonist that actually makes sense…. GraphicsThe visuals in Among the Sleep were impressive for an indie game running on the Unity engine, unlike most Unity based games there wasn’t any motion blur that was over powering me while I played, this feature can get quite annoying so Im glad they opted out of that idea.There was one instance in the game were an object I needed to collect for progression didn’t actually fall down after hitting it sooo in order to continue I had to use a no clip console command to get it…Later the game crashed and luckily they had a checkpoint before as when the game reloaded I was able to collect the object correctly.Other than a few bugs here and there the game looked amazing and it really did feel like I was actually in this house, which for me made the experience that much more enjoyable.Sound DesignThe sound design in this game played an extremely important part, with ambient sound alone adding yet another layer of creepy to the environment which helped pull off a horror type experience.Some sounds that would appear to be scare sounds, weren’t scary at all but seemed placed there to keep you on your toes which I thought was a neat inclusion.Rather than trying to scare you constantly throughout the game, Krillbite decided to ease you into scares which if you havnt seen part 5 of my playthrough I would strongly recommend you go watch that, to get a real understanding as to what I am referring to.P.S. I nearly flew out of my chairVerdictAlthough there was a decent amount objects clipping through walls here and there… the core game didn’t get effected by this and the creepiness of this game grasped me in and made me want to understand what was going on in this world.Which for a horror game is a great step up from the rest… and well you’re a 2 year old with a talking teddy what more can you ask for.Bugs and issues aside, Among the Sleep was a solid indie game developed by Krillbite Studios and seeing as this is their first game… they didn’t do a whole lot wrong.That is why Among the Sleep gets an 8/10.

Posted: June 7, 2014
												I really, really wanted to like Among the Sleep. I mean, I kickstarted it, so clearly I was behind the idea.However, while I tried really hard to get myself into the mindset of this as an immersively spooky experience, it just kept drawing me out of the immersion by being buggy, repetetive, tedious, and did I mention buggy? Like... REALLY buggy.I finally, when it became clear that I was stuck at a point where the bugginess of the game was going to force me to have to replay a section for something like the fifth time, I just couldn't face another minute of it; The thought of relaunching the game was like a knot of bile rising in my gorge.First big complaint other than bugginess: No reasonable save function. I keep hearing developers make the same mistake over and over, saying that they know having a well-implemented save function is important to people and they always concur except their game is the one special snowflake where there is a compelling reason to not allow the player to arbitrarily save. You know what? No. There is never a good reason for that. Most of us have lives. The save points in this game are sometimes very far apart in time, and very tedious to get to. If you have to go get six McGuffins in a given region, the game will only save if you get all six and then find the exit to the next region. If you happen to be very busy or get interrupted frequently? I hope you like getting those first five McGuffins OVER and OVER and OVER and OVER again. Aside from that, this is a game that depends on you cutting it a lot of slack in return for a spooky atmosphere, and the tedium of the game kept pulling me out of that spooky atmosphere, whereupon all the things I'd been sort of forgiving -- sound effects that made no sense, terrible physics, terrible UI design, horrible movement mechanics, a lighting system that turns itself off at the drop of a hat so you're forced to re-enable it again ang again, instant-kill bad guys that can't always be avoided, bugs, etc. -- became hugely grating rather than things I could wave away. Ultimately, you can only forgive so much. This is a game I really wanted to love, but like that member of the family that just goes too far, there came a point where I had to just cut and run.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												The story is really solid and compelling, the pacing basically perfect, and the tension/horror is top notch. The environments are fairly linear but for the most part you don't really feel it - they're desined to make you think you're not really on a set path, and it works. Everything is designed to make you feel helpless and a little confused (just like real children ;) ). The only detraction is some of the physics can be a bit iffy, so it breaks the awesome atmosphere and immersion of the game. Between 2-4 hours of gameplay (depending on exploration and how tricky you find 1 or 2 of the puzzles). It was worth the price on sale ($15) for me, ymmv.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												This game is simply a must-have for any horror fan.The graphics of course are also very well done, which is not everything, but is a bonus to the atmosphere. I saw a few people complain that this game was too short. But again, the reasons listed above made up for it. Either way, you'd see that this is a game that shouldn't be made extremely long anyway. If it was made long, it would ruin it and then people would complain that it was too ''dragged on''Basically, if you like a good story line, good graphics, and an ending you won't expect, buy this game.

Posted: June 7, 2014
												The game was over just as I thought it would start. The opening sequence was well made. That was the best part of this game.Maybe 1-2 hours of gameplay. No replayability, not much in terms of horror. Useless lean-function. No puzzles other than picking up things and using them 10 seconds later in really obvious places, or climbing on top of things. If their target audience is 5-years old I imagine it could be a scary and adequately challenging game. To anyone else, it is a borefest. Follow the linear path through the various areas and try not to be bothered by all the reused props in the environments. Easily dodge the few poorly made antagonists. Yawn as nothing scary happens. Finish the game. Uninstall and never play again.NOT worth 20 eur. Go see a movie with a friend instead. More fun per second per money in that. Godzilla was pretty good.

Posted: June 2, 2014
												This game is absolutely amazing. The controls are tight, the music and ambient sound never let up, and the visuals really capture the feel of a world from a small child's perspective. And the story, without giving anything away, will disturb you and might even make you think.The controls feel very similar to Amnesia, at least in the sense of how you interact with the world. Opening doors and turning valves, picking up objects to throw, rotate, or carry, and using the bear as a flashlight will all feel very familiar to players that have braved the halls of Castle Brennenburg.The audio, in all its forms, is unrelenting. Even the lack of audio at times will fill you with such a sense of impending dread that you will slowly and cautiously navigate the surrounding. And sometimes even the slightest 'bang' or 'crash' will send you scurrying towards any safe haven, for fear of something coming up behind you.The visuals have such a grasp of a child's imagination it is uncanny. Words are as scribbles, sense a child cannot comprehend them, and drawings litter the worlds, as if a tiny person is giving you clues that you can easily understand without a spoken or written language. And the literal perspective of everything towering over you really draw on the feeling of helplessness in an unknown place, with only your teddy bear as comfort.Overall, this is a delightful horror gem. There is no reason to only catch it on a sale, for fear of it being underwhelming. If you enjoy horror games with thought, puzzles, and huge atmosphere, then 'Among the Sleep' is an absolute must have.
