Posted: June 15, 2014
												For modern horror games these days it's not about superstrong enemies but about unarmed and vulnerable players trying to survive in an oppressive and potentialy lethal situation. Among The Sleep takes this approach to a new and original level. You play as two year old child on the night of your birthday in what turns out to be a far more disturbing game than the cute intro scenes suggest. As a defenseless toddler wondering around a dark house, you have good incentive to stay out of harms way. But that's not the most uncomfortable thing about this. It's the familiarity of the situation. Aliens in spaceships and zombies in castles are scary, sure, but at least they're fictional stories that non of us have had to go through in real life. In this game though we have. We've all been toddlers, and we all know what it's like to be scared of dark rooms and the unfamiliar (which is most stuff at that time). As well as the halucination-like imaginations. It takes you right back to those early memories.You are accompanied through most of this by a talking Teddy that can light up and even walk around at times. He's no fighter though.When I first started playing it I thought it was going to be a ghost story along the lines of Poltergeist or Paranormal Activity. Overturned cot, strange sounds, doors opening by themselves, flickering TV and lightning. But the game takes a much stranger turn as the normal but dark house at night gives way to earie and disturbing Tim Burton-ish dreamscapes. The puzzles that need solving are simple enough. You are meant to be a two year old after all. But creeping around these strange yet weirdly familiar places trying to find the pieces is not.I soon realised it's no ghost story, but a journey through dreams, memories and metaphores. But lurking among this childs imaginative world is somthing real, right now and threatening. It's up to you to find out what it is.It's a relatively short game, but if you're looking for a game that gives you a fresh and emotionaly intense experience, it's well worth getting.

												So I am not a huge survival horror guy, I prefer co-op games.  When I first saw among the sleep I admit I was skeptical, but I have kids.  Because I have kids I never really undestood what it was like to be in an environment that was bigger than me, the concept behind it was beyond me.  So I figured I would try it out. You a baby, a 2 year old lovable little munchin who wants nothing more than to just be a baby.  Then the weird stuff starts to happen... Posted: June 29, 2014
												The horror feeling was nicely done, not only from a toddler's perspective was it scary. The blurry screen and the shaking and wow the sounds was really haunting. It was really well done.Of course since the game is basically you playing a two-year old there is of course a limit to what you can do. It's not an all-out horror story, it's a little kid being scared and altohugh with imagination one can think of quite some scary things, it had to be as close to realistic as possible, which I lvoed and it totally achieved.I loved every level, how the details for example the particular objects scattered throughout an eare, hinted at something that was going on in the real life, but it was invading the toddler's dreams. Also they did an excellent job on giving you a false sense of security/safety in the beginning.Anyway, it was a joy to play. A simple yet invigorating to play through and excellent work on showing how real life things can affect everyone. Loved the twist and loved Teddy! So if you like horror games but are a bit of a scarecat or if you're simply looking for a quick enjoyable experience to pass the time, definitely try this one. It's got it all.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												Among the Sleep is not your typical horror game. It is a bit short, but not as short as the 1 hour playtime that I've seen others give. I'd say it's a solid 2-3 hour game, a little more if you explore the environment (which you should). It's got a beautiful, touching story that reveals itself gradually. The environments you travel through are varied and very rich, with minimal texture reusing, which is unusual and refreshing in an indie game. The atmosphere is perfect and creepy, but not chock full of jump scares. The first parts of the game will lull you into a false sense of security. To say anything more would be a spoiler.There's no incentive to replay unless you missed a Steam achievement, and this game isn't really made for replays because the story will have been revealed. However, I think the first experience was solid enough and unique enough to stand on its own. I got it for $15.99 and thought it was well worth the price because it seems much higher quality than other indie games and I am very interested to see what else the developers can do. I highly recommend it!

Posted: June 9, 2014
												Great, terrifying game. From a design perspective, choosing to make the main character a baby is brilliant. It's like the hopless feeling you get when playing Amnesia, but dramatically increased. Speaking of Amnesia, the gameplay will be very familiar to veterans. Walk around (sometimes crawl), move things, pick things up. Pieces of the story are subtly told through childish drawings found in various locations. It's enough to be able to accurately predict what's really going on, yet it isn't stated plainly, giving you a sense of accomplishment. The jump scares were usually done on my own accord, like making the baby breathe harder after running, or knocking something over. The ambience, as well as the creeping fear that something unstoppable is following you, sets the stage for you to scare yourself. And then, when you laugh at yourself, something intentionally terrifying happens, and you go change your underwear.For those that care, the graphics are decent. Average to low poly models, relatively low resolution textures, but they get the job done. They are readable enough that you can tell a key from a doorknob, which is all it really needs. You won't have much time to focus on the scenery, or if you do, adjusting your view will make you realize that something was focusing back at you.

Posted: August 1, 2014
												In Among the Sleep, by Krillbite Studio, you will take on the role of a 2 year old child who just had his birthday. You are eating cake in the arms of your mom when there is a knock at the door. This is followed by an argument, and then your mom coming back in with a present. You then fast forward to around bedtime/nap time, I'm not really sure which. It is then that the game takes on a nightmarish overlay.The visual look of this game felt like it fit with the character being a 2 year old. I'm not saying that it was rainbows and puppies, but there were those softer colors, even when everything was dark. The levels of this game were beyond creepy, especially for me because I have an almost 2 year old, so I could see myself in his shoes. There is a slight terror to knowing that something bad could happen right out of the corner of your eye. The levels span from a deserted play ground, a library in a forest, small sections of your house, and more. There are villains that creep around as well. All I have to say is you are going to need to hide from them, or you will suffer a restart of the section you are in. I also really enjoyed the companion, the teddy bear that helped me along. All I had to do was hug it and he would produce a little bit of light that would help me see through the darkness.The sounds in this game are extremely creepy. Once again it was doubley so because I have a young son, and hearing those noises creep around in a dark area would scare the pants off me at that age. I also think the voice acting in this game was spot on. I could see the roles of the mother and the teddy bear in the voices given.The controls of the game are your usual configuration with WASD, shift to run, ctrl to crawl or get up, space to climb, and the mouse to control the camera and interact with objects.Though this game wasn't as long as I would have hoped, it definitely had enough there to keep me on my toes, and hoping that nothing was going to get me around the next corner. There is just something about this game that awakened long gone fears of my childhood, and the fear of what is in the dark. In this respect the developers did a great job. To be honest I can't really think of anything I found clunky or missing from this game. I will tell you this, the twist is a hell of one, and I'm not going to tell you what it is because you need to play this game to find out, but when the game ends everything kind of makes better sense.There were definitely puzzle aspects to this game, most of the time it was moving objects so that you could get to a different location, but there were a couple of times where the developers threw in a mechanism just for a small section of the game that changed things up a little. A couple examples of this would be throwing objects to knock something off a shelf, or collecting a specific type of object so that you could weigh down the end of something so you could get to the other side. I'm not saying that this was a bad thing, but I would have liked to see a little bit more of these mechanics, to do them once and then seeming to throw them away made me feel like they were afterthoughts in the game creation process.So lets get down to the part that most of you want to know, and that is should you play this game. The answer is yes, you should play this game, and you should play it in the dark, at night, and pray that no one sneaks up behind you while you are playing. This game gets an 8.9 out of 10.

Posted: July 31, 2014
												This is probably the first Survival Horror game that hit me on a psychological level. Delivering you into the body of a two year old child, you must navigate the dark and disturbing world of a troubled mind and uncover the mysterious dissappearence of your mother. Alongside you a teddy bear named "Teddy" aids you in your journey often keeping you comfort when you need it. The game sets up an interesting premise but falls short at making you feel more vulnerable as a child as opposed to any other horror game. The true feat here is how large and menacing the environments are and the illusion that every object in the game world is either falling on you or trying to pull you in. Quite often in places you dont want to go. That combined with the chilling ambient sound make for a very unnerving atmosphere. The story is well written and completely out of left field. Please buy if you consider yourself a fan of this genre.

												This game really immerses you into a nightmare. With a crisp soundtrack and a colourful visuals, you feel like you're in a constant state of horror. SPOILER:The plot of the game was very unclear to me at first, but I suppose they meant to do that for the ending sums everything up in about a minute. Coming to the understanding that the mother herself is the actual antagonist and a drunk, you find that it was your father who was at the door and that he is the boy's safe-haven. The father is the one who gifts the teddy bear to you, and once you realize that, you see why there is a heavy emotional bond between the bear and the boy.There's a deep moral message to this game, and it makes you think rather than just play a game.

Posted: June 5, 2014
												'Among the Sleep' is an indie first-person horror adventure game on Steam, about the thirtieth to come out since Amnesia: The Dark Descent became wildly popular and everyone started pumping out crappy copycats like half-bred mutts at a puppy mill. Regardless of how tired I am of seeing 'of Horror' or 'Lovecraft' or 'Dark' being added on to a bunch of half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥titles, Among the Sleep caught my eye as a birthday game release and after reading the concept, decided to take a chance on it.The game's protagonist is a two-year old boy living with his single mother, and apart from thudding heartbeats and occasional toddleresque grunts of fear or exertion it's no surprise that the main character follows the Gordon Freeman camp of protagonist dialogue. This makes perfect sense, given little Gordy's age, but in order to give voice to the character's emotions and the player's observations, a birthday-gift Teddy bear takes on the Alyx Vance role as vocal sidekick, though whether he's 'magic' or just an imagined sidekick is left up to the player.It might not be immediately appealing to read that the main character is a toddler. It sounds gimmicky and hard to pull off, and I'm sure it was. But Krillbite Studios took the challenge seriously; the mechanics, story, and aesthetic all embrace this concept wholly and do it well.The gameplay matches the controls and concept; most of your challenges involve simple scavenger hunting, or moving objects around to climb on to reach other areas. This doesn't really get boring, because the game isn't very long. There are some wheel-crankings and such, but the puzzles are simple to work out and it's clear that Krillbite are more interested in seeing you enjoy the aesthetic and atmosphere than they want to stump you with a real brain-teaser. I mean for God's sake, you're a two-year-old; the puzzles aren't going to throw you for a serious loop. The environments are haphazard and nutty without being confusing or messy; the nighttime dreamscapes of an infant made playable. The art style itself isn't groundbreaking or super high-def, but they're clearly creating workable, playable, surreal environments that avoid the clutter-crap-style that some other horror indies I've played attain (cough, Anna).The triumph of Among the Sleep's style is that the environments start feeling consistently tense and foreboding because of how close and immense they feel in comparison to you. Again, they're really embracing the concept of little Gordy being a small, frightened child alone in a large, frightening world. The wooded areas feel like a 3-D rendition of Limbo with the level of character helplessness you'd expect to find while playing Slender.Among the Sleep is a horror game that offers a new twist on the gameplay and does it well from every angle. It has a pretty short playtime but also never drags on. The story ends pretty abruptly and the little details and hints are never made entirely clear, but the game ends with a pretty big emotional punch to the gut.

Posted: June 6, 2014
												This one is a little difficult for me to go with a YES or NO. Some points I want to make.I've been seeing this compared to Outlast & Amnesia. Cut it out. The similarities end with it being "horror" genre, and the only option you have when facing trouble is run or hide. Positives ++Eerie scenery. (what kinda got me to check it out,it looked at first that it would have an American McGee's Wonderland feel)+Loved the visuals+Cool soundtrack.+Plenty noises and things that would terrify a toddler, amped up to make it spooky.+Pretty imaginative. Remember back on  the things that scared you as a child... well, yea, a lot of that. Negatives --Far too short. I even spent some time exploring the levels. Soaking in the scenery. Managed to finish around 2 hours. -Took awhile for me to learn any repercussions in the game. The Teddy would suggest being quiet, and I just would go about my business. Even chased a monster down in the woods before it disappeared trying to see if anything would happen. Wasn't until it caught me later near the end of the game, that I learned the monster does infact interact with you. -Very simplistic puzzles. (which I get it, you're a baby.)- How you're expecting the story to end, it pretty much does.-Just wasn't really ever that scared. I think knowing that I was a child, and that harm to a child in any game is pretty much taboo... I felt basically invincible the entire time. (at one point in time, to sate my curiosity, I did drown myself. lol. but just the thought that no real danger would come to me, created a "Star power" mentality.)Side notes-Lots of foreshadowing. Pay attention to things said earlier on, drawings on paper and chalked on the walls. You'll know where the story is heading. If you ever saw the 1995 movie, Tales from the Hood, the similarity between the two makes it very hard to not see the metaphor the game implies.But, it was very cool for an indie game. However in my opinion, 19.99 is sorta steep for what is offered with this game. If you can get it on sale, do it. I am looking forward to see what the developers come up with the future.

												I'm gonna go out on a limb here and say that Among the Sleep is perhaps creepier than the original Amnesia to myself.Why?Well we've all been there.  Seeing a place in the daytime only to return during the nocturnal hour and see that what was once a bright and cheery place is now something dark and twisted.  Shadows creep along walls that once held happy portraits and floorboards creeking now signify the arrival of another eldritch horror coming to drag us off to hell.Among the Sleep captures this feeling and does it very well.But I can't just say good things, no I have two complaints.  1. The game is horrifically short.  How short?  I beat it in about two hours.  Was it a good two hours?  You bet your♥♥♥♥♥  2. The ending...well the ending is pretty easy to figure out. Posted: June 3, 2014
												Short, but sweet, this is almost your typical first person horror game, except there's a twist: you're a toddler. The gameplay mainly revolves around a "find the thing" mechanic that has you crawling, walking, pushing, and pulling your way across several locales while occasionaly avoiding some manner of big bad. In this respect the game is most similar to Slender in many respects although with a definite focus on surreal visuals that coupled with the distorted perspective of a small child create a much more atmospheric experience. While the game has more bark than bite in the horror department and the story (such as it is) doesn't so much unfold as fall into your lap toward the end, Among the Sleep is quality experience. Though the $20 price for less than 3 hours of non-repetition warranting gameplay is a bit steep, I'd still recommend checking this title out, though you may want to wait for a 50% off sale.

I left it paused for a little while) I got from the game were as fulfilling as any "full length" game, just condensed. I think a lot of people expect more out of games in terms of value, but that doesn't always seem fair. Considering how much you end up paying to see a movie at the theater, or for a a few rounds of drinks at a bar, this game starts to look like a pretty good deal. Overall, no matter how much you think you're getting ripped off, chances are good that a video game is still the best value in terms of hours per dollars spent.

												A well made an atmospheric game, with a really fresh perspective on first person horror - but quite short.I clocked it in about 2 and a half hours (had it alt+tabbed while I tended to my actual toddler).Lavishly designed in a really vibrant and alarming style, and controls that are really clever.Not sure it's worth a $20 price point, but on sale it was perfect.

Posted: September 14, 2014
												Assuming the role of a todder on their second birthday, players of Among the Sleep go on a dark, atmospheric journey that expertly plays on childhood fears and anxieties to create an immersive, if uneven, experience. After being put to bed by their mother, the player interacts with their new birthday present: Teddy the teddy bear. Teddy guides the player out of the bright, warm bedroom and into a dark, forbidding world. Stuck in this world away from their mother, the player must explore the dark environments and solve puzzles to recieve items which represent fond memories of their mother. The player explores the world by slowly walking through the environments or by crawling, which is much faster. The player is able to climb over obstacles and interact with many objects in the world. In dark areas, the player can hold Teddy tight, making the toddler feel more confident and lighting the way. The design is minimalistic and encourages the player to immerse themselves in the toddler's world. The environments are distorted perceptions of a normal household. The dark tone makes things appear more menacing than they would normally, adding to the tense atmosphere. In several environments, a dark presence hunts the player, forcing them to hide. The gameplay in these sections feel similar to Slender: The Arrivial but requires the player to hide, rather than run away, adding to the tension.Among the Sleep is short but still feels repetitive toward the end. The final section is satisfying enough to warrant a playthrough and the game as a whole delievers a well crafted psychological experience.

Posted: July 2, 2014
												Baby's first horror game! Most horror games put you in the shoes of an at least somewhat competent "hero", some even give you weapons. Among The Sleep is not one of those games. Here you're put into the blue jammies of a 2-year-old scared and confused little kid. The perspective alone makes a world of difference. Everything is more scary when you can't quite orientate yourself, tables become insurmountable objects and hallways become mile-long catacombs. There's also the fact that as a toddler you're weak, literally, so moving things becomes slow and difficult. And with your short legs outrunning danger becomes nigh impossible. I could go on a while as to why being a baby is scary stuff... And this game executes the experience very well. Coupled with a nebulous but interesting story, awesome visuals and terrifying design on everything. Yeah, it's a success. My only complaint is that it could've been a little bit longer.

Posted: July 29, 2015
												I'm actually a sissy when it comes to horror games - especially if they are in 1st person.However, the overall concept of the game caught me and after some while fearing, that I just couldn't get through the game, I snatched it using a humble bundle and tried.The game is just great. The main theme is the fear and awkwardness, children have in a world they don't fully understand. They tend to "interpret" things they see, so that they somehow make sense in their eyes. And that's what the game's doing. If you would be a grownup character, you wouldn't find any of the events in "Among the Sleep" terrifying, but through the eyes of a toddler, even a simple flash can be horrifying. And that's what the game really does well: It puts you in an atmosphere and plays with the surroundings, the size of the main character and its large amount of fantasy.So the creeps don't come from blood-dripping corpses or something like that. It comes from sounds, voices, height, eerie shadows, lonelyness and helplessness.The sound is aiding this pretty well and the overall sound composition is fitting in any minute.I, too, have to say, that the game is pretty short considering it's usual price. But after about 2,5h of creeps, I was kinda happy to really finish the game and get on with more milder themes. ;-)I highly recommend this game to people, that like to get some good shivers now and then, but don't actually want to be creeped out. Horror-Pros might find this game not so creepy, but may find the concept rather interesting.I hope, that's not the last game we see from Krillbyte.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												Great game! Very unique take on perspective in the horror genre playing as a 2 year old. Certainly not the scariest game, but great atmosphere, fun playthrough (albeit short), and I personally really apreciated the story (I cried at the end). I don't normally write reviews, but this game stuck with me and I felt compelled to provide some feedback. Compared to other games, it is really short for the price of the game... but I enjoyed it more than many movies where I have paid more money for less time spent. Definitely pick it up if it's on sale and you like a creepy, surreal atmosphere in games.

Posted: October 29, 2015
Summary 7.9/10A purely story-driven adventure that has no other direction but forward, but a good pace and experience in general leaves you satisfiedThe Good:- Great scares- Good use of tactics and required "know-how"- Cute, but bat-sh*t crazy- Dark and Eery, while also being justified- Sense of justice and acomplishment in the end- Strong connection with protagonist (At least for me.)- Great use of ambient soundThe Bad:- Expensive for so little time I put into it and completed it- Abysmal voice acting- Disappointing ending, although conclusive- Repetitious- Sudden cuts in audio and poor blending- Constant clipping, and extremely obviousConclusionAmong the Sleep is a lot like an Italian dessert. Its absurdly small, it's a poor decision, expensive and somewhat unhealthy in structure, but overall tasty and satisfying. If you loved Slender, play this. If the theme itself interests you, go for it. If you are looking for a long-lasting meal with dessert at the end, find another. It's good, but nothing I'd ever probably order again.

Posted: January 8, 2016
												It's a very atmospheric and a nice experience. The ending twist is a decent plot twist, although if you pay attention to your surroundings it is not that shocking of a reveal :) Some really nice art direction on some of the environments. I liked it very much, and audio desing is fittingly creepy. This type of abstract horror is much more effective than jumpscares. The negative is the horrendous performance and general clunkyness of the game code. Framerate is erratic, jumping around even VSynced, stream loading of environments are bad, and certain areas have some bugs making the framerate flicker from 57-60-62-60 all the time even when synced causing major stuttering and general unsmoothness. Some bugs as well. Does not trap the mouse in fullscreen, so on a multimonitor setup the mouse will sometimes exit the game when you click it (annoying when chased by monster guy and trying to hide). Some inventory bugs, also some graphical issues on light sources. But the stuttering is the worst i've seen in a while. Something is generally really wrong in certain areas of the game and it break an otherwise masteful immersion. I still recommend the game though, as it is a very atmospheric experience and you will love the detail of the environments

Posted: December 11, 2015
												Among the Sleep really surprised me!  It was much scarier than I anticipated and I found the story to be intelligently weaved into the gameplay.  The setting, the atmosphere, the controls – all of it fits together perfectly to achieve the mythical “Immersive” factor that so many games fall short of. Typical scare tactics are utilized to keep you in suspense; but there is also a more personalized fear that comes from being able to connect your own childhood fears to the obstacles that the child must overcome.  Entertainment value aside, Among the Sleep affords you the opportunity to face some of those latent fears from early development and gives parents a better perspective of what their child may be suffering through.

Posted: August 8, 2015
												Pros 'n Cons:+Very atmospheric, puts you constantly on edge, even if nothing is actually nearby (which most of the time, nothing is).+Great sound design, so much work went into creating the soundscape for this game, there's pretty much always something going on in that arena. MUST be played with headphones. +Creative premise, though I'm sure it won't be for long (on steam, nothing ever remains original for long, I'm lookin' at you, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ DayZ clones).+Neat monster design (though I wish I'd have been able to get a better look at the second one at some point, you get plenty of chances to see the first one, the second one you only kind of see its bottom half).-Definitely too short for something that costs $20. If you're thinking that the story can't possibly be over once you've collected all 4 memories, you are totally wrong, because it is, barring an epilogue scene (which I didn't see coming, though I knew there was going to be SOME kind of twist ending).-Has a very slow ramp up for such a short game. While the atmosphere is incredibly thick, it takes until about 1/2 of the way through the game before you are in any actual danger (IE, there's a roaming monster chasing you that will game over you if it touches you).-Only one real threat, and while it's terrifying, I'd have liked for there to be more. I believe technically the second monster CAN kill you, but I never had this happen because I've played Amnesia and know how to hide properly. -Did I mention it's short? Oh my God it's so short. Seriously though, wait until this thing is on sale for $5, buy it then, play it once (it'll only take a few hours), uninstall it, and never think about it again, but it's totally worth a playthrough. I hope to see more from this team in the future.

Posted: August 28, 2015
												A game that is far better at visual storytelling than scaring. All aspects of the story are fully supported by the excellent use of imagery and hints are everywhere. The environment you crawl around looks both scary and appropriately colorful. The sound effects, editing, and mixing are varied, unknown, mysterious, and evoke paranoia. But when it finally comes to actually scaring, almost nothing happens. The creepy sounds can be ignored and dismissed, as the game will rarely follow up on them with consequences in the gameplay. More often than not, the fear is not followed up on and the game presents little to no threats to the player. And even when there are threats, the game is too easy for you to fail to avoid them. With so much going for it, at the end of the day this game fails to scare.

Posted: February 25, 2015
												Among the Sleep is an incredible look into the roots of all horror, drawing heavily on much of the ideas postulated within Sigmund Freud's "The Uncanny" while exploring the world of trauma and fear through the eyes of a toddler.  It is a chilling experience, filled with excellent sound effects and exceptionally creative settings.  The game has a simple, but compelling story that the player is encouraged to experience with new eyes.  The controlls aren't perfect--I did get stuck on a few tree roots here and there--but overall, they suffice to bring the player a deep, memorable experience with very few hiccups.  It took me an hour and a half to play this game all the way through, but let me tell you, it was a briliant trip.  I would wait for it to go on sale, since $20 does seema bit steep, but if you can catch it for a decent price, grab this gem.  It can easily outdo any horror flick.8/10, due to the short length and sparse control hiccups.

Posted: November 22, 2015
												I just finished my first play through. It took a couple of months to finish because I played a few minutes at a time, but it took me about an hour to finish the game.I loved the experience. I'm a mom of a 2-year-old, which is why I bought the game in the first place. The story is heartbreaking and most of what's creepy about this comes from the fact that this is a neglected child. Can't get much worse than that :(That said, I'm not an expert on child psychology, but it's funny, and I say this as a mom, how accurate the game is when it comes to being a toddler. They do climb on chairs and drawers and do dangerous things without considering what could go wrong. The mechanics are totally plausible.It's very clear that the world and the events are how a very young, abused child sees them: distorted. This is also why the game is so scary, you kinda go through the house looking for your mommy but at the same time know that if you make a mistake (e.g. break a bottle), you'll regret it. Fear of someone you love is just terrible, especially if you're so vulnerable, and this game does a great job of getting you in that state of mind. This game has a great story and it makes you think about childhood, especially as a parent!

Posted: May 28, 2015
												DISCLAIMER: Obviously, reviewing horror / thriller games is tricky at best since fear is subjective; some find FNAF terrifying, others don't. For the record, I am a horror game veteran with games such as Silent Hill 1 & 2, Resident Evil 2 & 3, and a ton of indie horror games under my belt. So it is entirely possible that my tolerance for terror is forming a bias on opinion.TLDR:+ Brilliant atmosphere, pretty much spot-on+ Great environment design, cohesive and consistent with the theme+ Decent Audio Design, even if the ambience sfx is a tad over-recycled- Horror? What horror?- Tone and atmosphere is very jarring, changing dramatically as game goes on- Gameplay is very textbook, and is altogether unchallengingREVIEW:Forget those shadowy nightmares, that teddy is 10 times scarier than anything else this game will throw at you.I really, REALLY wanted to like Among The Sleep. I'm always on the lookout for innovative ideas, and the concept of a horror game through the eyes of a 2 year old was certainly intriguing. The story, without going into spoilers, is essentially that of a toddler who awakes in the middle of the night, and upon hearing noises downstairs decides to go investigate and look for mummy. Controls are the standard First-Person control scheme, with the nice added touch of crawling for increased movement speed as opposed to walking.Personally, I think the level design is where the game does really well; the environment is designed to be really up-scaled and large, and it does a great job of portraying a toddler's perspective of the world. Chairs are giant obstacles that take effort to climb onto, fridges feel like a giant white pillar, and getting from point A to B is an arduous task. The atmosphere is unnerving and subtly sinister, reminding me of the foreboding and evil vibe I got from Dead Space or Alien: Isolation. Lighting is sparse, casting shadows on everything, and at one point a flash of lightning made a tree seem like a monster. A nice touch showing the power of a child's imagination. All this combined gives us a first hour of feeling really tiny and vulnerable, exactly how a horror game should do. I was nervous, I was jumpy, and I was really looking forward to how the rest of the game would play out.And then, well... the game kinda gave up trying.I had assumed the suburbian home environment I saw in trailers and screenshots would continue throughout the game, and since it was up-scaled to be so large this would have been entirely possible. But for some reason, the the game turns into the Adventures of Alice In Wonderland opening with a literal tumbling down the rabbit hole. We start seeing the atmosphere's creepiness being traded in for whimsy and wonderment, and any sense of danger just drops out of the game with an audible thud. It occasionally tries to remind us of its spooky ways with whispers, moody lighting and the occasional shadow, but by the third act I was so comfortable and complacent with the game that I just lost interest.I will give a tentative thumbs-up for the story (still spoiler-free), which is intriguing enough that I may play more of the game just to see its conclusion. But again, the fact that I lost all interest points to an indication that the opening hook for the mystery was not strong enough for me to keep me invested. Most horror games either keep you engaged via mystery (Silent Hill, Amnesia) or survival (Resident Evil, Dead Space). Since Among The Sleep isn't about a baby struggling in post-apocalyptia, it has to rely on mystery. Which, unfortunately, isn't very mystifying; it's rather predictable and overall feels kinda cliche. But like I said, it is intriguing enough that I'm willing to play more in the future. And since most horror games aren't actually that complex in the story department anyway, I'm willing to let this aspect of the game go unpunished.Gameplay-wise there's not much to talk about. It's a very standard exploration puzzler à la Amnesia. You find a locked door /  staircase / see-saw, so you collect X keys to open said obstacle. It's not challenging, it's merely time-consuming, and the puzzles involved in getting the keys are mildly difficult at best, downright trivial at worst. This wouldn't be so bad if the story was interesting enough to carry the game on its own, and turn the game into more story-focus rather than gameplay-focus. However, as established previously the game isn't exactly strong in the story department, so Among The Sleep falls down on both fronts.Apparently there is also a persistent enemy within the game that hunts you down in each level, but if there was I didn't encounter it. I didn't even realise there was an enemy, which is a failure of design if you ask me. You want a persistent, omni-present monster to hunt the players down and scare them? Great! So make sure the player is aware of the enemy's presence at most / all times. You can't have an oppressive, nemesis-type antagonist if it's so passive in its oppression.Overall, I can't recommend Among The Sleep. I really WANT to, since it's such an fresh concept. It's also visually interesting, the level / audio design is pretty great, and the initial atmosphere is damn-near perfect. But the writing and gameplay design let it down for things to remain engaging, especially for a horror game. I would recommend this game when on a discount, but otherwise it's just not worth the regular asking price.

Posted: June 8, 2015
												I'm extremely fond of indie horror titles in general, having seen the old classics turn slowly into action titles (Resident Evil comes to mind) and as an original oculus rift kickstarter backer I watched this one with keen interest.All I can say is: wow.True horror makes you feel vulnerable, it doesn't give you any way to fight back, it makes things hopeless - and what better way to do that than to put you into the fears of childhood. This game really pulls that off well, a formal analysis would find lots of little psychological tricks used to generate an intense atmosphere and I heavily recommend playing with headphones on and the lights off.If you have one, the oculus rift is a must, but there is one annoying issue: it didn't work on Linux. This is something that should be fairly simple to fix, and may just be a problem with my setup (i'm using SteamOS inside a docker container), but it still annoyed me as setting up the rendering view for the rift should be a fairly trivial task to do cross-platform.That said, it's still got plenty of atmosphere played on a normal LCD monitor in a dark room, the whole game reminds me of the otherworld in Silent Hill, but far creepier due to the vulnerability it induces.If you enjoy horror, just get it.

Posted: June 13, 2015
												"Amongst the Sleep" is a surprisingly good little survival horror game that invokes your primal fears by placing you in the body of a small toddler that can barely walk upright. What may seem amusing at first quickly becomes outright scary as the child's unique perception of reality turns seemingly mundane objects and locations (such as a closet or a playground) into pure nightmare fuel. Even when the twist at the end of the story reveals the toddler's terrors to be relatively normal from an adult's point of view, the anxiety and uneasiness you will experience throughout the game will not simply fade away, as it merely replaces the imaginative fear with a real one.Unfortunately, the enjoyment you can get from this game is drastically limited by it's very short length, with a walkthrough taking little more than roughly two hours. It is perhaps something to be expected from a game that evolved from a student project, but still, by the time the credits roll you may feel extremely disappointed and longing for more. For what little it's worth, the game still manages to scare the hell out of you for these two hours.

The locations are interesting and fit perfectly with the view point as the young child.I haven't played the DLC yet, but I would say it was a bit shorter then I expected.  I don't think that takes away from anything, but it is worth noting if you are looking for quantity.If you like story driven games that aren't too difficult this would be a great game to add to your library.

												Everybody has had bad experiences throughout their childhood and in a very young stage your imagination plays a very big role in the scares you experience as a child. This game made me relive some of those experiences through the scary locations that where marvelously integrated in the game. Eventough you play a todler the movement is well-thougth-out and your dissabilty of not being able to move around like you normally would, creates a challege and makes it more enjoyable. Also the soud was pretty amazing and really made the difference. And even though it was a single player game, your companion Teddy made it feel like you were not alone. The way you interact with your Teddy and the benefit you have from his company made it sort of realistic. After I finished the game I was so sucked into the story line I wanted to remain a todler. The story line is great and even a child could understand it. However I would have liked more detail from the story line. Luckily the prologue showed some more detail about the story surrounding you. The game was short but worth the money (steam summer sale). I would have liked it to be longer but that probably would bring the story out of balance. I would like more dlc's (free or paid).

Posted: December 27, 2014
												In Among the Sleep you play as a VERY strong (as in strength) and agile two-year-old.  The game plays more as an "adventure narrative" and focuses primarily on fetching "memories" and solving very simple puzzles.  Although, I do recommend this game to people who like "narrative story games" there is not much else to it. I did notice that it was tagged with "horror theme" and was a little confused. It definitely has some spooky parts, but  I wouldn't label it as horror. PROS: Pretty visuals and a cool sidekick Teddy bear that helps you along the adventure. CONS: A VERY short story that leaves the fun, supernatural themes and ends with what feels like an after-school-special plot line. I was a little disappointed with the plot twist.

Posted: November 30, 2014
												10/10 Artworks looks stunning, presentation is excellent, perfect length for a game like this. Exceeded expectations, I love that they don't spell anything out for you, figuring out the story for yourself is part of it. The gameplay is simple and perfect. Most noticably, the game isn't arduous and long, it can be completed in 3-4 hours, which is perfect because even in horror games like amnesia or outlast, I find that after I've been playing it for too long, or if I have to return to it later in order to complete it, it drops me out of the experience and by the end of the game I'm sprinting with wreckless abandon and my sense of immersion drops. Not to mention there aren't any extended puzzles or stealth sequences that halt your progression. Additionally I'd like to point out that this isn't exactly a horror game as much as it is a scary psychological adventure, and it absolutely nails it.

Posted: January 2, 2015
 A game to make your blood run cold This game for me, was absolutely terrifying, and anyone who says it isn't I think may not have fully emmersed themselves in the creepy and quite frankly dark story -  and it is a very dark theme , which may be an emotional trigger for some.   Theme of Alcoholism and suggested child abuse and dissociation coping mechanisms during a parental feud and divorce  I like this style of game because of the atmospheric horror style, which echoes some of the elements of "Silent Hill" puzzle solving, and the paranormal and psychological aspect from F.E.A.R. This game is not for those who are prone to panick attacks, as I myself found out the hard way. However if you are the sort of person who gets a kick out of the adrenaline while being terrified, then I thoroughly recommend this game to you. It is beautiful and horrific all at the same time.

												I was recommended this game a short while ago and decided that I would give it a try.I picked this up at the full price, so one thing I will say is that while I thoroughly enjoyed my experience playing this, I don't feel as though it is worth the fairly hefty pricetag for a short indie game.One of the first things that I enjoyed about this title was the voice acting - it fits in perfectly and really helps to set the characters. Posted: January 5, 2015
												Score: 8/10Price/Value: $10 Time: 2 hours*Spoilers Ahead* Among the Sleep turned out to be a wonderful surprise. You play as a wee two year old toddler navigating a world which appears nightmarish to your infant eyes. Many people will be reminded immediately of the Penumbra series when it comes to world interaction (chests, drawers, opening doors, object manipulation). Artistically, this game is lovely to look at. Coats, boots and everyday objects are made out to be creatures in the dark or stylized into the creatures themselves. The baby's room is well done and being able to look down and see your tiny self fidgeting like a child might actually do in reality is a neat little thing to include. The mother looks fantastic and the lighting sets the mood for the rather dark and sad story they are telling.This is where we get into spoilers. The gist of the story is that the creatures from your nightmares are actually your mother and, from what I am guessing, either your father or some form of social services worker. As you might have guessed from that last sentence, your mother is losing you. The symbolism that is put forth in the child's drawings scattered around the level was an interesting inclusion to go along with the theme of child abuse, alcoholism and misunderstanding that children have when these things happen really sealed this up into a gem. Seeing your mother in the floor of the kitchen, your bear in one hand and wine glass in the other weeping left me cold inside at the end. Realising that the witch in the well from your children's story is your mother and her alcoholism struck a chord and is relatable I'm sure to many people growing up from all walks of life. This is easily a gem and worth it at any price. Not really a horror title as I thought it might be more-so, but actually something much deeper and more meaningful.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												The monster only appears a handful of times, and it usually disappears immediately after if the player finds a hiding spot in time. The interaction with the monster is very limited, and so it's not that significant an element in the game. It doesn't stalk the player, and there's no real cat-and-mouse interplay. As long as you keep aware of the nearest thing you can crawl under, then you won't have to fear much for your safety.If the developers had come up with an actual need for hugging the teddy bear, and if they had expanded upon the evasion of the monster, then there could have been a lot more gratification and strategy in the gameplay. If the monster was a bit smarter and more persistent and methodical in its search for the child, then the teddy could have been used to calm the child to prevent it from crying and giving away his position. Or something like that.The $20 asking price for this game might be a bit steep for the limited playtime and lack of any real scares. But if you can pick it up on a Steam sale (as I did), then the novelty makes it worth a few hours of your time. It's story is shaky in the middle act, but the conclusion is very human, very blunt, and terrifyingly real, in a way that goes far beyond the childish terror that any imaginary closet monster can create.Full review on my personal blog:http://www.megabearsfan.net/post/2014/08/22/Among-the-Sleep-game-review.aspx

Posted: September 3, 2015
												I recommend this game becuase it tells a sad story that is based on real life. It does it in a relatively short but well paced game - it doesn't feel to short, nor too long (about 3h). There's no stretch padding, and it doesn't feel rushed. The game is definitely story focused, so don't come expecting a ton of mind bending puzzles or complex routines, the challenge level is very low.The story is set against simple but powerful music, sounds and visuals, and the unusual perspective of the player (a baby) works well for a unique gameplay experience and for the theme of the game. Soundwise, if you don't play with headphones or a decent surround sound then you're probably missing out.Horror wise, I found it reasonably scary - but it's not just cheap jumpscares, it ties very well with the narrative. As the game reaches an end, you'll realise that the scariness is rather childish... and even more horrible.All in all, Among the Sleep is a good story game that uses interactivity to rise above what you would experience with a film or novel of the same nature.

												Long story short: Get it on sale at < $10. It's good.I was following the crowd-funding campaign and development of this game somewhat close and was super excited after playing the Alpha that was released.The game definitely does not disappoint when it comes to presentation: Killbrite ♥♥♥♥ing kills it when it comes to atmosphere. I was completely immersed most of the time and I noticed my mouth was agape a lot. The art style is qwerky by design seeing as how it's through the lens of a toddler and the sections where fear alters the environment is really awesome.The sound design of this game is super on point. All the little creaks and cracks in the environment as well as the occasional loud breathing of the protagonist kept me on edge even when there was no perceivable threat. Hearing the mother character humming a lullaby when you were near the end of your objective was assuring but the somber melody is super creepy at the same time.Where this game falls somewhat short is in the actual gameplay. The puzzles are so laughably easily, a baby can do them......*crickets*...whatever. Anyway, most of the game is classic horror: Try a door >♥♥♥♥♥♥s locked > look for key > traverse level looking for key > get key > open door > move on to next level. The perspective is somewhat unique in that you're a tiny babby ♥♥♥♥♥-his-pants so you have to find creative ways to traverse an environment, which largely includes moving chairs to climb them to open doors or opening drawers to climb them.My biggest gripe with the game is actually the length. I beat it in 2 hours and I'm ♥♥♥♥ing dog♥♥♥♥♥♥at video games. A good player can prolly beat it in an hour or less. Posted: October 29, 2015
Summary 7.9/10A purely story-driven adventure that has no other direction but forward, but a good pace and experience in general leaves you satisfiedThe Good:- Great scares- Good use of tactics and required "know-how"- Cute, but bat-sh*t crazy- Dark and Eery, while also being justified- Sense of justice and acomplishment in the end- Strong connection with protagonist (At least for me.)- Great use of ambient soundThe Bad:- Expensive for so little time I put into it and completed it- Abysmal voice acting- Disappointing ending, although conclusive- Repetitious- Sudden cuts in audio and poor blending- Constant clipping, and extremely obviousConclusionAmong the Sleep is a lot like an Italian dessert. Its absurdly small, it's a poor decision, expensive and somewhat unhealthy in structure, but overall tasty and satisfying. If you loved Slender, play this. If the theme itself interests you, go for it. If you are looking for a long-lasting meal with dessert at the end, find another. It's good, but nothing I'd ever probably order again.

Posted: November 1, 2015
												This is an excellent, short, little horror game. Playing as a child is perfect starting point as you are so helpless and vulnerable, you can either walk slowly or crawl but you cannot see too far when crawling. The atmosphere is what makes this game so good. It starts off with a very creepy oppressive atmosphere where you never know what dangers are lurking. Then just when you are thinking it is only a sinister atmosphere and there are no actual threats you catch a glimpse of enemies. There are no really cheap jump scares but lots of menacing corner of the screen glimpses of things and when you do first get caught by the enemy it is terrifying. So this manages to maintain the atmosphere throughout that game where you are never sure if you are in danger or not. My only complaint is that some of the camera movements when climbing made me a little nauseous.

Posted: February 7, 2015
												Among the Sleep is a different sort of horror game in that it utilizes jump scares, creepy ambiance, and heartpumping adrenaline spikes rather than outright gory, bloody, horror. It's whimsically odd in aspects that are reminiscent of Alice in Wonderland, and creepy in aspects that closely resemble that of Slender/Amnesia. It's fun to play, might even get you a few times with some scares, and is completely worth it.This game surprised me in more ways than I expected. I was consistently trying to figure out the plot and whenever I thought I had it, it would change on me. The bear for one is somewhat creepy on it's own, and when you first begin to meet and interact with Teddy it feels very reminsicent of Chucky. As the game plays forward however, Teddy is your best friend in the entire world, as you navigate through a world that feels like the "Other Mother" built it (Coraline reference!). There's simple puzzles to complete to progress as you go, but they aren't mind-numbingly simple, some of them take a few minutes to put together.The story itself gives a fresh new way of looking at this kind of situation through a child's perspective. You're playing as a two year old child, and your objective is to rescue your mother from this nightmarish, topsy-turvey, alternate version of your own world. The ambiance is amazing, and the graphics are impeccable. It can get truly terrifying.I bought this game on a daily deal for 66% off. Among the Sleep isn't a very long game, it's only roughly 3 hrs of playthrough, so I feel better about paying 6$ vs 20$ to be honest. It's gamepad compatable, and if you're using a pc with Windows it goes without saying that it's recommended you use an Xbox 360 controller.It's fun, short, but not so sweet! If you can swing it, pick up Among the Sleep and play it, it's worth it.

Posted: April 20, 2015
												Among the Sleep is an excellent game, especially for people who don't like horror games in general. The terror is more the kind that you let yourself sink into - sliding into the small hiding places that only you, as a toddler, can fit inside; rushing to climb on top of small boxes to save yourself from a fairy-tale monster; exploring the nooks and crannies of the dreamscapes you find yourself inside; feeling the discomfiture of a world that isn't quite right.The game is only a couple hours long and the story unfolds at a leisurely pace across it, but the world has a lot of very interesting details if you look for them, the simple puzzles do a good job of building tension, and the level design does a very good job of leading your forward and keeping you on edge. I definitely recommend it.

I went into Among the Sleep with minimal information, I just saw that you played as a infant, and I knew I had to have it. The adventure that followed starting from 12 to around 3 in the morning some might say was shortlived, however I loved every bit of it. The atmosphere, symbolism, and thought that this game provokes stemming from the question of what is real and what is imagination from the point of a two year old was comparable in complexity to the ending of Bioshock Infinite. I also find it comparable to movies such as American Psycho and Donnie Darko in the same way. Not everyone will have the same interpretation, although I have heard very good ones in the forums. If you expect from this game cheap jumps scares or award winning graphics or action, look somewhere else. This game is more of an allegory within a haunting art form, and I will fondly remember those nearly three hours I spent on this game, as  I will also remember what I took away.

Posted: November 28, 2014
												Wow. That was just...I dunno. It's 70% wow and 30% meh for me. I'm not really an expert in horror games since this is the first of the genre that I've ever played but, I have to admit, I was kind of disappointed because I had expected more . I had expected there to be some fighting or kicking♥♥♥♥♥ whichever you prefer, but there weren't any. I wanted there to be epic teddy bear transformations and bedroom weapons, but we can't all have what we want. There was a lot of hiding involved though and bottles. Boy, were there a lot of bottles. There were also jumpscares here and there, but they were okay. If you wanna know how scary it is, think of a really short rollercoaster ride. This game kind of struck me as a combination between Slender and the movie "Mama". You'll figure out why once you've tried it out. The graphics and sounds were nice enough, but the story was something else altogether. Mind you, it was great and different, but it was no fairytale. I was able to put two and two together during the first chapter, but I wasn't able to figure out the whole story until the very end, even if there were lots of clues laid out throughout the game. Overall, it was fun and well worth a try.  I don't know about the price though since it's kind of short. Maybe you can buy it when it goes on sale if you're hesitant about purchasing it.

Posted: November 30, 2014
												Among the Sleep takes players on a journey through a nightmarish dreamworld concieved by a toddler's imagination, and molded by the disturbing issues he faces in real life. The concept is certainly fresh, but does the game itself hold up under scrutiny?It's abundantly clear from the start that the developers of Among the Sleep have spent a lot of time carefully constructing the environments in this game. Many of the objects and locations are made up of very authentic-looking artifacts that you might see scattered around a toddler's room in real life. Some of them are used to frightening effect, such as removing the eyes from an otherwise adorable stuffed animal, or making the seemingly innocent drawings of a child take on a far more sinister meaning. All of these conscientious design choices come together quite effectively, and the atmosphere benefits greatly from it.One of the biggest concerns I had for this game was if it could deliver true horror. The kind of horror that slowly and carefully builds into a suffocating climax of fear. Thankfully, I was not dissapointed. The game doesn't pull any punches, and although it takes some time at the beginning to establish the story, the rest of the game is a non-stop, exhilariting tour into darkness. Well...for the most part. The puzzles in the game are never demanding, and they don't really increase in difficulty much. Most of them involve collecting specific items or keys, and taking them to the correct location, which is all too easy considering how linear the game is. It's almost a nitpick, considering how frequently the game excels at building tension and fear through its various assets, but I would have appreciated a bit more complexity and origniality when it came to the actual gameplay.At the end of the day, the biggest problem I had with this game was its length. Sure, its well-paced. It has great visuals, great voice-acting, great sound design...but if the game can be beaten in 2 hours or less, you're not getting much value for your money. I expect a little more content from a game thats list price is $20. Some might argue that all of that money is well-spent considering how much obvious love and effort was put into this game, and how amazing it turned out to be considering that it was created by a very small indie development team, but in my personal opinion, $20 is still too much to ask for such a short game, with so little replay value. If you can get it on sale though, Among the Sleep is a very solid horror experience. If you've enjoyed games like Amnesia or Outlast, Among the Sleep will deliver more of the same great storytelling, audio design, and horror you've come to expect from those games, albeit on a much smaller scale.7.5/10

Posted: August 1, 2014
												In Among the Sleep, by Krillbite Studio, you will take on the role of a 2 year old child who just had his birthday. You are eating cake in the arms of your mom when there is a knock at the door. This is followed by an argument, and then your mom coming back in with a present. You then fast forward to around bedtime/nap time, I'm not really sure which. It is then that the game takes on a nightmarish overlay.The visual look of this game felt like it fit with the character being a 2 year old. I'm not saying that it was rainbows and puppies, but there were those softer colors, even when everything was dark. The levels of this game were beyond creepy, especially for me because I have an almost 2 year old, so I could see myself in his shoes. There is a slight terror to knowing that something bad could happen right out of the corner of your eye. The levels span from a deserted play ground, a library in a forest, small sections of your house, and more. There are villains that creep around as well. All I have to say is you are going to need to hide from them, or you will suffer a restart of the section you are in. I also really enjoyed the companion, the teddy bear that helped me along. All I had to do was hug it and he would produce a little bit of light that would help me see through the darkness.The sounds in this game are extremely creepy. Once again it was doubley so because I have a young son, and hearing those noises creep around in a dark area would scare the pants off me at that age. I also think the voice acting in this game was spot on. I could see the roles of the mother and the teddy bear in the voices given.The controls of the game are your usual configuration with WASD, shift to run, ctrl to crawl or get up, space to climb, and the mouse to control the camera and interact with objects.Though this game wasn't as long as I would have hoped, it definitely had enough there to keep me on my toes, and hoping that nothing was going to get me around the next corner. There is just something about this game that awakened long gone fears of my childhood, and the fear of what is in the dark. In this respect the developers did a great job. To be honest I can't really think of anything I found clunky or missing from this game. I will tell you this, the twist is a hell of one, and I'm not going to tell you what it is because you need to play this game to find out, but when the game ends everything kind of makes better sense.There were definitely puzzle aspects to this game, most of the time it was moving objects so that you could get to a different location, but there were a couple of times where the developers threw in a mechanism just for a small section of the game that changed things up a little. A couple examples of this would be throwing objects to knock something off a shelf, or collecting a specific type of object so that you could weigh down the end of something so you could get to the other side. I'm not saying that this was a bad thing, but I would have liked to see a little bit more of these mechanics, to do them once and then seeming to throw them away made me feel like they were afterthoughts in the game creation process.So lets get down to the part that most of you want to know, and that is should you play this game. The answer is yes, you should play this game, and you should play it in the dark, at night, and pray that no one sneaks up behind you while you are playing. This game gets an 8.9 out of 10.

Posted: July 31, 2014
												This is probably the first Survival Horror game that hit me on a psychological level. Delivering you into the body of a two year old child, you must navigate the dark and disturbing world of a troubled mind and uncover the mysterious dissappearence of your mother. Alongside you a teddy bear named "Teddy" aids you in your journey often keeping you comfort when you need it. The game sets up an interesting premise but falls short at making you feel more vulnerable as a child as opposed to any other horror game. The true feat here is how large and menacing the environments are and the illusion that every object in the game world is either falling on you or trying to pull you in. Quite often in places you dont want to go. That combined with the chilling ambient sound make for a very unnerving atmosphere. The story is well written and completely out of left field. Please buy if you consider yourself a fan of this genre.

Posted: September 16, 2014
												Among the sleep is a very good game, its creepy and has a few jump scares- which makes it very enjoyable!

Posted: September 14, 2014
												A well made an atmospheric game, with a really fresh perspective on first person horror - but quite short.I clocked it in about 2 and a half hours (had it alt+tabbed while I tended to my actual toddler).Lavishly designed in a really vibrant and alarming style, and controls that are really clever.Not sure it's worth a $20 price point, but on sale it was perfect.

Posted: September 14, 2014
												Assuming the role of a todder on their second birthday, players of Among the Sleep go on a dark, atmospheric journey that expertly plays on childhood fears and anxieties to create an immersive, if uneven, experience. After being put to bed by their mother, the player interacts with their new birthday present: Teddy the teddy bear. Teddy guides the player out of the bright, warm bedroom and into a dark, forbidding world. Stuck in this world away from their mother, the player must explore the dark environments and solve puzzles to recieve items which represent fond memories of their mother. The player explores the world by slowly walking through the environments or by crawling, which is much faster. The player is able to climb over obstacles and interact with many objects in the world. In dark areas, the player can hold Teddy tight, making the toddler feel more confident and lighting the way. The design is minimalistic and encourages the player to immerse themselves in the toddler's world. The environments are distorted perceptions of a normal household. The dark tone makes things appear more menacing than they would normally, adding to the tense atmosphere. In several environments, a dark presence hunts the player, forcing them to hide. The gameplay in these sections feel similar to Slender: The Arrivial but requires the player to hide, rather than run away, adding to the tension.Among the Sleep is short but still feels repetitive toward the end. The final section is satisfying enough to warrant a playthrough and the game as a whole delievers a well crafted psychological experience.

Posted: September 18, 2014
												Among the Sleep is not your conventional AAA title, and as such, cannot really be judged against them. It is, however, excellent. The pacing, especially considering that this is a game that you can easily complete in one sitting, assuming your heart can take it, is absolutely spot on. The tutorial blends seemlessly with the flow of the game; while the level design is detailed and beautiful, and, while linear, doesn't feel restricting. The controls are simple, with no excessively complex button mappings to memorise, don't forget to lean around a corner or two though... The music is that perfect blend of atmospheric without being so attention grabbing that you stop feeling immersed. Lastly, the story, while simple, will definitely take you on a rollercoaster of emotion. There will be no spoilers here, but here are my four best bits of advice regarding Among the Sleep:1) Remember, all this is through the eyes of a child, let the game immerse you in such.2) Keep an eye out for the drawings scattered around, they'll not only help build the story, but may be key to your progression...3) Play it in a darkened room, headphones if you've got them (not necessary, but I played with just my speakers and succeeded in freaking myself out with the random noises in the empty flat around me).4) Get it! Play it! It's so completely worth it!Good hunting!- id_doomerFootnote: If your mouse doesn't work as a control interface, like mine didn't; it may mean that your joystick is plugged in, as Among the Sleep will default to using the joystick as an input source first. A rare situation in today's PC gaming world, I know, but toggle it off in the option menu and you'll be fine.

Posted: September 18, 2014
												The atmosphere of this game is great: rooms and open spaces are fully explorable and detailed, hints about the plot are scattered all over and it's interesting to reconstruct the story. The tension is build progressively, and the tutorial is surprisingly well integrated within the game. The little plot there is is ambiguous enough to leave room for interpretation, which I always like. The ending is great!What I do have an issue with is with the questionable saving system and the checkpoint placement (I was stuck after the game crashed & unable to proceed, had to restart the game over again).Also, the idea of having the player regulate the brightness of the screen is great... until you realize you can't see a thing. Don't go overboard with it :P

Posted: September 13, 2014
												Pros: A lot of attention has been placed on the backstory to this game, and there a plenty of little clues to what is going on. The developers seemed to have a fairly good understanding of how children think as well, and it paints a picture of abuse pretty well.It is pretty artistically done, as well.Cons: It is relatively short. This isn't neccessarily a bad thing, in that it took about as long as it needed for the story, but can be a downstide for anyone expecting a lot of play out of this game. Since it is story focussed, any replays are mostly going to be to pick up things you missed the first time.I would have appreciated more information on the father in the backstory. Still, pay attention when you do here what is presumably his voice at the end, because it's pretty familiar.This game does 'have feels'. I was actually fairly angry on the behalf of the child in the game by the end, as well as sad to see the whole situation. I'd recommend picking it up, but likely when it's on sale, as I feel the normal price would be a bit much for the amount of gameplay you get.

Posted: September 12, 2014
												At first glance, the game seems a little pricey for the hours logged. But, one thing that is worth noting is that the game has very little down time. The pacing is good and the game alterantes primarily between suspence and intensity. Had it been longer, it would have worn out its charm. And had it been less expensive... Well, everyone has to make a living, and I'm sure a lot of work went the game. It's very polished and the visuals and sound are fantastic, so I don't feel ripped off. The two hours (ish... I left it paused for a little while) I got from the game were as fulfilling as any "full length" game, just condensed. I think a lot of people expect more out of games in terms of value, but that doesn't always seem fair. Considering how much you end up paying to see a movie at the theater, or for a a few rounds of drinks at a bar, this game starts to look like a pretty good deal. Overall, no matter how much you think you're getting ripped off, chances are good that a video game is still the best value in terms of hours per dollars spent.

Posted: June 8, 2015
												I'm extremely fond of indie horror titles in general, having seen the old classics turn slowly into action titles (Resident Evil comes to mind) and as an original oculus rift kickstarter backer I watched this one with keen interest.All I can say is: wow.True horror makes you feel vulnerable, it doesn't give you any way to fight back, it makes things hopeless - and what better way to do that than to put you into the fears of childhood. This game really pulls that off well, a formal analysis would find lots of little psychological tricks used to generate an intense atmosphere and I heavily recommend playing with headphones on and the lights off.If you have one, the oculus rift is a must, but there is one annoying issue: it didn't work on Linux. This is something that should be fairly simple to fix, and may just be a problem with my setup (i'm using SteamOS inside a docker container), but it still annoyed me as setting up the rendering view for the rift should be a fairly trivial task to do cross-platform.That said, it's still got plenty of atmosphere played on a normal LCD monitor in a dark room, the whole game reminds me of the otherworld in Silent Hill, but far creepier due to the vulnerability it induces.If you enjoy horror, just get it.

Posted: May 9, 2015
												I am giving this a 9.I have not loved a lot of puzzle adventure games in the past. I find the controls a little finicky usually, and sometimes the puzzles are too involved just for the sake of ... I don't know showing they can? The toddler's perspective is so incredibly well done, and so immersive! When you stand up from crawling, they've captured this cute little loss of balance wobble - very life-like! And it doesn't happen everytime.For those who say it is not scary - I totally disagree! The atmosphere and the sinister/sad nature of the story make it terrifying. Yes, it is short. Whatever. It took me way longer than 3 hours, but I'm not an old hand at the types of puzzles and I was genuinely terrified and didn't want to leave the closet at some points.Among the Sleeps controls and mechanics are simple to work out. And they work incredibly smoothly. I love the game despite one or two bugs that made me look at walkthroughs where I thought I was stuck but it was just a question of reloading the checkpoint. These glitches do not happen to everyone, and there are plenty of checkpoints, so it's not a huge drama.I cried at the end.

Posted: July 23, 2014
												I very much liked the idea and concept of this game.  Turning a child's world into a horrific nightmare and making you actually FEEL like a child in which all you can do is run and hide from monsters?  Yes please!  The dynamic of a two year old works really well, making the world around you much bigger than if you were playing an adult.  The scenes are beautiful and creepy beyond belief, and the monsters are genuinely terrifying.  What I liked most in some cases was when you're running for the last little segment and you think to look behind you - and a monster would be right behind you.  Having gone undetected until then sure gives you a big jump and some desparation to escape.  It's very short, and I felt a little disappointed by that, but the rest of the game makes up for it - mainly the story.  This is a game where you can't do much at all, but that's to let the story be the sole mechanic of moving the game forward.  And I was quite impressed with the story and its twist at the end.  Definitely worth playing!
