Posted: July 12, 2014
												A baby's first horror adventure; A rather intriguing idea which unfortunately is not explored in a wholly satisfying manner. You play as a baby whisked into a dark slumberland with your mother ominously gone missing. Dreaming up a way to find and save her only by walking, crawling and grabbing objects is the idea here. A bit of adventuring is required, then.I don't generally have a problem with games featuring very little actual gameplay if the story, environments or the general atmosphere are interesting enough. None of these elements are that compelling in Among the Sleep. The sound design is a strong point and manages to create a few heebie-jeebies, but for the most part it's just you toddling along in pitch-black corridors, bumping into furniture and other things in the night. There's not really that much to do, and the levels, while metaphorically rich, are a bit too abstract for their own good.Also I must have played a few too many horror games, since for me the most frightening figure of the whole game was the supremely unnerving walking and talking teddybear, who is actually supposed to be your friend and mentor. I think the way the game introduces him is done completely wrong, unless they were specifically aiming to present him/it as a suspicious character. Never trust the teddy.Anyhow, after a couple of hours of wandering in the dark doing the same things over and over again, the game ends. The story does not end up being a complete waste, but overall, I was hoping for a somewhat stronger finale. After all, the gameplay stuff in between start and finish wasn't that brilliant either. I feel like the game would work much better played with the Oculus Rift (for which it was clearly designed for), but as a traditional first-person horror quickie the game is just too mild. Too scary for actual children and not scary enough for adults, but worth a glance and not a total snoozefest.

Posted: July 16, 2014
												This game, man, where to start?I'll start with what I liked I guess. The art style, story, voice acting, sounds, level design, virtual reality compatability, and concept as a whole are all generally great. Its a very nice game to look at, even though I didn't play it at it max settings, it still looked great, I mean, there are plenty of games that look a hell of a lot better, but coupled with its art style it does look very good indeed. The sounds are also very well done, they add a real eery atmosphere to the already weird yet interesting environment, one that would suggest you and your Teddy Bear companion are never alone. The story is also fantastic, with a seemingly paranormal setting, the ending outcome of the story is obvious when you take into consideration the fact that you play as an infant child yet provides an answer to the puzzling chapters of the game. The voice acting, although there isn't much of it, is very well done. The voice acting of your Teddy Bear is perfect, as it conveys a nice friendly tone with a dash of authority and protection, similar to that of a brother and companion. The voice acting of your Mother brilliantly shows the things a mother experiences with their young children, and how a child may percieve her. I don't own an Oculus Rift myself, or anything that does a similar job, but, using one with this game would have been such a cool experience. Finally, the idea of taking the place of a child is indeed, clever, as its puts a complete twist on your perception of the world, as you see the events infront of you, and all you can think is that its some sort of paranormal ghost, or demon, yet come the end you mearly had to look at the world through a scared toddlers eyes.Now, the parts that I personally did not like. The length of the game, the optimization, and some of the balancing for the monsters. Honestly, when I finished I was a bit disappointed at the length of the playable story, from what I remember there was only 6 chapters, according to Steam, I've only played 2 hours of it, and I was afk for a decent amount of that, so I'd say it was an hour to an hour and 45 minutes or so depending on how well you solver puzzles, get past monsters etc. I also felt that the optimization of the game wasn't great, as I've played games with a lot more going on in them at a lot better framerate, not that my PC is in fact the knees of the bee, but this may be as simple as it being more suited to NVidia graphics rather than AMD (which I use). Finally, on one chapter, I felt like it was a little hard to escape past the monster, this may be my fault, but it did seem a little unbalanced due to the limited speed and defense the player has. Most of the things I have a problem with though, could be fixed with patches and DLC.Overall, I would heartily recommend this game to anyone who enjoys puzzle-horror games, as this one has a good blend of the two, as well as a well written story, terrifying set of monsters, eery setting and a very good sense of immersion. I'd give it a 7.9/10 and am very happy with the amount of I money paid for the game.

Posted: December 12, 2014
												Good storytelling but predictable and ruined by the bear.I wouldn't recommend this game except for the way it handled the storytelling.  Even though I figured out everything by the second painting, I felt it did a good job getting the whole feel across from a young child's perspective.The game isn't really scary, although it conveys the same sort of childhood 'spookiness' that a dark house and strange sounds bring.  That is it's greatest strength, conveying a nightmare from a child's perspective -- full of strange places and monsters.  This emersion is then quickly ruined by the addition of the damn teddy bear pulled out of some children's show who you HAVE to take with you and who ruins everything.It controlls well, looks good, and conveys a feeling of helplessness that a two-year old child would have along with the potential havoc and trouble a two-year old can get into.  At least, until the bear opens his stupid mouth again.I can't state this enough, but the bear ruins the whole experience by talking.  Listening to him suffer in the washing machine or trying to hang on to you is one thing; I hated him from the get-go but even I felt bad for him at those points.  If they cut out his dialogue and just left him emotion he would have been an excellent companion, but as implemented he screams "HELLO YOU ARE IN A GAME WITH TALKING BEAR WHO POINTS OUT THE OBVIOUS".The game is short, and it would have been a nice bit of art if everyone would learn to shut up.  As is, I think some people will enjoy it a lot and ultimately what it does well it does well enough that I can forgive the rest.  This game is NOT for you if:1. You are immune to childhood fears2. You want a long game (I've logged 3 hrs and that includes taking the time to write swears in blocks)3. You want a scary game (unless you are very vulnerable to childhood fears, in which case this is for you)4. You hate physics puzzlesThis game IS for you if:1. You are vulnerable to childhood fears and like being haunted by them.2. You enjoyed the demo (despite how badly the bear ruins the experirence)3. You like 'artistic' game experiences and an interactive way of telling a story.I'm personally in the middle, and would have recommended this stronger if the bear was mostly mute as well.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												The monster only appears a handful of times, and it usually disappears immediately after if the player finds a hiding spot in time. The interaction with the monster is very limited, and so it's not that significant an element in the game. It doesn't stalk the player, and there's no real cat-and-mouse interplay. As long as you keep aware of the nearest thing you can crawl under, then you won't have to fear much for your safety.If the developers had come up with an actual need for hugging the teddy bear, and if they had expanded upon the evasion of the monster, then there could have been a lot more gratification and strategy in the gameplay. If the monster was a bit smarter and more persistent and methodical in its search for the child, then the teddy could have been used to calm the child to prevent it from crying and giving away his position. Or something like that.The $20 asking price for this game might be a bit steep for the limited playtime and lack of any real scares. But if you can pick it up on a Steam sale (as I did), then the novelty makes it worth a few hours of your time. It's story is shaky in the middle act, but the conclusion is very human, very blunt, and terrifyingly real, in a way that goes far beyond the childish terror that any imaginary closet monster can create.Full review on my personal blog:http://www.megabearsfan.net/post/2014/08/22/Among-the-Sleep-game-review.aspx

Posted: October 2, 2014
												When it comes to horrors, this is pretty good. It has a great atmosphere, the sounds are incredibly creepy, and it's enemies... Oh, it's enemies. Let's start with the first "monster", he looks like a coat-rack with a coat and an umbrella (that's the idea), he isn't a threat but is involved with a jumpscare a few minutes in. Next is the swamp-tree lady. She looks like medusa with hair like branches and bright glowing eyes, she is more of a threat. Lastly is the Raincoat man. He looks like an egg with a raincoat, he doesn't pose much of a threat but is still creepy until you figure out a way to bypass him, then no problem.A special interesting thing is when you have finished the game, you'll find that the monsters are based on the mother. (not gonna spoil much.)The story I think is you 're playing a two-year-old living with a single mother whom has some problems, she becomes pretty abusive but does not give you to the father, it does not appear like this at the start but you'll figure it out, anyway you go on this nightmarish adventure looking for your mother after a darkness invades your house, you'll need to solve puzzles, throw objects, but most of all, survive the threats of the monsters.The ending, to me, is really powerful, (I don't wanna spoil) in tugged a heartstring in me, and hopefully it will for you.Overall I give a 9/10. It's chosen art style is nice and the models are great, but a small optimisation would be nice, but hey, it's no Slender: The Arrival. I'll say you'll enjoy this game with it's easy to earn achievements, and it's dark atmosphere!

Posted: September 13, 2014
												Pros: A lot of attention has been placed on the backstory to this game, and there a plenty of little clues to what is going on. The developers seemed to have a fairly good understanding of how children think as well, and it paints a picture of abuse pretty well.It is pretty artistically done, as well.Cons: It is relatively short. This isn't neccessarily a bad thing, in that it took about as long as it needed for the story, but can be a downstide for anyone expecting a lot of play out of this game. Since it is story focussed, any replays are mostly going to be to pick up things you missed the first time.I would have appreciated more information on the father in the backstory. Still, pay attention when you do here what is presumably his voice at the end, because it's pretty familiar.This game does 'have feels'. I was actually fairly angry on the behalf of the child in the game by the end, as well as sad to see the whole situation. I'd recommend picking it up, but likely when it's on sale, as I feel the normal price would be a bit much for the amount of gameplay you get.

												This is an odd game. Afterwards I think to myself, "C'mon, I'm stupid for getting scared about this. As a kid we all remember snuggling with our favorite stuffed animals when the lights go out and that fact is used very well in the game. Posted: June 13, 2015
												"Amongst the Sleep" is a surprisingly good little survival horror game that invokes your primal fears by placing you in the body of a small toddler that can barely walk upright. What may seem amusing at first quickly becomes outright scary as the child's unique perception of reality turns seemingly mundane objects and locations (such as a closet or a playground) into pure nightmare fuel. Even when the twist at the end of the story reveals the toddler's terrors to be relatively normal from an adult's point of view, the anxiety and uneasiness you will experience throughout the game will not simply fade away, as it merely replaces the imaginative fear with a real one.Unfortunately, the enjoyment you can get from this game is drastically limited by it's very short length, with a walkthrough taking little more than roughly two hours. It is perhaps something to be expected from a game that evolved from a student project, but still, by the time the credits roll you may feel extremely disappointed and longing for more. For what little it's worth, the game still manages to scare the hell out of you for these two hours.

Posted: January 2, 2015
 A game to make your blood run cold This game for me, was absolutely terrifying, and anyone who says it isn't I think may not have fully emmersed themselves in the creepy and quite frankly dark story -  and it is a very dark theme , which may be an emotional trigger for some.   Theme of Alcoholism and suggested child abuse and dissociation coping mechanisms during a parental feud and divorce  I like this style of game because of the atmospheric horror style, which echoes some of the elements of "Silent Hill" puzzle solving, and the paranormal and psychological aspect from F.E.A.R. This game is not for those who are prone to panick attacks, as I myself found out the hard way. However if you are the sort of person who gets a kick out of the adrenaline while being terrified, then I thoroughly recommend this game to you. It is beautiful and horrific all at the same time.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												Among the Sleep is not your typical horror game. It is a bit short, but not as short as the 1 hour playtime that I've seen others give. I'd say it's a solid 2-3 hour game, a little more if you explore the environment (which you should). It's got a beautiful, touching story that reveals itself gradually. The environments you travel through are varied and very rich, with minimal texture reusing, which is unusual and refreshing in an indie game. The atmosphere is perfect and creepy, but not chock full of jump scares. The first parts of the game will lull you into a false sense of security. To say anything more would be a spoiler.There's no incentive to replay unless you missed a Steam achievement, and this game isn't really made for replays because the story will have been revealed. However, I think the first experience was solid enough and unique enough to stand on its own. I got it for $15.99 and thought it was well worth the price because it seems much higher quality than other indie games and I am very interested to see what else the developers can do. I highly recommend it!

Posted: November 12, 2014
												Among the Sleep is a frightening, fairytale-like, original and surprisingly resonant game that reminds us what the world looks like through the eyes of a 2-year old child. It’s a bit short, over-priced and it doesn’t quite manage to live up to its great potential, but it is definitely worth playing, especially by fans of first-person survival horror adventure games.Full review: http://adventureadvocate.gr/gamereviews/item/among-the-sleep-3

Posted: November 15, 2014
												This is another survival/exploration horror game, but one in which you play as a two year old child. Somehow, this makes the whole thing that much more terrifying, even if the game itself isn't a pants-filler like Outlast. It's not just that you're defenseless and don't want to get eaten by some monstrosity, but you also don't want the little kid you're playing to get hurt either. It definitely adds to the fear.As others have said, the game is a bit short, although they recently added some free DLC, which helps round it out a bit. The design is interesting in that it actually feels like what a toddler might imagine based on the pieces he can put together from the world and events around him. It even reminded me of snippets that I can remember from when I was a little kid, from imaginary worlds to fragments of dreams.The mechanics are relatively simple and involve a fair amount of finding Tab A and getting it into Slot B before progressing. It's a common element in many games, and at least it isn't obstructive or overt here.The story is what got to me, though. I don't want to spoil anything, but pay attention to those crayon drawings you see littering the place and various recurring themes and objects. Some parts were fairly obvious, some were a bit of a surprise, but regardless, it was heartbreaking at points. Making the player a little kid brings out the sadness of many things.I definitely recommend picking this one up. If you're wary, grab the demo or wait for a sale. Parents playing this game might just find themselves giving their kids a big hug after playing.

Posted: January 11, 2015
												Very immersive game, that had me wanting to find out the ending.    I really am drawn more to the story based, adventure style games that engage your mind to work through puzzles and reword you with more clues/pieces of the story (i.e. not so much into the quick twitch nonstop shooting games), so understand the style of games you like and take that into account when reading this review.    This Indie game was really enjoyable,   I hesitate to call it a horror game, even though I feel it fits in that category, as it does not follow the normal tactics of most horror games.    I love the use of sounds to provide the tension without the need for gore.   Another new concept (at least for me) was playing as a very small child, which added to the tension of the game as it taps into our normal protective nature for children, and made me more concerned for the characters well being.    The idea to play as a small child was genius, as it opened up new obstacles and adventures (as well allows for the concept of the story) that I had not really experienced before (things like reaching a door knob became an adventure).   The game mechanics were good and provided interesting twists...such as being able to crawl faster than you can walk (as is fitting for a small child), and being able to run for short bursts, but falling down if you run too long (again...this felt very realistic).  Graphics were ok, with a few glitches here and there, but overall decent enough (especially considering the Indie nature of this game).     I truly enjoyed the game and the story that it told.   I talked about it to my wife and friends, and while I don't think I conveyed the full affect of the game to them (they did not seem as impressed as I was), just the fact that it had me talking about it is something not a lot of games do.I highly recommend you give this game a whirl if you are into this genre of game.

												If you enjoy an immersive storyline, beautiful graphics, amazing music, and a horror aspect that blows the mind, you will fall in love with Among the Sleep. The telling of the story is from the eyes of an unnamed two year old, along with the stumbling, heavy breathing, and curiosity of a young child. The game itself isn't very long, and if you push through the story, you can be done in a matter of hours. Posted: November 22, 2014
												I really enjoyed this game. At first I didn't know what to make of it, considering its from the perspective of a toddler and was leery about getting it on that merit alone however I am extremely glad I got over it. The unique perspective of the toddler really lends to the whole story portrayed throughout the game. (sorry no spoilers :) ) DLC really does expand upon the story and though it does leave a couple more questions in the mind for possible more DLC later on down the road, what it does add does make you pause and blink. I know I did. Pros:*Unique perspective of the toddler + eye level items ( makes you have to *THINK* to get around some obstacles you'd normally just walk up to and click, in other games) *Dispite being a first person camera perspective, the shaking/movement animations do *not* incite the usual motion sickness nausea that usually accompany's such "realistic" perspective in a game. I contribute this to this game being VR compatible and that it must have gotten play tested very well to look for such problems for VR users. (don't know how many games utilize this first person camera perspective and because the camera is going EVERYWHERE, its a game I cannot play in one sit thru. Among the Sheep, does *NOT* have this problem. Was able to play through it in one sitting with much enjoyment had.)*Ambience + level music lends more to the suspense/horror as you play. ( If I'm not mistaken some of the undertones are suppose to supposedly resonate with the player to highten this suspense. Probably mistaken but if your ears are keen or have heard those tones before that may influence mood, might make the same mistake in thinking the undertones are the same. *shrug*)*The drawings, pictures and monsters = story line goodness (try and see them all!). Especially if playing pretty much uninterrupted by RL things, the monsters (there's technically two if take into consideration the DLC) really lend to the feeling of dread and will probably have you either shock/startle when they appear, or hiding in a closet from a meer noise that might possibly somehow in a far flung galaxy be indication that the monster's coming to possibly eat you, or whatever it does when the screen turns black! ( dun dun Dun!)* Teddy Bear Companion. This little guy, how they put him throughout the game, there's always this nagging feeling, just by how he talks, what he asks of your character, if you should trust him. I think because of the way the companion was made and what it adds to the game, you do have that added layer that some games lack in creating attachment to sidekicks. *Graphics=Awesome. There's not much more to be said on that point, provided you have your settings at the optimum for your system and calibrated the gamma correctly to give that spooky look, you're gonna have a great time. Even the pieces of wood have breakpoints and lines, the detail on the items the toddler has to crawl over you can tell someone put a lot of work into those little points that really bring out the mental mind trip Alice in wonderland vibe. ( Makes you almost wonder what exactly was in that happy birthday baby bottle at the begining before the cake!  Ha.) ConsUnfortunately, with how much I *loved* playing this game. I did find two picky little Cons. * End Credits. Awesome to pay respect to all the backers from ever and always but it does make the credits uber long to sit through. Took me a good few times of pressing escape before being able to get out of the long list of credits. Sitting though the whole thing on the DLC, took enough time to get up, get a drink, go use the washroom and come back in enough time for it to still be going through the R names. LOL. Certainly there has to be an easier way on the main interface to give all the backers and such recognition than a long scroll screen where its hard to catch all their names, but again, like I said. "that's me being picky." * DLC is a little hard to find. At first I didn't realize it had downloaded DLC when I first booted up the game. If it wasn't for beating the game and deciding to go back and replay some chapters, I wouldn't know that the DLC is listed in the Chapter Selection, portion of the main menu and I may have missed out on playing some EPIC DLC. The extra story the DLC adds on, especially if you play it AFTER the main game, makes one sit back and go Dayuum. Overall this is a great game and I recommend it, especially if you have time to dedicate going through an entire playthru uninterrupted. Another time I tried playing it, and I constantly had to set it down and pick it back up again, really had not as many of the features pop out or strike me as the first time, when well, you've been playing it for hours and all that ambience has gotten to you. HA! :)  I really recommend playing the DLC after the Main game, for a different perspective on the game story. I played it both with DLC first, then main game, and also Main game with DLC after. Found doing it one way over the other, tends to lend itself to one verson of understanding the story while doing the other, makes one almost ponder a complete nother.  As to what I'm talking about! Play the game! can you note the difference I"m speakin' of? Lady

												Well, I am normally not one to take to horror games in any form and I am also not one to play "ATMOSPHERIC" type games in any capacity willingly. 												Guess I just can't go away without reviewing this piece of work.   There is only one problem with this game: it's pretty much overpriced. If you like games with deep meaning, which keeps you rethinking the ending again and again, well, I can recommend "Among the Sleep" for you.   Developers literally put you into the child's body and more important: they put you into his mind.   If you would like to imagine difficult childhood of 2-year old baby, his fears, his dreams, the way he looks at world...well, that would be something like "Among the Sleep".   Wonderful piece of art. Highly recommended, especially on sales.

Posted: July 3, 2014
												I had seen a demo of this game played before I decided to buy it, and from even watching the demo I was already excited about this game. It's not often you get to play as a two year-old child running around the house escaping the "monsters" with a talking teddy bear.The point of this game is to avoid the "monsters" (spoiler-free review) in the dark while searching for objects attached to memories of your mother. You have your trusty light-up companion Teddy with you the whole way reminding you to keep quiet and be careful. The storyline is sad, so if you're easily phased, be warned. Overall, there weren't as many jump scares as I had anticipated, just a creepy atmosphere. But it's really a good game, and I'm looking forward to seeing more from this amazing company.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												The horror feeling was nicely done, not only from a toddler's perspective was it scary. The blurry screen and the shaking and wow the sounds was really haunting. It was really well done.Of course since the game is basically you playing a two-year old there is of course a limit to what you can do. It's not an all-out horror story, it's a little kid being scared and altohugh with imagination one can think of quite some scary things, it had to be as close to realistic as possible, which I lvoed and it totally achieved.I loved every level, how the details for example the particular objects scattered throughout an eare, hinted at something that was going on in the real life, but it was invading the toddler's dreams. Also they did an excellent job on giving you a false sense of security/safety in the beginning.Anyway, it was a joy to play. A simple yet invigorating to play through and excellent work on showing how real life things can affect everyone. Loved the twist and loved Teddy! So if you like horror games but are a bit of a scarecat or if you're simply looking for a quick enjoyable experience to pass the time, definitely try this one. It's got it all.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												This isn't a game you play on a laptop while hanging out with friends.  This isn't a game you play while listening to your iTunes playlist in the middle of the afternoon.  This game can only be played late at night, in the dark, with the only sound coming from your computer speakers.  When you do, you will lose yourself in the mind of our main character, a two-year-old, as he tries to make sense of the intimidating world around him.What makes this a "Horror" game does not come from gratuitous amounts of gore, or the living dead popping up out of nowhere.  It comes simply from crawling around, taking in the sights and sounds as you try to determine if what you are experiencing is real, a nightmare, or something that adults take for granted that is unsettling/horrifying to a toddler.The game doesn't last long; it only lasts a couple of hours (free DLC on the way)!  But it isn't meant to be a game that occupies your bored mind for hours and hours of replay on end.  It's meant to be an experience, and it was.  I hope you decide to try this experience as well!

Posted: July 31, 2014
												This is probably the first Survival Horror game that hit me on a psychological level. Delivering you into the body of a two year old child, you must navigate the dark and disturbing world of a troubled mind and uncover the mysterious dissappearence of your mother. Alongside you a teddy bear named "Teddy" aids you in your journey often keeping you comfort when you need it. The game sets up an interesting premise but falls short at making you feel more vulnerable as a child as opposed to any other horror game. The true feat here is how large and menacing the environments are and the illusion that every object in the game world is either falling on you or trying to pull you in. Quite often in places you dont want to go. That combined with the chilling ambient sound make for a very unnerving atmosphere. The story is well written and completely out of left field. Please buy if you consider yourself a fan of this genre.

Posted: August 1, 2014
												In Among the Sleep, by Krillbite Studio, you will take on the role of a 2 year old child who just had his birthday. You are eating cake in the arms of your mom when there is a knock at the door. This is followed by an argument, and then your mom coming back in with a present. You then fast forward to around bedtime/nap time, I'm not really sure which. It is then that the game takes on a nightmarish overlay.The visual look of this game felt like it fit with the character being a 2 year old. I'm not saying that it was rainbows and puppies, but there were those softer colors, even when everything was dark. The levels of this game were beyond creepy, especially for me because I have an almost 2 year old, so I could see myself in his shoes. There is a slight terror to knowing that something bad could happen right out of the corner of your eye. The levels span from a deserted play ground, a library in a forest, small sections of your house, and more. There are villains that creep around as well. All I have to say is you are going to need to hide from them, or you will suffer a restart of the section you are in. I also really enjoyed the companion, the teddy bear that helped me along. All I had to do was hug it and he would produce a little bit of light that would help me see through the darkness.The sounds in this game are extremely creepy. Once again it was doubley so because I have a young son, and hearing those noises creep around in a dark area would scare the pants off me at that age. I also think the voice acting in this game was spot on. I could see the roles of the mother and the teddy bear in the voices given.The controls of the game are your usual configuration with WASD, shift to run, ctrl to crawl or get up, space to climb, and the mouse to control the camera and interact with objects.Though this game wasn't as long as I would have hoped, it definitely had enough there to keep me on my toes, and hoping that nothing was going to get me around the next corner. There is just something about this game that awakened long gone fears of my childhood, and the fear of what is in the dark. In this respect the developers did a great job. To be honest I can't really think of anything I found clunky or missing from this game. I will tell you this, the twist is a hell of one, and I'm not going to tell you what it is because you need to play this game to find out, but when the game ends everything kind of makes better sense.There were definitely puzzle aspects to this game, most of the time it was moving objects so that you could get to a different location, but there were a couple of times where the developers threw in a mechanism just for a small section of the game that changed things up a little. A couple examples of this would be throwing objects to knock something off a shelf, or collecting a specific type of object so that you could weigh down the end of something so you could get to the other side. I'm not saying that this was a bad thing, but I would have liked to see a little bit more of these mechanics, to do them once and then seeming to throw them away made me feel like they were afterthoughts in the game creation process.So lets get down to the part that most of you want to know, and that is should you play this game. The answer is yes, you should play this game, and you should play it in the dark, at night, and pray that no one sneaks up behind you while you are playing. This game gets an 8.9 out of 10.

Posted: January 10, 2015
												Let's get this out of the way right now, this is not a horror game.  This is an adventure game with some scary bits in it.  The more important part is that you understand the story and not that you♥♥♥♥♥♥yourself.  That being said, let's talk about the pros and cons. Pros  Good Graphics Sounds are very fitting and well recorded When it wants to get scary it does so very well Creative mechanics that make use of the player being a baby Interesting puzzles Surreal setting that's very weird in a good way Cons  Paper thin story that you can figure out by the 2nd chapter or less Kinda short for 20 bucks (havent played DLC yet) Some of the less interesting puzzles boil down to finding a thing to unlock another thing Game doesn't get scary until halfway throughIn short, it's an interesting game that, while scary in some parts, is more of an adventure game than a horror game.  It has a mediocre and forgettable story that could have been done better and seems like it was trying way too hard to be art.  It's still a good time though, but for 2 hours the price may be a little steep.  There is free DLC that I haven't played yet though, this is just a review on the original game.  I recommend that people go into Among the Sleep with an open mind and not expect something that's not there.Final Grade: 8.75/10

Posted: March 9, 2015
												At only 3 hours of gameplay (including the very short prologue DLC), some might consider Among the Sleep a poor investment for their gaming dollars.  To those, I ask, how much did you spend on your last trip to the movie theater, and after you watched it, did you find yourself thinking about the deeper meanings of it, or wanting to talk to others to explain how moving it was?That is this game.  Short, true, but longer than an average movie, and definitely far more engaging.  Among the Sleep manages to do more in those few levels than most big-budget franchise games have accomplished in their entire series.  Playing from the perspective of a toddler, from the difference in size, to the inability to jump, to the general sounds and movement styles, is the key element that makes this game different, but not what makes the game great.  The fascination that you see repeated over and over again in reviews comes from the subtle, yet powerful, story-behind-the-story.  Yes, you're a toddler, wandering around the house with a teddy bear.  But the real story lies behind the "why."Fans of horror games like Amnesia will enjoy this, while fans of action games will probably want to pass.

Posted: November 1, 2015
												This is an excellent, short, little horror game. Playing as a child is perfect starting point as you are so helpless and vulnerable, you can either walk slowly or crawl but you cannot see too far when crawling. The atmosphere is what makes this game so good. It starts off with a very creepy oppressive atmosphere where you never know what dangers are lurking. Then just when you are thinking it is only a sinister atmosphere and there are no actual threats you catch a glimpse of enemies. There are no really cheap jump scares but lots of menacing corner of the screen glimpses of things and when you do first get caught by the enemy it is terrifying. So this manages to maintain the atmosphere throughout that game where you are never sure if you are in danger or not. My only complaint is that some of the camera movements when climbing made me a little nauseous.

Posted: October 29, 2015
Summary 7.9/10A purely story-driven adventure that has no other direction but forward, but a good pace and experience in general leaves you satisfiedThe Good:- Great scares- Good use of tactics and required "know-how"- Cute, but bat-sh*t crazy- Dark and Eery, while also being justified- Sense of justice and acomplishment in the end- Strong connection with protagonist (At least for me.)- Great use of ambient soundThe Bad:- Expensive for so little time I put into it and completed it- Abysmal voice acting- Disappointing ending, although conclusive- Repetitious- Sudden cuts in audio and poor blending- Constant clipping, and extremely obviousConclusionAmong the Sleep is a lot like an Italian dessert. Its absurdly small, it's a poor decision, expensive and somewhat unhealthy in structure, but overall tasty and satisfying. If you loved Slender, play this. If the theme itself interests you, go for it. If you are looking for a long-lasting meal with dessert at the end, find another. It's good, but nothing I'd ever probably order again.

Posted: January 2, 2015
 A game to make your blood run cold This game for me, was absolutely terrifying, and anyone who says it isn't I think may not have fully emmersed themselves in the creepy and quite frankly dark story -  and it is a very dark theme , which may be an emotional trigger for some.   Theme of Alcoholism and suggested child abuse and dissociation coping mechanisms during a parental feud and divorce  I like this style of game because of the atmospheric horror style, which echoes some of the elements of "Silent Hill" puzzle solving, and the paranormal and psychological aspect from F.E.A.R. This game is not for those who are prone to panick attacks, as I myself found out the hard way. However if you are the sort of person who gets a kick out of the adrenaline while being terrified, then I thoroughly recommend this game to you. It is beautiful and horrific all at the same time.

Posted: October 19, 2015
												Long story short: Get it on sale at < $10. It's good.I was following the crowd-funding campaign and development of this game somewhat close and was super excited after playing the Alpha that was released.The game definitely does not disappoint when it comes to presentation: Killbrite ♥♥♥♥ing kills it when it comes to atmosphere. I was completely immersed most of the time and I noticed my mouth was agape a lot. The art style is qwerky by design seeing as how it's through the lens of a toddler and the sections where fear alters the environment is really awesome.The sound design of this game is super on point. All the little creaks and cracks in the environment as well as the occasional loud breathing of the protagonist kept me on edge even when there was no perceivable threat. Hearing the mother character humming a lullaby when you were near the end of your objective was assuring but the somber melody is super creepy at the same time.Where this game falls somewhat short is in the actual gameplay. The puzzles are so laughably easily, a baby can do them......*crickets*...whatever. Anyway, most of the game is classic horror: Try a door >♥♥♥♥♥♥s locked > look for key > traverse level looking for key > get key > open door > move on to next level. The perspective is somewhat unique in that you're a tiny babby ♥♥♥♥♥-his-pants so you have to find creative ways to traverse an environment, which largely includes moving chairs to climb them to open doors or opening drawers to climb them.My biggest gripe with the game is actually the length. I beat it in 2 hours and I'm ♥♥♥♥ing dog♥♥♥♥♥♥at video games. A good player can prolly beat it in an hour or less. Which is why you should get it for less than $10 and you won't be disappointed.Or don't, whatever. ♥♥♥♥ you.

Posted: October 19, 2015
												While the idea behind this game is interesting, I found it to be poorly executed. The story itself is interesting enough, if a little predictable. The overall atmosphere isn't bad either. The gameplay is where the game lost me. You spend 70% of the game trudging back and forth to collect keys/items to solve arbitrary puzzles that block the way forward. The puzzles are nothing more than fluff since there's no danger or real skill involved in solving them and it's literally just walking to one end of the room to collect an item and then walking back. Considering the game is already so short, taking these puzzles out would leave you with about 20 minutes of game. It took me a little more then 2 hours to complete the main game and DLC and most of the time was spent trundling back and forth trying to figure out which hidden corner I forgot to search to progress to the next area. The monster is barely ever a threat and the few times you actually have to run from it are over in just a few seconds. Overall, this might be worth playing if you pick it up in a bundle or on sale, but I'd be upset if I paid the full 20 bucks they're asking.

												Basically a light version of Amnesia that can nonetheless stand on its own thanks to its concept and story.Pros:-concept of being a toddler,from the point of view,to the movement and sounds,it works well and really immerses you in the game world-sound,extremely well done,unsettling,same goes for the musical cues used-story,how it ties with real event is quite unsettling-tension is well done and mantained through the gameNeutral (but could be a factor for you):-basic puzzles-not really reliant on enemies,save a few sectionsCons:-short,I'd say from 2 to 3 hours,plus 20-30 mind of Prologue in the free DLC-sometimes jumping on things isn't as smooth as it should be-a few clipping problems can get in the way of the immersionOverall,I'd really recommend it if you liked Amnesia and similar games...I'd wait for a 50% sale though due to its overall shortness.

Posted: January 28, 2015
												I was pretty nervous during the introductory phase, then I NOPEd out pretty quick once the Groots actually started killing me. There's a reason I don't play a lot of horror games. But I watched the rest of it on youtube and I gotta say, this game is absolutely genius. So many things to love about it, in terms of both narrative and gameplay. If you've ever been reading and come across something profound and your reaction is "yes! someone else said it!", you'll have a lot of moments like that during this game if you think through the implications of what you're being shown.The horror comes in two flavors: gentle suggestion of a threat that causes you to scare yourself via the power of imagination, and actual Slender-esque sequences that will result in a game over. We get the former exclusively for about the first 2/3rds of the game, and it works extremely well although it might wear out it's welcome if the player decides that the game is all bark and no bite. However, after a seemingly arbitrary point you will start dying, and it will seem random and arbitary, which is of course jarring as hell once you're good and tired of the game being harmless. My only issue with this is that you aren't given any indication that this change has happened, and the advice on how to deal with it came 20 or 30 minutes ago. Basically just try not to make noise since that's what usually causes the Groots to spawn, and if they spawn anyway just run.All-around it's a genius game and I hope it gets some quality imitators. 10/10 would reccomend.

Posted: June 2, 2014
												This game is absolutely amazing. The controls are tight, the music and ambient sound never let up, and the visuals really capture the feel of a world from a small child's perspective. And the story, without giving anything away, will disturb you and might even make you think.The controls feel very similar to Amnesia, at least in the sense of how you interact with the world. Opening doors and turning valves, picking up objects to throw, rotate, or carry, and using the bear as a flashlight will all feel very familiar to players that have braved the halls of Castle Brennenburg.The audio, in all its forms, is unrelenting. Even the lack of audio at times will fill you with such a sense of impending dread that you will slowly and cautiously navigate the surrounding. And sometimes even the slightest 'bang' or 'crash' will send you scurrying towards any safe haven, for fear of something coming up behind you.The visuals have such a grasp of a child's imagination it is uncanny. Words are as scribbles, sense a child cannot comprehend them, and drawings litter the worlds, as if a tiny person is giving you clues that you can easily understand without a spoken or written language. And the literal perspective of everything towering over you really draw on the feeling of helplessness in an unknown place, with only your teddy bear as comfort.Overall, this is a delightful horror gem. There is no reason to only catch it on a sale, for fear of it being underwhelming. If you enjoy horror games with thought, puzzles, and huge atmosphere, then 'Among the Sleep' is an absolute must have.

Posted: June 3, 2014
												Okay, so it took me 2 hours to beat the game. You could even beat it in 1 hour if you don't stop to look at every little thing like I did. I even died 2 times and had to reload from a checkpoint 3 times. So yeah, if you don't die, don't encounter bugs that force you to reload the checkpoint and don't stop to admire the scenery, you'll be able to beat the game in a little under 40 minutes. Dead serious. So the game is short, what else? It's buggy. Really buggy... In chapter 3 (I think, the water level), I pressed F when I was under a chair and suddenly, me legs are in the floor. I press F again and I am now falling through the map. In the next chapter where the drawer extends to no limits, that drawer for me was... like misplaced or something, because I saw it come out from the wall rather than the hole it's supposed to come out of, so I was forced to reload the checkpoint. Lots of times you can get stuck almost anywhere, but like 80% of the time, you can get out. I still recommend it though, as it is scary and it's a good story, though maybe not explained/told that well and some may miss the point (below, you can read how I interpreted the story, so if you don't want any spoilers, you can end here). Imagine... you're just a baby crawling on your tiny little legs and arms and you have to go through a nightmare-ish land with your teddy and there are monsters just lurking to kill you. Although I wish the game was longer...WARNING! SPOILERThat nightmare-ish land... it has to do with the child's mother. It feels like the kid is terrified of her and imagines her as those monsters and the locations we are in are drawn from the books he read and the house itself. So the game has some psychological stuff in it too, which is interesting.

Posted: June 8, 2014
												   This game is short. It FEELS very short. It pulls you into its creepy and perfectly executed atmosphere, but that feeling of knowing you are close to the end really saps your joy from the journey when it arrives so quickly.      The terrified and overly imaginative perspective of an infant is perfect. You must cling to your teddy bear for comfort (A source of light) and every scene in the game seems like it takes place in one's imagination.    I've played 4 1/2 hours and it's hard to want to go back to it since it feels so linear. However, I'll ride a short roller coaster over and over if it is still fun. I love the feel of the game because it's unique it still felt unique even after playing games like Amnesia and Penumbra. The story and symbolism is what makes me want to play through it multiple times.    "Mind-F" and "Jaw-dropper" of an ending and intense scares throughout make this game amazing. I screamed a lot and I had been thinking about this game for days after completing it

Posted: February 7, 2015
												Among the Sleep is a different sort of horror game in that it utilizes jump scares, creepy ambiance, and heartpumping adrenaline spikes rather than outright gory, bloody, horror. It's whimsically odd in aspects that are reminiscent of Alice in Wonderland, and creepy in aspects that closely resemble that of Slender/Amnesia. It's fun to play, might even get you a few times with some scares, and is completely worth it.This game surprised me in more ways than I expected. I was consistently trying to figure out the plot and whenever I thought I had it, it would change on me. The bear for one is somewhat creepy on it's own, and when you first begin to meet and interact with Teddy it feels very reminsicent of Chucky. As the game plays forward however, Teddy is your best friend in the entire world, as you navigate through a world that feels like the "Other Mother" built it (Coraline reference!). There's simple puzzles to complete to progress as you go, but they aren't mind-numbingly simple, some of them take a few minutes to put together.The story itself gives a fresh new way of looking at this kind of situation through a child's perspective. You're playing as a two year old child, and your objective is to rescue your mother from this nightmarish, topsy-turvey, alternate version of your own world. The ambiance is amazing, and the graphics are impeccable. It can get truly terrifying.I bought this game on a daily deal for 66% off. Among the Sleep isn't a very long game, it's only roughly 3 hrs of playthrough, so I feel better about paying 6$ vs 20$ to be honest. It's gamepad compatable, and if you're using a pc with Windows it goes without saying that it's recommended you use an Xbox 360 controller.It's fun, short, but not so sweet! If you can swing it, pick up Among the Sleep and play it, it's worth it.

Posted: June 3, 2014
												Among the Sleep. A horror from 2 years old perspective. Sounds rather interesting, don't you agree? I was waiting for the game since the start of the Kickstarter campaign. And to my embitterment, the game has disappointed me.First of all - this game is supposed to be a horror. While the game has that uncomfortable atmosphere, it failed to scare me even once (and I'm rather easy to scare off). Sudden loud noises (and many sounds like rustle, sound of something being scraped etc.)   lightning pop-ups, "monsters", which look like they were taken from a kid's cartoon - they are not scary for a grown-up. I would understand if the game was positioned as horror for kids, but it wasn't.Second - graphics. The design of the game is well made. Everything looks good  and not out of order, like a child would've seen (big scary coats in the dark closet, big furniture and other stuff like that). The only con is glitchy textures - they tended to disappear on my PC. Audio. Except sudden loud noises, music is very well made. It's very atmospheric and goes well with the game. Gameplay. The game is very straight - the objective of the game is to collect "memories" and find your mom. While doing so, you will face various obstacles (from closed doors, on which you can not reach the door knob and need to place a chair and got on it first to closed doors where you would need a key). When you need to reach high places, you will need to climb on them  using drawers, chairs and other thing. It's fun, but repetitive. The great thing is the message that the story holds (review  is spoiler free, so I'll just note that).One thing has bothered me - why a two year old child can push very heavy objects, throwing some of them  at a distance of two meters, climbing without taking a break like a professional athlete? Big chairs, tires - two year old doesn't have that amount strength. The game was promised to last for at least 3 hours, but I finished it in 90 minutes. It's really short for the money it costs. 20€ (18 with discount) is TOO much. You can buy it for 5, but not 20 Euro.So, in the end:Pros:+ Music+ Atmosphere-+ Graphics (+- because of glitchy textures)+ StoryCons:- The non-existent horror part- Repetitive gameplay- Baby has super strength- Very short- OverpricedConclusion: If you want to play this game, wait for big sale or you'll just overpay like I did. 5/10

												The story is really solid and compelling, the pacing basically perfect, and the tension/horror is top notch. The environments are fairly linear but for the most part you don't really feel it - they're desined to make you think you're not really on a set path, and it works. Posted: June 27, 2014
												This isn't a game you play on a laptop while hanging out with friends.  This isn't a game you play while listening to your iTunes playlist in the middle of the afternoon.  This game can only be played late at night, in the dark, with the only sound coming from your computer speakers.  When you do, you will lose yourself in the mind of our main character, a two-year-old, as he tries to make sense of the intimidating world around him.What makes this a "Horror" game does not come from gratuitous amounts of gore, or the living dead popping up out of nowhere.  It comes simply from crawling around, taking in the sights and sounds as you try to determine if what you are experiencing is real, a nightmare, or something that adults take for granted that is unsettling/horrifying to a toddler.The game doesn't last long; it only lasts a couple of hours (free DLC on the way)!  But it isn't meant to be a game that occupies your bored mind for hours and hours of replay on end.  It's meant to be an experience, and it was.  I hope you decide to try this experience as well!

Posted: August 5, 2015
												TLDR: I highly recommend Among The Sleep.  It's beautiful, immersive, thought provoking, and genuinely creepy.  There are few games like Among The Sleep, in fact as of now it may very well be entirely unique.  Not only does it put the player into the unique perspective of a two-year-old, it actually manages to maintain that perspective by never forcing you to do something that the average toddler couldn't.  In fact, it could well be said that this provides a significant portion of the game's difficulty.  While the challenges and puzzles are simple, so too are the actions you can take to complete them.  You can't throw a ball more than a few feet, you can't even reach doorknobs without finding something to stand on.  If something comes out to get you, you'd better believe you can't fight back, in fact you can't even run very far without tripping and falling on your face.  While we're on the subject of running from something that's come out to get you, I should mention something else that isn't nearly common enough among games: the ability to present both sections which are adorable, and sections which are downright chilling.  For instance, the character Teddy ranks very high among the cutest I've ever seen, while the Water Woman is easily one of the creepiest and well made out monsters I've ever seen.Speaking of exceptional design, the entire game fits that category to a T.  The levels are beautifully surreal, often melding bright colors with deep shadow to stunning effect, all the while employing an excellent soundtrack with plenty of auditory cues to help the player along.  The voice acting is superb; it's as good as, or better than, most AAA titles.Of course, nothing is perfect, and Among The Sleep is no exception.  There were a few minor glitches, ranging from a small section of wall in a closet which didn't display properly, to a case where my toddler failed to enter a closet and was subsequently caught by one of the beasties.  In all fairness, I'm not entirely sure I was supposed to be able to get in there in the first place.  Regardless, another issue I had was that there were a few times where I was pretty clearly supposed to be listening for the current monster to avoid it, and, well it sounded like it was coming from everywhere at once.  Honestly though, all that is very nitpicky stuff, and I've ignored far more glaring errors in games which had two orders of magnitude more development staff.  By far the most significant flaw is, in my opinion, the length of the game.  I probably took about three and a half hours to get entirely through it, and I spent a good bit of time smelling the proverbial roses along the way.  I'm pretty confident that I could do a speed run in half the time if I tried.  But before we judge it too harshly for its length, let's take a moment to consider that, so long as you take your time to enjoy the game's art and ambiance (and if you don't then I don't know why you're playing it), the price you're paying per unit time-being-entertained is no more than for a trip to the movies.

Posted: December 25, 2014
												Definitely recommended. The great thing about indie studios is that they bring you experiences that are truly different, and Among the Sleep is no exception. No combat, no complicated puzzles, just the experience of how it feels to be a baby and not truly understand the world. It is a sad story, but poignant. It is a little on the short side however, and some of the level design is a little more odd than scary. But there are some very tense moments that make the experience worthwhile. A big plus as well is that it is a horror game without gore or demonism, so if those things typically put you off about this genre don't worry, you won't find them here.

Posted: December 12, 2014
												Good storytelling but predictable and ruined by the bear.I wouldn't recommend this game except for the way it handled the storytelling.  Even though I figured out everything by the second painting, I felt it did a good job getting the whole feel across from a young child's perspective.The game isn't really scary, although it conveys the same sort of childhood 'spookiness' that a dark house and strange sounds bring.  That is it's greatest strength, conveying a nightmare from a child's perspective -- full of strange places and monsters.  This emersion is then quickly ruined by the addition of the damn teddy bear pulled out of some children's show who you HAVE to take with you and who ruins everything.It controlls well, looks good, and conveys a feeling of helplessness that a two-year old child would have along with the potential havoc and trouble a two-year old can get into.  At least, until the bear opens his stupid mouth again.I can't state this enough, but the bear ruins the whole experience by talking.  Listening to him suffer in the washing machine or trying to hang on to you is one thing; I hated him from the get-go but even I felt bad for him at those points.  If they cut out his dialogue and just left him emotion he would have been an excellent companion, but as implemented he screams "HELLO YOU ARE IN A GAME WITH TALKING BEAR WHO POINTS OUT THE OBVIOUS".The game is short, and it would have been a nice bit of art if everyone would learn to shut up.  As is, I think some people will enjoy it a lot and ultimately what it does well it does well enough that I can forgive the rest.  This game is NOT for you if:1. You are immune to childhood fears2. You want a long game (I've logged 3 hrs and that includes taking the time to write swears in blocks)3. You want a scary game (unless you are very vulnerable to childhood fears, in which case this is for you)4. You hate physics puzzlesThis game IS for you if:1. You are vulnerable to childhood fears and like being haunted by them.2. You enjoyed the demo (despite how badly the bear ruins the experirence)3. You like 'artistic' game experiences and an interactive way of telling a story.I'm personally in the middle, and would have recommended this stronger if the bear was mostly mute as well.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												The horror feeling was nicely done, not only from a toddler's perspective was it scary. The blurry screen and the shaking and wow the sounds was really haunting. It was really well done.Of course since the game is basically you playing a two-year old there is of course a limit to what you can do. It's not an all-out horror story, it's a little kid being scared and altohugh with imagination one can think of quite some scary things, it had to be as close to realistic as possible, which I lvoed and it totally achieved.I loved every level, how the details for example the particular objects scattered throughout an eare, hinted at something that was going on in the real life, but it was invading the toddler's dreams. Also they did an excellent job on giving you a false sense of security/safety in the beginning.Anyway, it was a joy to play. A simple yet invigorating to play through and excellent work on showing how real life things can affect everyone. Loved the twist and loved Teddy! So if you like horror games but are a bit of a scarecat or if you're simply looking for a quick enjoyable experience to pass the time, definitely try this one. It's got it all.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												Among the Sleep is not your typical horror game. It is a bit short, but not as short as the 1 hour playtime that I've seen others give. I'd say it's a solid 2-3 hour game, a little more if you explore the environment (which you should). It's got a beautiful, touching story that reveals itself gradually. The environments you travel through are varied and very rich, with minimal texture reusing, which is unusual and refreshing in an indie game. The atmosphere is perfect and creepy, but not chock full of jump scares. The first parts of the game will lull you into a false sense of security. To say anything more would be a spoiler.There's no incentive to replay unless you missed a Steam achievement, and this game isn't really made for replays because the story will have been revealed. However, I think the first experience was solid enough and unique enough to stand on its own. I got it for $15.99 and thought it was well worth the price because it seems much higher quality than other indie games and I am very interested to see what else the developers can do. I highly recommend it!

												Play as a two foot tall baby exploring the world through his eyes. Manipulate objects around you to your advantage; use dressers as staircases and tables and chairs as cover. Sound effects/details are great, from creaks of wooden floors to distant footsteps. Highly recommend!

Posted: November 22, 2015
												I just finished my first play through. It took a couple of months to finish because I played a few minutes at a time, but it took me about an hour to finish the game.I loved the experience. I'm a mom of a 2-year-old, which is why I bought the game in the first place. The story is heartbreaking and most of what's creepy about this comes from the fact that this is a neglected child. Can't get much worse than that :(That said, I'm not an expert on child psychology, but it's funny, and I say this as a mom, how accurate the game is when it comes to being a toddler. They do climb on chairs and drawers and do dangerous things without considering what could go wrong. The mechanics are totally plausible.It's very clear that the world and the events are how a very young, abused child sees them: distorted. This is also why the game is so scary, you kinda go through the house looking for your mommy but at the same time know that if you make a mistake (e.g. break a bottle), you'll regret it. Fear of someone you love is just terrible, especially if you're so vulnerable, and this game does a great job of getting you in that state of mind. This game has a great story and it makes you think about childhood, especially as a parent!

Tried to unlock an easy one at the start of the game (checked a few walkthroughs to make sure I was doing it right) but to no avail... Reading through the discussions, achievements seem to be hit and miss but I can't find anyone else who have unlocked none at all.That being said, I do recommend people have a go at this. It's a nice horror game with a different idea.

Posted: December 11, 2015
												Among the Sleep really surprised me!  It was much scarier than I anticipated and I found the story to be intelligently weaved into the gameplay.  The setting, the atmosphere, the controls – all of it fits together perfectly to achieve the mythical “Immersive” factor that so many games fall short of. Typical scare tactics are utilized to keep you in suspense; but there is also a more personalized fear that comes from being able to connect your own childhood fears to the obstacles that the child must overcome.  Entertainment value aside, Among the Sleep affords you the opportunity to face some of those latent fears from early development and gives parents a better perspective of what their child may be suffering through.

Posted: September 29, 2014
												I've heard a lot of complaints about how this game isn't scary, or that it's too short for the price you're paying, but I have to say I loved this game. The price is understandable since it is the first full game krillbite has put out and if it really bothers you that much pick it up on a sale it goes for half the cost. The atsmosphere is really a lot more important than the horror itself I feel like and it does nail that down pretty solidly. One of my favorite things about this game is how accurately it captures playing as a two year old. The movements, the perspective on reality, the fact that your teddy bear can walk and talk and you don't even consider questioning it, all that together just made for a really solid immersive experience. I really enjoyed this game quite a bit and I'm looking forward to seeing what krillbite will come out with in the future.

Posted: September 29, 2014
												If nothing else then this is a pretty interesting game.  The last time I can remember playing as an infant was in the beginning of Fallout 3.  The game seems to be about the atmosphere, environment, and getting through a spooky situation as a scared infant carrying a teddy bear (which functions as a flashlight when hugged).  I didn't find the entertainment being so much in the actual gameplay as trying to interpret what this child is seeing into what the real situation was supposed to be.  The downside of this game is that puzzle solving and entertaining gameplay is at a minimum and the game itself should take at most three hours to finish and if you push it then you could probably finish in one or two hours.  I would advise if you have any interest in this game put it on your wishlist and pick it up when it goes on a holiday sale.

Posted: September 23, 2014
												I have played a lot of horror games. Some excellent, and a lot of not so excellents : there's a ton of "oh look ! Amnesia is scary because you can't defend against the monster you must hide and run away ! MAGIC INGREDIENT TO SCARE !!!!" games that definitly didn't understand that there's more than pop monster and run. So when one of the indie horror game community appear to be different, all I can do is recommend it.Among the sleep brings a real great atmosphere of dreams and nightmares, Alice in Wonderlands type, showing a coherent view of a house at night from a 2 years old child who just want her mother back. Everything seems higher, noise louder, cracking sounds like growling. That's a great job indeed, the gameplay fitting perfectly to this 2 year old.Graphics and animation are quite decent, sometimes really good, the voice acting is great, and the story simple but effective.There's two bad point to the game : it's too short, which lead to the second bad points, it's a bit expensive for what it offers.But I'm not hiding my pleasure, I'm glad I bought it. If you feel like supporting the team, buy it, otherwise, you might want to wait for a steam reduction. But this is a game you need if you like scary and dark style.

												Among the Sleep is a great short horror game. Even though I didn't find it too scary, I found the atmosphere to be very tense and enjoyed it all the same. The game is original in the aspect that it is from the perspective of a toddler, which is what grabbed my attention as someone who doesn't play horror games.My main complaint is that the game is seriously short; I completed the game in around 2 hours, which is unnacceptable given its price tag. Posted: November 10, 2014
												Before I begin, this game is very good. So when i first heard of Among the Sleep and started looking into it, it looked like a cool game with a good concept, one where you play as a child. This idea is brilliantly shown in the actual game with everything being bigger or twisted in some way due to children seeing things differently to adults. In terms of the gameplay, this game is clever. You can alternate between standing and crawling as well as using items such as chairs to reach higher places i.e. a door handle. In terms of what the game does best it is its approach to horror and tension. It doesnt throw out a lot of jump scares with it building up tension using sights and sounds for instance a passing glimpse of some other creature or hearing a door slam. It is nearer the end of the game in which you start to encounter some other creaturs but I am not saying how this is done. Overall this game is clever and very good even though it is only 2-3 hours long. Also the recently released free downloadable content adds a strong 20 minutes of additional gameplay, one which is a prologue to the events of the main game. I would thorougly recommend this game to anyone.

Posted: September 14, 2014
												A well made an atmospheric game, with a really fresh perspective on first person horror - but quite short.I clocked it in about 2 and a half hours (had it alt+tabbed while I tended to my actual toddler).Lavishly designed in a really vibrant and alarming style, and controls that are really clever.Not sure it's worth a $20 price point, but on sale it was perfect.

Posted: September 14, 2014
												Assuming the role of a todder on their second birthday, players of Among the Sleep go on a dark, atmospheric journey that expertly plays on childhood fears and anxieties to create an immersive, if uneven, experience. After being put to bed by their mother, the player interacts with their new birthday present: Teddy the teddy bear. Teddy guides the player out of the bright, warm bedroom and into a dark, forbidding world. Stuck in this world away from their mother, the player must explore the dark environments and solve puzzles to recieve items which represent fond memories of their mother. The player explores the world by slowly walking through the environments or by crawling, which is much faster. The player is able to climb over obstacles and interact with many objects in the world. In dark areas, the player can hold Teddy tight, making the toddler feel more confident and lighting the way. The design is minimalistic and encourages the player to immerse themselves in the toddler's world. The environments are distorted perceptions of a normal household. The dark tone makes things appear more menacing than they would normally, adding to the tense atmosphere. In several environments, a dark presence hunts the player, forcing them to hide. The gameplay in these sections feel similar to Slender: The Arrivial but requires the player to hide, rather than run away, adding to the tension.Among the Sleep is short but still feels repetitive toward the end. The final section is satisfying enough to warrant a playthrough and the game as a whole delievers a well crafted psychological experience.

Posted: September 12, 2014
												At first glance, the game seems a little pricey for the hours logged. But, one thing that is worth noting is that the game has very little down time. The pacing is good and the game alterantes primarily between suspence and intensity. Had it been longer, it would have worn out its charm. And had it been less expensive... Well, everyone has to make a living, and I'm sure a lot of work went the game. It's very polished and the visuals and sound are fantastic, so I don't feel ripped off. The two hours (ish... I left it paused for a little while) I got from the game were as fulfilling as any "full length" game, just condensed. I think a lot of people expect more out of games in terms of value, but that doesn't always seem fair. Considering how much you end up paying to see a movie at the theater, or for a a few rounds of drinks at a bar, this game starts to look like a pretty good deal. Overall, no matter how much you think you're getting ripped off, chances are good that a video game is still the best value in terms of hours per dollars spent.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												The game delivers on its promise of being a non-violent horror game, seen through the eyes of a toddler. It doesn't have the greatest graphics in the world, but in this fantasy world that's not really necessary either. The only place where it bothers a bit is when the game tries to render humans,. But luckily there's only one (mommy) and we only see her very briefly.The formula revolves around navigating levels and collecting items in order to advance, whilst remaining unseen by the scary evil that roams the world. And let me tell you, when it is near, you feel its presence. This is where the game really distinguishes itself in my opinion: the evil presence is quite scary, and it will make you play it cautious so as to not invoke its wrath. Very well executed.There's little replay value though, and even the extra story in the free DLC was unnecessary in my opinion. It's also a step down from the main storyline if you ask me. It failed to captivate me because of its repetitive formula and unreasonable expectations of wilful suspension of disbelief compared to the main storyline. Then again, nobody forces you to play it, and the main storyline is definitely worth it even if it doesn't have a lot of replay value. For this reason I suggest you may perhaps want to wait for a sale.The game has a free demo, which is not something you see often. I haven't played it, but if you're curious I'd suggest you take it for a spin.

Posted: July 4, 2016
												The concept of using a two-year old as the protagonist is obviously ingenious, though somewhat undercut by how you can do stuff that is clearly just not possible for a kid that age - as the game uses a first-person view so we don't see the main character either. At times it feels like pretty much the only indicator that it's a two-year old is that the game makers have told us so. This becomes especially true when the game abandons its initial setting - the home of the kid and its mother - and dives into more surreal territory. The loving home that suddenly becomes haunted and scary works much more efficently than what takes its place a bit into the story.  Also, the graphics feel somewhat generic (with the important exception of the monster, which looks great),However, while Among the sleep is far from perfect, it's still haunting and pulls off its thematic ambitions in a smart and ultimately successful way. And for all the reservations mentioned above, having such an extremly vulnerable main character works wonders for the horror aspect of the game.

Posted: August 6, 2016
												The game is surprisingly short (ca. 2-3 hours if you take your timex to explore each and every corner, 1 hour if you are of the fast paced type) but well made and definitely entertaining. The unique approach to play this adventure in the role of a 2-year old child and the beautiful (sometimes scary) dream-like scenes make Among the Sleep stand out from the large amount of story driven adventure games that currently flood the market. However, it could be longer and also more challenging - just because you play a 2-year old does't mean that the challanges also need to be on that level. The ending leaves room for personal interpretation and further discussion - maybe even a part 2?

Posted: February 2, 2016
												An atmospheric horror game that puts you in the footie pajamas of a toddler. You've just received a cute teddy bear for your birthday that lights up when you squeeze it, and comes to life when your mother's not around. In the middle of the night, you realise that a shadowy monster is stalking you, and with teddy in hand you must locate your missing mother by finding sentimental items connected to your memories of her. As you explore your home, you slowly realise that things are far darker than they seem.Among the Sleep is truly terrifying, mostly due to the POV. Playing as a toddler with what amounts to only a night light, your only defense is to hide from danger under tables, in closets, and beneath bookcases. You can only run away for a short amount of time before falling to the ground and having to crawl, or push yourself back up to your feet. The scenery alone, just being so much larger and daunting, really adds to a feeling of helplessness.While I really enjoyed this game, its price is far too high for how short it actually is. Buy it on sale to enjoy it as much as you can.

Posted: January 26, 2016
												Among the Sleep is a very inventive and imaginative game concept, the main focus is experiencing the world through the imagined perception a 2 year old will create when confronted with something frightening.The game's many subtle references hints at an overarching story beyond what you play, but I won't say anything that may spoil that.Personally I don't really like horror games, the concept never really appealed to me, I can enjoy one but I usually won't go out of my way to play one, this game is a bit different though, it is a horror game but it's not so much an actual threat that's scary, instead it's more of an imagined threat the player experiences from the atmosphere, there are some actual threats from time to time but it's the atmosphere that unerves me a bit more (Yeah, I'm a wimp, I know you're thinking it).In terms of gameplay, I got a good 3-4 hours of gameplay out of this game and its DLC, I really enjoyed what I played but the game really doesn't have much replayability, I got it during a sale for about £4, I don't think the game is worth £10.99, It's a good game, just not THAT good.Anyway, all in all, a very enjoyable experience and well worth your time, I'd say just wait for a sale though.
