The music, graphics and "baby logic" throughout the game is great. Only thing that is sad is that I completed the game with half of the acheivments in about 3 hours, so it isnt a long game. Still, I liked it and am happy I bought it.

Posted: January 12, 2016
												Among the Sleep is one interesting horror game. Made by norwegian students as university project, I honestly thought this would be hastily slapped together game with interesteting premise, but underwhelming delivery.Boy was I wrong!So here it goes, and remember TL;DR is always at the bottom. Positives:  1.  Story is kept simple, yet interesting at the same time. You play as a baby exploring this nightmarish realm with help from your toy teddy bear. Prologue chapter does good job introducing characters and game mechanics and the baby perspective is pretty damn interesting since it gives this huge opportunity to run wild with creativity and imagination.To be honest, I can't tell too much about story since I'm afraid of giving anything away, but it is surprisingly serious and excellently crafted. 2.  Gameplay is pretty straight forward. Go/ crawl from A to B solving puzzles and sometimes hiding in closets/ under tables or beds. It's basically a Penumbra/ Amnesia clone but with baby as protagonist. But hey, if it works, don't break it, right? 3.  Levels are pretty linear but still very well made. Every location feels unique, looks both interesting and scary and breathes atmosphere. I have to give credits where credit is due, guys over at Krillbite did amazing job bringing this game to life. 4.  Sounds and music are also pretty damn good. Game relies heavily on creepy sounds to make you feel uneasy and does good job with it. Music is used sparingly but when♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan, effect is simpy amazing and terrifying at the same time. When talking about voice work and dialogue, there's not much to it really, since characters don't speak that much, but they are good enough. 5.  Graphics, while not amazing, works just fine. Game is mostly dark, so shadows and lighting effect are only factors that really count, and can make or break it's setting. Thankfully both effects are used very well. Because of this, first level is worse looking one, since graphics engine is clearly not top gen. Animations are nothing special, but they work just fine. 6.  Among the Sleep is very well optimized and runs very smoothly even on my old laptop. I have only 3 negatives and they are:  1.  Game lenght. I managed to run through this game in 4+ hours (and I was exploring almost every corner). Sure it's story is very well made, sure it's atmosphere is amazing, sure the ending is  sorry, you need to experience it yourself and draw your own conclusion  but when I got there, I just wanted more. I understand that developers went 'quality over quantity' route and it's all well and good, but the world they created was so darn good, I really wanted more. 2.  This game is extremely easy. I wish there was some kind of difficulty select or something to make this game more challenging because (in my opinion, it's way too easy otherwise). 3.  Game is also kinda unfinished. As of moment of writing Chapter 5 is missing from the game, and while developers promised to release it soon, it's still nowhere to be found. Chapter 6 ironically is the games ending so what Chapter 5 was all about, I can only guess.At some point devs released one dlc chapter. While it was free, short and sweet, it was just an extra chapter and not Chapter 5. Hopefully it will be released one day but untill now, it's sad and dissappointing. TL;DR and/or conlusion: I really liked this game. It surprised me. Sure there are flaws and I wish it was longer, but other than that I'm extremely happy with this purchase.As far as the horror games goes, it's probably not the best or most scariest one, but it's story and setting is a damn good one. I only hope devs will release Chapter 5 someday in the future and I will be on the lookout for their next game in the future.

Posted: January 11, 2016
												What a game!  I'm not hugely experienced with horror as a genre, but I knew as soon as I heard about this game that it would appeal to me.  The perspective of a toddler as your character is very unique, and it adds a lot more to the game itself.  At times, the game can be completely sweet and innocent, and other times perfectly terrifying.  You mentally put yourself in the position of the toddler as well.  Everything is huge and scary/intimidating to you, having Teddy around makes you feel safe with his voice and personality, and when the going gets rough you just want your mommy.  And being a toddler makes the horror moments all the more terrifying because you are so helpless; you can't fight your way out of a situation.  All in all, the game captures playful innocence, some interesting puzzles/exploration, truly stressful horror and stealth play, and an ending that likely sends people right to discussion forums (seriously, some other opinions on that would be nice ^^;).  It may be very short (I finished in a little more than 3 hours), but it's an unforgettable ride that may merit a diaper change!  8/10

Posted: January 16, 2016
												The game is not bad for a indie title.Don't be fooled by the demo and the trailer! This game is not about a little kid wondering around a big house and experiencing ghost activties. That was only the first little part, you will spend the rest of the game play have fun with (jokeing) walking simulation (as a infant) and find the 4 legendary swords inside the child's inner world.Game play is boring. Monsters and their chasing mechanics are not scary at all. This game turns out to be a nice little story with a sad touch at the end.DO NOT BUY AT FULL PRICE, BECAUSE YOU WILL REGRATE IT!Extra Note: Game is about 2 hours long, keep that in mind.

Posted: January 16, 2016
												If you want to enjoy this game fully you better don't read about it. I got the plot spoiled after waiting for it since it was on development but I still enjoyed it... not the same experience I guess.You are a baby that one night gets into what it seems a nightmare. Nothing beyond reality as you will find out later. You will have to run away from a monster looking for you and try to find your mother going through places that would scare not just kids.There are so few jumpscares. When you are in danger you will be warned so you better run and hide. The "death" animation can be a bit disturbing but it is not a jumpscare I guess since you will see it coming.One of the things I most like is looking down and seeing your body. It's a little detail but it helps with inmersion. And that feeling of being a scared kid is there... you can see harmless things as monsters when there is nothing there: getting scared by a hanged coat, ha!Once you know what is going on it is nice to play it again to see things you might have missed and that you will understand then.The only bad thing is you need a pretty good computer to play it with decent quality and framerate. If you have a so good one it will be so beautiful.

Posted: March 3, 2016
												With modern horror gaming's continual focus on rendering players defenceless to conjure up feelings of fear, playing as a toddler was an inevitable outcome born of this trend, and Krillbite do an adequate job of conveying that helplessness. Roger L. Jackson delivers a great performance as Teddy, who acts as a comforting presence throughout the entire game. Its ridiculously brief duration and general lack of scares are the considerably largest drawbacks that prevent the title from being a standout of the genre.Worth trying.6/10

Posted: February 27, 2016
												First -- play as a toddler, incredible ideaI don't want to spoil the rest but let's just say that the story as it is, is very good. But, it's something that relies on not being spoiled.As a 'game' this thing is terrible, there's no fun, no play -- but that's the thing, we now make things that are technically video games that aren't, well, games. Interactive experiences or stories, walking sims, adventure games -- whatever you call them, the key is story-driven content (this includes the setting, atmosphere, and POV). It didn't get good for me until very near the end, but it was easily worth the price of admittion jsut for that -- because it shaped my feelings of the entire experience up to that point, gave context to small details that didn't have an understood meaning ebfore then -- again, it ends on a really excellent note. A great way to spend a couple of hours, very touching.

Posted: February 29, 2016
												If you ever wanted to play a game where you get to be a scared toddler looking at the world from a baby's vivid imagination, then this is the game for you.Essentially this is another one of those walking simulatory Amnesia style games. Atmospheric, lots of creepy  noises  and monsters who make screeching sounds and get all blurry when you look at them. The game has received a poor PC port with numerous bugs and control issues, so beware. It is also quite short, about 2-3 hours depending on how often you screw up and have to restart at a checkpoint. My biggest enemy was the pits, so I failed a lot.While I was prepared to give this game a thumbs down for its numerous issues and copypasted Amnesia style scares, the ending elevates this game to something much better. It just made the game come together in a big way and since you can pick it up for next to nothing at a steam sale then I say go for it. Just power through the annoying moments and the hammy gameplay and you'll find a very satisfying ending to tie it all together.

Posted: March 10, 2016
												I was a backer of this game on Kickstarter because I loved the concept, and it certainly didn't disappoint when I finally got my hands on it. I don't usually play 'horror' games, and I'm not even sure I'd class this as one, although there were certainly a few moments that utterly terrified me, probably more so than any other game I've played. I'd recently played 'Outlast' which I also enjoyed despite being a 'horror' game, but I think the main difference with the scares in Among the Sleep is that they are unexpected, whereas a game like 'Outlast' is quite tense the whole way through.The way the story unfolds throughout the game through clues and hints makes you pay close attention to what's going on around you without getting in the way of the game itself. However, the only shortfall of the game is that I don't think the story resolves itself very effectively, which was disappointing as I'd been playing close attention to all the clues to work out what was going on throughout the game.There have been several updated to the game since I last played it, so I might have to give it another go.

Posted: April 6, 2016
												Among the sleep is a first person game where the player character is a baby. You play as a small child and along with your trusty Teddy Bear side kick you must search for your mother, solve puzzles, and get through the horrors present in your own imagination. It is a curious and frightful nightmare for the toddler. The narrative goes to some nightmarish places, but it ends all too abruptly, and technical issues apply the sleeping cap to an already mixed release. The story behind the game is a well-written script and the ending is just a little heart warming. One problem the player might have is the control part. If the player does not have a mouse, it would be a hard for them to get through the game. The player would use the trackpad, but it would take some time to move things around and open doors.

Posted: February 27, 2015
												Among the Sleep won't take you very long to complete, but the time you do spend on it will be worth it. It's spooky and disturbing with a puzzles thrown into the mix. (Don't worry, even a baby could complete them). The story becomes somewhat predictable as you progress, but collecting the clues is surprisingly fulfilling. Controlling a helpless baby makes the game that much more uncomfortable, but in a good way, not annoyingly so as I expected. It's a solid game if you're into psychological horror, and probably even if you aren't. When I first wrote the review it was $20 and now it's $15, but I wouldn't recommend paying that much if you can avoid it due to how short the story is. I snagged it on sale for 5 or 10 bucks when it came out. Tip: Don't turn your gamma too far down. If it's too dark it goes from immersive to just annoyingly difficult. Plus, the art style is cool and you probably want to be able to see it.

Posted: April 3, 2016
												Distinctive and surreal, overall a very well put together game. Just finished my second playthrough of it and I enjoyed it just as much as the first time.With a unique interaction style in the world, as an infant you must go through battling real life objects/puzzles and those of a small childs imagination. The deeper you fall into this dream land the more unhinged your perception becomes. Simple rooms or areas become scary labyrinths of the unknown. Although this isn't the point of the game, the story is infact quite sad with a somewhat reassuring ending.I don't want to talk about it to much, you'll just have to play it to see what I mean.

Posted: April 4, 2016
												*SPOILERS DUH*Among the Sleep is a horror experience trauma that gives a perspective of a young toddler going through an adventure with an imaginary talking teddy bear to find the child's lost depressed alcoholic mother. The visuals and effects the developers interpret on how the gamers witness the young child's point of view of the environment surroundings, figures/toys, and the monsters are all a horrifying imagination. Overall, the game has a very unique idea, an original concept, and a wonderful short storytelling experience, but the only downfall is wanting more out of the game. Personally I wanted a little bit more out of the game, more to the story, perhaps what happens next after the father takes the child. Will the mother ever come back? Will she regain strength and fix her issues with alcoholic? Questions left me to wondering on what could happen next. Sequel or without, I enjoyed the overall premence of the game and will give my rating 4/5 stars.

Posted: April 4, 2016
												 The game features a good story overall, with a lot of deep and hidden things that have to be put together, as it is not spelled out to the toddler protagonist. Loved figuring out the child's issues and real problems behind this Alice in Wonderland-type exploration. The controls and mechanics are a little strange. They make sense, with them being a toddler, but the game features a slow waddle in the up-right standing position and a faster crawl. I found myself almost bugging out the game switching back and forth too quickly so I could move around at a faster pace. If you just slow down the animations get laggy, but as long as you let yourself fall into the game this shouldn't be an issue for you. Other than that has pretty good overall controls and mechanics. In closing, I definitely enjoyed Among the Sleep and would recommend it to anyone to give a try to, but good game overall.

Posted: April 5, 2016
												Among the Sleep is one interesting game. The story was really good, the graphics were awesome for a short indie game, and the rush when playing the game is indescribable. Something I do want to say out there is that this game is not motion sickness friendly, so if you do get motion sickness easily do not play this game. The cinematography was in first person which means everything you do or interact with is really close which was a problem with my laptop because I had no mouse just a touch pad. This was extremely annoying as I had to move the screen first then I could proceed to go on forward. It does make me sick playing the game for more than 10 minutes as you are required to move the camera often.  Other than that the game play was smooth and easy to follow, the monsters in the game will scare the crap out of you.

												A very cute and nice looking unique game. The graphics are well done. However there're some bugs with some game mechanics. The game was not scarry or thrilling that much. I liked the puzzles in the game. It kept my interest for whole 80 minutes. VR support would be nice. 8/10

Posted: January 12, 2016
												Among the Sleep is one interesting horror game. Made by norwegian students as university project, I honestly thought this would be hastily slapped together game with interesteting premise, but underwhelming delivery.Boy was I wrong!So here it goes, and remember TL;DR is always at the bottom. Positives:  1.  Story is kept simple, yet interesting at the same time. You play as a baby exploring this nightmarish realm with help from your toy teddy bear. Prologue chapter does good job introducing characters and game mechanics and the baby perspective is pretty damn interesting since it gives this huge opportunity to run wild with creativity and imagination.To be honest, I can't tell too much about story since I'm afraid of giving anything away, but it is surprisingly serious and excellently crafted. 2.  Gameplay is pretty straight forward. Go/ crawl from A to B solving puzzles and sometimes hiding in closets/ under tables or beds. It's basically a Penumbra/ Amnesia clone but with baby as protagonist. But hey, if it works, don't break it, right? 3.  Levels are pretty linear but still very well made. Every location feels unique, looks both interesting and scary and breathes atmosphere. I have to give credits where credit is due, guys over at Krillbite did amazing job bringing this game to life. 4.  Sounds and music are also pretty damn good. Game relies heavily on creepy sounds to make you feel uneasy and does good job with it. Music is used sparingly but when♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan, effect is simpy amazing and terrifying at the same time. When talking about voice work and dialogue, there's not much to it really, since characters don't speak that much, but they are good enough. 5.  Graphics, while not amazing, works just fine. Game is mostly dark, so shadows and lighting effect are only factors that really count, and can make or break it's setting. Thankfully both effects are used very well. Because of this, first level is worse looking one, since graphics engine is clearly not top gen. Animations are nothing special, but they work just fine. 6.  Among the Sleep is very well optimized and runs very smoothly even on my old laptop. I have only 3 negatives and they are:  1.  Game lenght. I managed to run through this game in 4+ hours (and I was exploring almost every corner). Sure it's story is very well made, sure it's atmosphere is amazing, sure the ending is  sorry, you need to experience it yourself and draw your own conclusion  but when I got there, I just wanted more. I understand that developers went 'quality over quantity' route and it's all well and good, but the world they created was so darn good, I really wanted more. 2.  This game is extremely easy. I wish there was some kind of difficulty select or something to make this game more challenging because (in my opinion, it's way too easy otherwise). 3.  Game is also kinda unfinished. As of moment of writing Chapter 5 is missing from the game, and while developers promised to release it soon, it's still nowhere to be found. Chapter 6 ironically is the games ending so what Chapter 5 was all about, I can only guess.At some point devs released one dlc chapter. While it was free, short and sweet, it was just an extra chapter and not Chapter 5. Hopefully it will be released one day but untill now, it's sad and dissappointing. TL;DR and/or conlusion: I really liked this game. It surprised me. Sure there are flaws and I wish it was longer, but other than that I'm extremely happy with this purchase.As far as the horror games goes, it's probably not the best or most scariest one, but it's story and setting is a damn good one. I only hope devs will release Chapter 5 someday in the future and I will be on the lookout for their next game in the future.

												I heard a lot of good things about this game, and while its not the scariest experience I've had, it's definitely worth checking out. It's a beautiful game that manages to escalate in tension the further along you go (as I feel a good horror game should...). The simplisity of the story and some really good voice acting help enhance this quite a bit and I found myself getting sucked into the world. Posted: April 20, 2015
												Among the Sleep is an excellent game, especially for people who don't like horror games in general. The terror is more the kind that you let yourself sink into - sliding into the small hiding places that only you, as a toddler, can fit inside; rushing to climb on top of small boxes to save yourself from a fairy-tale monster; exploring the nooks and crannies of the dreamscapes you find yourself inside; feeling the discomfiture of a world that isn't quite right.The game is only a couple hours long and the story unfolds at a leisurely pace across it, but the world has a lot of very interesting details if you look for them, the simple puzzles do a good job of building tension, and the level design does a very good job of leading your forward and keeping you on edge. I definitely recommend it.

Posted: October 3, 2016
												8/10An unique horror experience that puts you in the small shoes of a 3-years old child, trying to survive the horrors of the dark.The principle is the same as many survival horror games - survive and don't get caught, while you find items and complete puzzles to progress. But right as you start the game and try out the controls, you see how different it feels, since you're in the role of someone incredibly young rather than a fully grown adult. The character moves faster when crawling, but you need to stand up to reach certain things or climb up a ledge. All items used throughout the game are related to toys a young child would have - toy keys, shapes to fit inside a shape mold (squares, triangles, etc), among others.I won't spoil the story, but I'll say it's certainly interesting and the Prologue (free DLC) expands on it, explaining the events before the main game.Highly recommended.

Posted: July 28, 2016
												Just finished the game, and now I am playing through it again with the commentary track. Though this is not the scariest of games, it doesn't try to be. The only word I can describe it is... Nostalgic. We were all children once, and we can all relate with the child in this story on some level. This is the truly creepiest part of this game; not the cliches (which there are very few), but the realism and the imagination behind it. It exceptionally captures the child-like imagination that we go the rest of our lives trying to reobtain. This beautiful and mysterious game will have you remembering the darkest parts of your childhood in the most creative of ways. It is worth twice the amount, simply from the feeling you have after you complete it. Imagine Alice: Madness Returns meets Amnesia: The Dark Descent, and then you will only have a glimpse of the beauty and naive surrealism that is this game.

Posted: November 14, 2016
												The game is short but enjoyable, it is plenty long enough to get it's story told without feeling rushed. I enjoyed the art style and graphics overall and the game is different to anything I have ever experienced before. It is a good concept and one that I would recommend to others. I did have a few technical issues, I had constant framerate drops and stutters and a few random crashes. With an i7 6800k, GTX 1080 SLI (disabled for this one) and 16 GB of fast RAM it was unexpected, it should run like butter but that was not the case. However it was not something that bothered me too much, I still had fun playing. The puzzles are too easy but the story and atmosphere made up for it. All in all I would give it a 7/10.

Posted: July 23, 2015
												For how short the story is, you may want to contemplate for a bit if you want to spend around $20 for this game. I would recommend just waiting for the Steam Summer Sale as it'll knock the price down a LOT. I find that this game is good for those who don't do too well with scary/horror games because the level of creepiness/tension is pretty moderate. There are rarely any popups (in a sense, none) and the whole "horror" feel to this game is based upon the child's incredibly vivid imagination. I personally enjoyed it a lot, mainly because of how cute it was to see something like a door, so big compared to how I would see it in my everyday life. If at any point, the game just seems too creepy to continue, just remember that everything is seen from the eyes of a very creative child.Pros: Impressive atmophere build up. Cute perspective from a child. Graphics are nice. Awesome teddy bear sidekick / flashlight. Creepiness > pop ups.Cons: Kind of short for the price you're paying for the game. Personal Con: It could've been a bit more frightening at some points. Ending was weird. LOL!

Posted: June 23, 2015
												This game could have been so good:Seeing the world in the eyes of a two year old... Check.Beautiful level design... Check.Great attention to the details... Check.Hiding under your mom's bed... Check.Slowly uncovering the story... Check.Carefully carved out atmoshere... Check.But while playing it I got really sad because I considered the potential wasted.It's not that it is too short - why not pay 20 bucks for a great ~2.5h game? - but it lacks in two major points:First of it is underdeveloped.I've come across so many bugs and glitchs I did not bother counting them.Maybe I had just bad luck but at three points those completly broke the gameplay.Also there were many instances where one just felt something missing, be it technical or a design matter.Second, it's not challenging at all.Most of the time one can just freely toddle around the area, without fearing being threatend by the monster.Even when caught by the monster one respawns like 3-5 meters behind and can just walk past that spot.I'd recommed to buy this game when it's on sale, then enjoy the visuals, enjoy all those little details and have fun for a cupple of hours.

Posted: July 1, 2015
												While it may be short (around 3 hours in length), "Among the Sleep" offers an intriguing story with a very thoughtful presentation. The environments are imaginative, and while linear, they offer just enough puzzle solving to stay interesting. The challenges are akin to "Amnesia", where you solve puzzles while avoiding a monster. The monster is presented well. You never get a good glimpse of it, and the reveal at the end is gut wrenching. If you're looking for a good puzzle game with a deeper meaning behind it, play this, though know that it won't take too much of your time, for better or worse.

Posted: May 16, 2015
												Among the Sleep is exactly as long as it ought to be - an intriguing, moving, fantastic game. My only gripe is that the game gives no real feeling of danger until you can get caught. I think token appearances a little earlier would have kept the game more consistently tense. Regardless, if you play with the lights out and let yourself get into it, it's a deeply atmospheric and creepy experience. I'm surprised at all the haters - this absolutely doesn't deserve the mixed reviews it has here. If the price tag turns you off, don't hesitate to pick it up on sale for < $10, you'll absolutely not regret it (if you're into short, sweet indie titles and the horror/suspense genre generally).

Posted: November 1, 2015
												This is an excellent, short, little horror game. Playing as a child is perfect starting point as you are so helpless and vulnerable, you can either walk slowly or crawl but you cannot see too far when crawling. The atmosphere is what makes this game so good. It starts off with a very creepy oppressive atmosphere where you never know what dangers are lurking. Then just when you are thinking it is only a sinister atmosphere and there are no actual threats you catch a glimpse of enemies. There are no really cheap jump scares but lots of menacing corner of the screen glimpses of things and when you do first get caught by the enemy it is terrifying. So this manages to maintain the atmosphere throughout that game where you are never sure if you are in danger or not. My only complaint is that some of the camera movements when climbing made me a little nauseous.

Posted: December 28, 2016
												i thought this was an interesting game. i thought it was cool playing as a toddler, it felt cool seeing things bigger then you like you once did as a child. its a cool experience looking in awe at the gigantic world around you when in reality its no bigger then your room. this game plays with the idea of a childs imagination and how things we see as a normal everyday room because a completely different experience for a child who views things differently then we do. i enjoyed the game overall, if anything i say get the game for the experience alone because it is where this game shines. the atmosphere is amazing and i was not let down.

Posted: January 1
												Nice, original game. I particularly liked the unusual point of view of a 2 year old toddler, who views the world from 70-ish cm high, moves faster when crawling, and sometimes stumbles when he runs.I think many of the negative reviews fall into 3 categories:1) Those who expected a horror game. It is indeed not quite scary (despite being tagged as "horror" on Steam). I don't really like horror games so that was rather a plus for me.2) Those who expected AAA Crysis-ish graphics. Sure it doesn't have some kind of ultra-realistic VR graphics, but the graphics are more than decent and not an issue for immersion.3) Those who found the game too short. Indeed I finished it in less than 5 hours.Overall a good game. Wouldn't buy at retail price ($15), but okay on sale around $6.

Posted: December 27, 2016
												Among the sleep is an indie horror game from both publisher & developer Krillbite Studio, based on exploration. The outcome of the story will be obvious almost from 1/3rd of game, and can't really say anything else about it, to not spoil it, but i must say it reflects on a social problem, that should be spoken more about of.Although the controls are really simple, it's hard to master, because sometimes it's bugged to a point, i have to say it's game breaking. The game supposed to be an indie horror game, but except for a few minutes of tenseness, in most of the playtime it's just a walking simulator from a 2 year old boys perspective who is looking for his lost memories. With the second playthrough the game can be completed in approximately 5 hrs, which in this games particular case is pathetic, and considering that the few achievements that are in the game are reported partially broken, and that i bought the game on sale for 6 Euros instead of 15, i have to say for me it's on the edge of not recommending it, unless it's highly discounted. It's a pity because with a full 8 hrs gametime, and with a few polishments on the controls here, and bug obliterations there it could have been a decent creation. 72/100

content:
Posted: March 9
												I really enjoy the concept of this game, and the overall presentation was very nice, though I felt the scary factor was often more cheesy than creepy.My main gripe about the game is it doesn't take enough advantage of you being a baby.  I liked the symbolism and child-like interpretations that were used, but there wasn't much of it.  Certain game mechanics (like being able to throw things) weren't used much, while others (like pushing objects to climb onto something) were used too much.I think if the game had 2 or 3 more chapters taking advantage of daylight, the additional content associated with it could've addressed my complaints.Overall cool concept.  Good game to play on a rainy weekend.
